name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 16 November 2017.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I would first like to welcome a delegation from the Irish Council of Churches, a cross—border body representing different Christian denominations on the island of Ireland, north and south, who are in the distinguished visitors’ gallery. (Applause) Thank you for giving them a warm welcome. It is a coincidence that I am in the Chair to make this announcement, but I am pleased about it. I would just add that our visitors are in Brussels to have discussions with Parliament and the Commission. This dialogue is provided for in the Treaties. I think it is also important to say that the churches on the island of Ireland have played an important role in the peace process and this is something our Parliament has strongly supported. Only last week, we hosted a very positive exhibition showing the impact of EU peace funding in Northern Ireland and in the border region of Ireland. So I would say to our visitors: you are very welcome, your visit is very timely, and please take back to your communities our message of continued support at this time. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Before we come to the order of business, I have three colleagues asking for the floor. Mr Frunzulică, you have a point of order?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, on 20 November in Kiev, a Forum of the National Minorities in Ukraine took place, including representatives of the Romanian, Hungarian, Polish, Slovakian, Bulgarian, Tatar and Jewish minorities, to discuss the new education law, Article 7 of which forbids the national minorities to educate their children in their mother tongue at all levels. This forum was disrupted by the Swoboda movement, a political party in Ukraine, and they had to be evacuated. I am asking Parliament to take a position on this important matter and on the Ukrainian authorities’ tolerance of such situations. Ukraine is an associate country of the European Union and has to comply with European values: it has to defend and promote European values, including human rights and the rights of national minorities and their right to education in their national, mother-tongue language.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I would like to speak in my mother tongue.Madam President, at this moment I feel obliged to inform this Parliament that the Croatian Parliament adjourned the session, that the BiH Parliament adjourned the session because the Hague Tribunal's verdicts against six Bosnian Croats who were to answer for command responsibility are underway.They were sentenced to large sentences.However, one of those generals, General Praljak, drank a glass of poison during a trial in the Hague courtroom half an hour ago and died in a hospital in The Hague, according to journalists.I believe that if these parliaments adjourned the session, that I, as a Croatian Member of Parliament, am at least obliged to inform you what is currently happening and what are the decisions of the Hague Tribunal regarding the events during the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the facts adjudicated against Croatia personally.I find it absolutely incorrect.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for that important information.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, we all know that political debates can sometimes get very heated and emotional, but I have to say that I was very shocked, even having been in politics for some time, to see the images of a kind of mock hanging of six of our Polish colleagues on the Internet. I am very pleased that President Tajani reacted immediately, and has approached the Polish government and asked it to secure the safety of our six colleagues. The Prime Minister of Poland has condemned the action. However, in the same breath, she immediately said ‘Oh, but look at the behaviour of your MEPs and how they are making slanderous statements about Poland’. As a matter of fact, her party friend and Vice-President of this House has made similar comments about his colleagues, including myself. Now there is freedom of speech for everybody, but I would hope that we have a little bit of respect for each other and that President Tajani will press the Polish Government to not just secure the physical integrity of our Polish colleagues but also to ensure freedom of speech, even when we are saying things that they don’t like.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you very much for that very important statement. As you know, President Tajani is taking action and I think the word ‘respect’ is a word we should perhaps use more often.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, on a point of order: just to ask Ms in ‘t Veld if her same commitment to freedom of speech also applies within the European Parliament, not just outside it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: If I may, colleagues, I am going to answer that question and it is ‘yes’.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: – Madam President, I only wanted to add to what our colleague from the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) has said; that for me it was extremely worrying when I saw on social media the pictures of several of our colleagues from Poland – pictures showing our colleagues hanged. I think that this is not at all something that can be covered by freedom of expression. For me, this was more a criminal act, and what we can expect our colleagues in the Bureau to do, including our Vice-President from Poland, is not only to make excuses for this action and their words but also to act against this action, which I see as a criminal action.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: This is a very serious issue. We have taken note and the plenary has given its support to those concerns, which we deeply share. I am now getting more requests for the floor. I really do not want a debate on this issue, but I will give the floor to Mr Krasnodębski.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Colleagues are worried unnecessarily, the Polish authorities are dealing with this matter.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for that information.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Madam President, we are expressing our solidarity today with several colleagues. I would like to ask the House to show some solidarity with two former Members of the European Parliament who are in jail in Spain. I think we should abandon our conspiracy of being silent as to what is going on there.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, on behalf of the European Parliament delegation to the Budgetary Conciliation Committee, on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure (11815/201714587/2017 – C8-0131/2017 – 2017/2044(BUD)) (A8-0359/2017).

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Chairman of the Committee on Budgets. - Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I welcome the agreement reached within the Conciliation Committee, in the wee hours of the morning, on the night of November 17 to 18, on the 2018 draft budget. Once again, we were able to measure the narrowness of our room for maneuver in a particularly constrained budgetary framework, but, my dear colleagues, we have reasons for satisfaction that I would like to share with you. First, the mid-term review is not a bible. Each annual budget discussion authorizes us to hand over the book on the trade. In other words, the European Parliament retains its prerogatives to discuss the budget each year. Secondly, we have managed to erase the cuts made by the Council, by restoring the majority of the appropriations which it had planed in order to preserve margins for alleged unforeseen expenditure, in particular, the extension of the budgetary facility for Turkey allowing this country to provide accommodation for Syrian refugees. If we have reached an agreement, it is because our priority was to overhaul the programs in section 1a, those which work best, the programs which prepare our future and protect Europeans: research via Horizon 2020, youth mobility via Erasmus, Erasmus + and Erasmus Pro - two programs which, unfortunately, cause frustrations, because we do not have the means to respond to all the good research projects, nor to all the requests made by young people for their mobility - also the interconnection mechanism, via the mechanism for interconnection in Europe, and aid to SMEs via the COSME program. These reinforcements are all the more appreciable as they benefit, my dear colleagues, from new money. We were also able to supplement the resources allocated to security, police and judicial cooperation as well as the rise of asylum and neighborhood policy. Our duty is to ensure the relevance of expenses, their added value. We have a duty to appease our spending urges. We therefore considered it necessary to save money by reducing the appropriations devoted to Turkey's pre-accession. I understand that some of our colleagues would have liked to support the youth employment initiative. Let it be clear, ladies and gentlemen, that we all share this desire to fight against youth unemployment, this scandal which is a cancer for our society. But I would remind you that an amendment of 116 million at the initiative of the European Parliament made it possible to increase the credit line by 50% and that the Commission undertook, if necessary if the appropriations were exhausted, to present a draft amending budget in the course of 2018. Personally, if you allow it, I would like to tell you that I would like us to be able to implement concrete measures, structural measures to fight effectively youth unemployment and promote apprenticeship and the mobility of apprentices, but also that we mobilize in their favor. The few European countries that have this practice in their culture, namely Germany, the Netherlands, Austria and Denmark, have in common a particularly low youth unemployment rate. All in all, I believe that Parliament can be satisfied with the 2018 draft budget. I thank the architects of the agreement we reached in the Conciliation Committee: the Estonian Presidency, which has spared no efforts to achieve an agreement, Commissioner Oettinger and his teams who have also been extremely diligent, presenting us with several versions of what could be an agreement in the Conciliation Committee. Then, allow me to greet our rapporteurs: Siegfried Mureşan has been an admirable general rapporteur, as have Richard Ashworth and Jens Geier.I thank them for the quality of their work.My dear colleagues, I hope and hope that many of us will vote tomorrow on the draft budget of the European Union for 2018.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, on 18 November, after 16 hours of final negotiations, we managed to agree on the budget of the Union for 2018. Parliament, the Council and the Commission have managed to agree on the budget of the Union for next year, and the good news is that the European Union is capable of acting. We have a budget for next year and, more than that, it is a good budget. I say this with full conviction because we are allocating the limited resources we have available for exactly those areas which, at the beginning of the year, we defined together as being our priorities. Firstly, growth and jobs; and secondly, citizens’ safety and security. We have allocated EUR 11.2 billion for research and innovation because this makes Europe’s economy more competitive, more future oriented and more capable of attracting investments. We are allocating EUR 2.7 billion for infrastructure. We are allocating EUR 354 million for small and medium-sized enterprises and EUR 2.3 billion for Erasmus scholarships so that the young people of Europe can travel, can become more competitive, can gain more skills and can be successful on the labour markets tomorrow. We are allocating a total of EUR 350 million to combat youth unemployment and we stay ready to evaluate this programme next year: if more is needed we are ready to allocate more resources. For the time being, we are allocating sufficient resources to give some prospect to those young people who are still looking for a job. In order to bring more safety and more security to the people of Europe we are strengthening the agencies of the Union which have responsibilities in justice and home affairs and in combating terrorism. To Europol we are allocating EUR 120 million and increasing its staff from 550 to 576 people. For the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), the agency which manages refugees in Italy and in Greece, we are standing by the side of Italy and of Greece through this budget and putting enough resources into the EASO to manage the refugee crisis in those frontline states.  We are doing more on defence. We are financing EUR 40 million for a preparatory action on defence research to do more on defence at European level – because Member States want to do this, because it makes sense and because it will enable Member States to save money in their national budgets.  We are also supporting our immediate neighbourhood – the southern neighbourhood, the Eastern neighbourhood and the Western Balkans, those countries that are neighbouring the European Union – where it is in our fundamental interest that stability is being achieved and, of course, we are also giving some important political signals. The reality in Turkey does not go unnoticed by the three institutions, and this is why we are cutting pre-accession funds to Turkey by EUR 105 million because Turkey is currently not respecting European standards when it comes to freedom of expression, the rule of law, and NGOs’ and human rights. We are putting EUR 70 million more in reserve money that will be made available subject to an improvement of the situation there. We are also allocating EUR 4.9 million to tackle disinformation, propaganda and fake news. A preparatory action of EUR 1.1 million will be launched in order to instruct and train EU personnel in Member States, in the eastern neighbourhood and in the Balkans with regard to the risks of propaganda. The remaining EUR 3.8 million will be added to the budget for Union communication in states outside of the Union in order to better communicate the benefits of Europe so that people are well informed and cannot easily fall victim to propaganda. All in all, it is a good budget. It is a budget which supports young people – young farmers, young entrepreneurs and researchers and young people looking for a job – and one which will provide more security to the people of Europe, and I kindly ask the Members of the House to vote in favour of it tomorrow. I would like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, our colleague Jean Arthuis, my co-rapporteur Richard Ashworth and Jens Geier, who was in charge of the budget for this year and with whom we have worked closely, as well as the shadow rapporteurs and, of course, Commissioner Öttinger for having identified the right priorities and for helping us to put EU funds into those areas where they are needed, where they are absorbed and where EU money is well spent.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, earlier this year this House approved an increase of Parliament’s budget for 2018 by 2.3%. Bearing in mind the exceptional additional costs involved in the security threats and also the effect of inflation, I thought this both reasonable and justified. I was therefore pleased to note that the Council was prepared to match Parliament’s restraint. They too proposed a budget increase of 2.3%. Having taken that as a benchmark, I am therefore happy to announce to the House that the overall increase for the other sections in 2018 has been agreed at 2.4%. I am satisfied that this budget enables us to meet three objectives. First, it ensures the institutions have the capacity to meet challenges that lie ahead. Second, that it observes fiscal discipline and, third, that it delivers value for money to European taxpayers. This is a budget of EUR 160 billion, and clearly there has to be a spirit of compromise between the two budget authorities: Parliament and the Council. I was particularly pleased to report that we have been able to provide funding for strategic communications. This I know has been a major concern to a number of parliamentary committees. On the other hand, some of the institutions will be disappointed with the settlement, and here I mention particularly the Court of Justice. I will continue to work closely with the Commission to ensure that additional funds be made available, should that be required to reflect their increased workload. Finally, President I would like to put on record my thanks and appreciation, first to the Estonian Presidency and Minister Kevinin and his team. Second, to Commissioner Öttinger and his team for the spirit of helpful cooperation, to the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Jean Arthuis, who guided the process so well, to rapporteur Jens Geier, but most of all to my fellow rapporteur, Siegfried Mureşan, who has worked incredibly hard and has, in my opinion, done an excellent job. President, this budget is a good outcome for Parliament and I commend it to the house.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is my pleasure to attend the debate today on the EU budget for 2018. All the previous speakers, who have worked very hard on the budget, used the word satisfaction, and I am as well, on behalf of the Council, very satisfied with the agreement reached by the Conciliation Committee in the early hours of 18 November. The discussions were long and at times difficult, not only between but also within the delegations of our institutions.  We have been able to establish a realistic budget providing on the one hand the necessary appropriations to cover the needs expected in 2018, but leaving on the other hand adequate margins to cope with the contingencies in the course of next year.  The Presidency appreciated the constructive atmosphere during these negotiations. The agreement on the 2018 budget was reached thanks to the readiness for compromise on both sides of the table. During our various meetings in the course of this year, be it in trilogue or in conciliation format, as well as during many informal contacts, it became clear that Parliament and the Council share the same two main priorities for the financial year 2018: to tackle challenges related to migration and security and to boost innovation, growth and employment in Europe. In the Union budget for 2018 we have been able to translate these priorities into concrete figures.  I would like to underline that, in addition to funding our shared objectives, the Council had two other guiding principles. Firstly, we considered it important to respect the agreements of the past. This means that agreements on the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) were considered as the cornerstones for our discussions.  Secondly, 2018 could become a difficult year. One of the issues that thus needed to be addressed was how to deal with the continuous challenges in migration, where it is clear that Europe will have to spend more. The package agreed by the Conciliation Committee includes two joint statements: the first one on the Youth Employment Initiative and the second one on the management of payments in 2018. The Council has also issued a statement recalling the importance of limiting the administrative burden by fully implementing our joint agreement on reducing over the 5-year period the number of staff in all institutions, bodies and agencies by 5%.  After the successful outcome reached by the Conciliation Committee on 18 November the Competitiveness Council tomorrow will formally approve the joint text on behalf of the Council. I am looking forward to Parliament approving the joint text tomorrow as well. The general budget for the financial year 2018 will then be adopted within the deadline foreseen by the Treaty. This would mean that, for the first time since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, three consecutive annual budgetary procedures will then have been completed successfully in conciliation without having recourse to a new draft budget to be submitted by the Commission and, consequently, a second round of negotiations.  Just like Mr Mureşan and Mr Ashworth, I would like, as an Estonian, to express my satisfaction about the fact that we have now the strategic communication capacity on steady European funding. So far, it has been funded by the Member States individually, including my own. I would like to thank, not only on my behalf but on behalf of Minister Kivine, who could not be here due to sudden illness, the Chair of Parliament’s Committee on Budgets, Mr Jean Arthuis and the rapporteurs Mr Siegfried Mureşan, Mr Richard Ashworth and Mr Jens Geier for their constructive approach during the whole annual budgetary procedure, for their openness to compromise and for the positive atmosphere persisting among our institutions during the last weeks and months. I would also like to thank all other colleagues from Parliament who, during long and stressful hours on the Council’s premises, showed patience and a spirit of compromise.  Finally, a huge word of thanks to Commissioner Günther Oettinger for facilitating our negotiations. Without your support, Commissioner, it would have been far more difficult to reach a balanced and timely agreement.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honorable committee chairman Arthuis, honorable rapporteurs Mureşan, Ashworth and Geier, dear colleague Maasikas for the Council Presidency, ladies and gentlemen! The fourth financial year in the seven-year budget framework. We have traditional tasks that we fulfill year after year: cohesion policy, infrastructure funding or the two pillars of agricultural policy. And next year we have tasks ahead of us that are ascending tasks that were not entirely predictable in 2013: migration, the refugee crisis, urgently needed aid for refugees, also outside of European territory, border protection, border control and the fight against terrorism . I am grateful to Parliament and the Council that the mid-term review has enabled us to readjust the budgetary framework here and has also given us more flexibility, flexibility between the financial years and between the chapters within a financial year itself Parliament, the political groups in Parliament's Committee on Budgets reached agreement. Only in this way could we re-allocate priorities and finance and implement them in the next year without damaging existing programs. In principle, we were in agreement: growth and employment, security, security, migration were big keywords for the European budget strategy. Nonetheless, it was difficult because, on the one hand, not only was the request for restoring the Commission's proposals in Parliament, but money in addition to this was proposed and, on the other hand, a perfectly understandable priority in the Council was not just to keep the leeway as in the current year but to increase either unforeseen what could come in the next year - disasters, earthquakes, other accidents that the member states alone are calling for and in which solidarity is required - to be fulfilled financially, or also to financially reflect in the budget what is likely to be foreseeable but not yet ready for the budget, such as a second Turkey-EU package for the creation of human dignity for refugees who have to live temporarily on Turkish territory. In this complex situation, the Commission is also grateful for the constructive approach of the Council Presidents. Please, Mr Maasikas, greet Mr Kivine and his whole team, your team, with my personal thanks for this constructive leadership, and I would also like to thank all members, namely the rapporteurs and the chairmen of Parliament's Committee on Budgets . The fact that we made this decision on time at the first attempt without delay shows the European Union's ability to act, even in a difficult financial, economic and political environment. It has also been shown that the budget framework, which was decided in December 2013, is tightly knitted and is therefore hardly able to fulfill all meaningful tasks and expenditures within the upper limits year after year. I am grateful that in heading 1a the ability to act for research and innovation, for Erasmus and school and youth exchanges, for the promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises has been strengthened. I am grateful that we have increased the youth employment initiative - and increased it moderately - and I promise that if it turns out later in the year that the funds we have been used to finance projects, for jobs, for If the outflow of funds should be greater than foreseeable, then we will supplement the corresponding funds with amendments and propose an increase in funds to your two bodies. We don't all have agencies, but we have some Agencies strengthened along the workload that is to be expected.In short, I am now sure that the budget is in line with the tasks and expectations of our citizens for the next year, research, innovation, infrastructure, traditional tasks and quick response in order to tackle new challenges politically but also financially.That is why I am asking Parliament and the Council for approval.I believe that in the limited scope of our financial framework, a better budget structure for 2018 would hardly be affordable.That is why we fully support what has been worked out between the Council and Parliament for us today and for the Council in the next few days.Thank you for that.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Above all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Council for this concession during 16 hours of negotiations, and also to Commissioner Oettinger overall for the fact that we all had the nerve to hold out to the end. I know that this is a tough job every time, but there are certain priorities for Parliament that have to be enforced. I am also very grateful to colleague Mureşan that we did not get up after lunch and go home and say: “There is no budget possible”, but that we really came to an agreement in a very close and direct discussion to do something for the citizens of Europe. It is no coincidence that the 105 million minus in Turkey, where we see major problems with human rights, democracy and many developments, but also the glimmer of hope that we have put something in reserve for an incentive to be able to approach Europe again in the future. Finally, I would also like to congratulate the Social Democrats on the fact that, together with us, they have succeeded in increasing the youth employment package to EUR 350 million. This is an important act for the future because here we are showing that the European Union is setting the right priorities. When you see that the European budget for commitments has only increased by 0.2% compared to the previous year, then I would like to look at the national states in which the budget has only increased by 0.2%. Overall, we claim 0.92% of payments from the gross national product at European level. That is probably the lowest budget that the European Union has ever had in this sense. I am very optimistic that we will finally reach the 1.24 for the multiannual financial framework that we really deserve and that we need in order to put Europe on the right track.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like first of all to thank in a non-formal but sincere way, at the end of this work, even publicly, having already done it privately, President Arthuis, the rapporteur Mureşan and Commissioner Oettinger for the work they have done in the long hours of conciliation. I would like to acknowledge to them that, if during this conciliation we have overcome some principles, as was said by President Arthuis, and we have made some achievements including economic ones, as pointed out by the rapporteur Mureşan and Commissioner Oettinger, it is for their work, for the work they did during the conciliation phase. The fact remains that their hard work, their commitment, etc., cannot see me fully satisfied and cannot see fully satisfied the group that I have the honor to represent here. The problems exist, they are still in front of us all and they are of three orders. They are of a general order, Madam President, they are of a methodical order and they are of a merit order. Of a general order, because for years we have been having to follow a ritual that is essentially empty, in which we wait for the 21 days of conciliation, we wait for the last final hours to try to arrive at a result and an agreement that must be for force a take or leave, and this can no longer be like this. Of a methodical nature, because the discussion that took place, despite our rapporteur, the President and the Commissioner we tried to bring it back on track, was a discussion that the Council wanted - and not out of demerit of the Estonian Presidency, to which my thanks also go - and that it was all aimed solely at the financial aspects of the budget, while we needed to give political answers to the requests of European citizens. We have already entertained a lot about this and a lot has been said, but I think that not all the answers that had to be given have been given, which were not what the European Parliament was asking, Madam President, they were not what we as parliamentarians were asking for, but only what European citizens expected from this European Union. We had to do much more at work, on the issues of immigration and the reception of refugees, and we could have done much more. I believe that this debate, Madam President, has shown that if there is a weak link in this European Union, the weak link is in the Council, certainly not in Parliament and the Commission. In a Council that in the face of citizens' requests, instead of looking citizens in the face, turns its head the other way and tries to solve only the financial aspects. We need today and we will need in the future to respond to the political, economic and social aspects that citizens ask us. This is why our vote cannot be in favor of the budget.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! With the 2018 budget, the EU has failed to send a sufficient signal for a real fresh start in the area of ​​budgetary policy. More than 70% of our budget still goes to agricultural policy and cohesion policy. Agricultural policy has been a challenge in the past. In cohesion policy, far too little attention is paid to what effects we actually achieve with the money we spend. The challenges of the future are to be found particularly in the area of ​​research, but also in the networking of science, then of course in securing our external borders and in a sensible migration policy. However, this must not lead us to simply and purposefully say: “We need more money.” Simply calling out for more money every year does not do our job, because we manage the taxpayers' money here, and with it we handle them carefully and sparingly. That is why we are also against long-term subsidies, rather we should switch to a type of subsidy that is being reduced year after year so that we can get out of the dilemma that once we pay subsidies, we always have to pay subsidies. We should also not forget that we had to give back ten billion euros in the 2017 budget because it was not properly spent. That shows that we didn't have the right focus. It shows that we had way too much bureaucracy and we need to work on that. Ultimately, with this budget, we are also combating expenses and problems that we would not have without the euro as a currency.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, we must tell the truth. It is a tight - not to say skimpy - budget that is being put to our vote, especially with regard to commitment appropriations. Judging from this: with a total amount of commitments of 160 billion, the 2018 budget is only up by 282 million compared to 2017, significantly less than inflation. That said, the combined efforts of our President, Jean Arthuis, our two rapporteurs, Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, and Commissioner Oettinger, to whom I extend my sincere congratulations, have enabled substantial improvements compared to the initial proposal of the Council, which will explain the favorable and unanimous vote of my group. Like my colleagues, I particularly welcome the additional resources allocated to research, young people and SMEs. I also welcome the modest but real increase in the resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative and the unilateral commitment of the Commission to table an amending budget in the event of increased needs. I welcome the additional resources obtained to achieve the objective of devoting 20% ​​of the expenditure of the current multiannual financial framework to the fight against global warming in accordance with the international commitments that have been made. I would also like to welcome the additional resources that have been obtained in the fight against terrorism, by strengthening the operational capacities of Europol and Eurojust. Likewise, by granting more resources to EASO, the 2018 budget strengthens one of the key instruments for the implementation of a real common policy on asylum and the management of migratory flows. I also welcome - like many of our colleagues - the increased appropriations for the Stratcom program, strategic communication from the European Union to third countries. At a time when free and democratic information is threatened by fake news and the propaganda of certain foreign powers, it is important and essential to react. Finally, there is a decrease in appropriations that I want to salute publicly. This concerns the reduction of 105 million and the placing in reserve of another 70 million of the appropriations allocated to Turkey for pre-accession. It is legitimate and urgent to make Mr. Erdoğan understand that the European Union does not subsidize authoritarian abuses or attacks on the rule of law and freedom of expression. Having said that, I also want to publicly express a few more personal reasons for dissatisfaction. I regret in particular that a proposal presented on my own initiative by Parliament's delegation was not accepted during conciliation. It was a joint declaration by the three institutions which called on the Commission to consider the possibility of proposing new legal and financial instruments to help victims of terrorist acts and their families. I also regret that no better account is taken of the real needs of certain institutions, for example the Court of Justice of the European Union. On a budget of 160 billion, I find it difficult to understand the refusal to approve the 1.5 million credits requested and justified by the Court, or 0.000009% of the total budget of the Union. In conclusion, Madam President, the experience of recent years leads me to believe that in its current system, the multiannual financial framework is a corset which freezes the distribution of resources in favor of existing policies and makes room for new policies more difficult. . It is therefore urgent and necessary that the future multiannual financial framework allow greater flexibility both within major headings and between headings, and to ease the conditions for mobilizing flexibility instruments. Such a change is needed, with new resources clean, to face the future.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – There is an impressive list of amounts of spending, there are areas where you feel there should be more. Do you not feel that – since, yes, the UK government may well be about to accede to demands for huge sums of money to leave – after the UK contribution dries up, surely this place should be starting to look at cutting back, because you are not going to have the cash-cow to milk anymore? So, surely it is now time to look at cuts rather than demanding more excess?

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: "blue card" response.- I have no intention and no one here intends to milk the British cow.You have paid your share, as we have all paid.And, if you have listened to me correctly, I have not pleaded for an increase - I would say unjustified - in the budget of the European Union, since I accept and I ask my group to agree to an increase in the2018 budget compared to the 2017 budget which is lower than inflation.So, if you don't mind, I'll save your comments.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after the negotiation we still do not measure up. Despite the proposed budget increase for 2018, an increase of 8% in payment credits is not enough to respond to the problems and challenges that we have to face. This rise is due to the need to make pending payments and the low budget execution of previous years. Basically, his recipes for austerity for people don't work. The budget of the European Union for 2018 - it must be said - will again be restrictive in real terms, since the increase of 1.4% is below the rise in the CPI of 1.7%. Therefore, what we are doing is sacrificing a budget based on the Union's own resources with a progressive tax system - which is what we have to aim for - in favor of public-private investment plans to socialize possible losses. We sacrifice migration and asylum funds in favor of investments in defense, security research and development funds conditional on externalizing our borders. We sacrifice our commitment to a new sustainable and renewable production and energy model in favor of more investment in fossil fuel infrastructure. To measure up, it would be good for us to look, read beyond the numbers and see the real social and environmental needs and act accordingly.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is always a great pleasure to take the floor on budgetary affairs at the very end of the budget procedure and praise all those whose efforts enable us to enjoy the results. We have reached an agreement which could be better, but let’s pay tribute to the Estonian Presidency. Madam President, may I ask you to add the names of Mr Maasikas, Mr Marksoo and the absent Mr Kivine to the minutes of our meeting protocols, if possible with golden letters? I can assure you that my attention will also be on the implementation of those budgets. I have a special interest in the budget of the other institutions. It is surprising how many savings institutions can manage to make in one year. While Mr Deprez pointed out the lack of resources at the Court of Justice and our mean approach towards their demands, on the other hand, my nemesis this year seems to be the Court of Auditors. If we look at the explanations for transfers of appropriations, for example, we’ll see that they forgot that the Court of Auditors was established 40 years ago, and asked for a transfer of EUR 1 million ‘to entertain the members of the Court’, in other words to have a party. This is not something that Europe’s citizens expect us to do. I am not going to criticise any further – you know my attitudes – but I would love Mr Ashworth, Mr Deprez and others to give next year’s rapporteurs the data on all of the transfers so they can make some sense of them in the end. Let me finish with a quote from Sir Paul McCartney, namely that we should not quarrel about money because ‘money can’t buy me love’. This is to provoke Mr Farage, because he might have a different opinion.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, let’s hear it for Commissioner Oettinger, the German commissioner in charge of the European Union budget. You, sir, are having a very good day. Christmas has come early – you must be delighted. The British Government is going to shell out a cool EUR 50 billion as part of our exit proceedings, which, when you think about it, is really rather odd, is it not, because 23 June 2016 wasn’t just significant politically, it was significant for the European Union budget. We have been a net contributor to the EU budget every single year since 1973. For most of those years we have been the second biggest contributor and we pay in 16% of the total European Union budget. But, of course, we are leaving. So logic says that if, for example, a family has an annual income and that income declines, they then have cheaper holidays, they cut their cloth according to their circumstances. And yet, when we look at the 2018 budget or the Commission projections for the next few years, we see that absolutely no account is being taken of the British leaving the European Union. You have decided simply to carry on regardless. And it would appear that in a very weak moment the British Prime Minister has decided to bail you out for it. Well, I would just say ‘Don’t bank on it’ because I think there is going to be a huge public reaction to this extraordinary sum of money. Honestly, I do! I think there is a real prospect of there being a big rebellion within the Conservative Party against their own leader. So don’t think this is absolutely guaranteed. Certainly, the line that I have always taken is that no deal is better than a bad deal, and in this case it’s worse than a bad deal because we don’t even know if we are going to get a trade deal in return. Even if there was a firm offer of tariff-free access to the EU single market, it would not be worth the EUR 50 billion payment. So celebrate for today, Commissioner, but I promise you, it is not in the bag. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Farage, for sure the challenges that the UK budget is facing for next year are much bigger than the challenges that the EU budget is facing for next year. Your revenues are going down, your growth perspective is worsening, investments will be at a slower level in the United Kingdom next year, not so in Europe. The question which I would like to ask you is this. We have increased the budget of the Union for next year primarily for research and innovation. Are you aware how much UK universities are benefiting from this and are you aware which country is the biggest beneficiary of EU research funds?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – The fact that the Office of Budget Responsibility is giving a bearish prognosis for the UK economy does not necessarily mean that they are right. We had lots of people, lots of big organisations telling us that if we did not join the euro we were headed for ruin, and thank God we didn’t do it!  Yes, I am aware of the extent to which our money, recycled through the European Union, comes back to British universities and some of it comes back to be very well spent in research. I acknowledge that and I understand that but, equally, much of it comes back to fund things like Jean Monnet professorships in British universities to teach a completely slanted, distorted view of history. We would rather spend the money ourselves.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I think, for clarification, the House would agree that the United Kingdom is still a full member of the European Union and remains so until the end of March 2019.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Madam President!While working on this budget, I have met many people who are very happy that this budget is so large and is growing so fast.However, I look at it with concern, because it reminds me of a patient who is very happy to see a huge tumor in his body that grows very quickly.The body does not react to it, it treats it as its own tissue.On the other hand, this cancer treats the human body completely differently, just as the parasite treats its host: it strives to destroy it.So what can be said about this in one minute?I can say what the famous character of the movie "Greek Zorba" once said: what a beautiful catastrophe.And the Scriptures make it very clear on this point: pride walks before a fall.Europe is collapsing under the weight of this budget.I am extremely sad, apparently European politicians have stopped reading the Bible.Detriment.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, the Council and all colleagues and all colleagues who are here. First of all, a thanks, thanks and a statement: there is a lot of work on the part of the rapporteurs that we have to underline, in particular Siegfried Mureşan and also Richard Ashworth, but also of all those who were in the negotiating team, chaired by the Chairman of the Committee on Budgets, and which made it possible to reinforce our priorities, which also allowed the agencies to have their resources strengthened. The priority for employment, for strengthening our competitiveness, for promoting youth employment as well, for supporting young farmers, for helping small and medium-sized enterprises, for strengthening security in the European Union, for strengthening also from institutions dealing with the fight against terrorism, to external solidarity, has been achieved. We managed to reverse 1.2 billion euros of Council cuts and reinforced programs like Horizon 2020 for research and innovation. We reinforce support, as I said, for small and medium-sized companies with COSMO, we reinforce the youth employment initiative. We were unable to do and solve all the problems with this budget, of course not, because this budget is about 1% of the European Union's Gross Domestic Product, but it corresponds to 94% of the investment, being only 6% for administrative expenses. In addition, in countries like mine, the European Union budget represents more than 70% of public investment. National competences are in the hands of the Member States and national budgets also have to help and collaborate.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Madam President, I in turn would like to sincerely congratulate our rapporteurs, MM. Mureşan, Geier and Ashworth, for the work done and also thank the Commissioner and his team. At the end of the negotiations, I wanted to highlight some good news which constitutes real increases obtained by the Parliament: 110 million on the Horizon 2020 program to invest in the future, 54 million on Erasmus, 116 million on the youth guarantee . So, I am reassured. The mid-term review to which we had committed a lot was indeed a real review and not a sleight of hand. In addition, in concrete terms, these increases will be able to meet pressing needs. However, we have to admit that these few sparks are not enough to illuminate a darker toll: a cut of 230 million for farmers, nothing on humanitarian aid and only 3.5 million on culture. I must also regret the cavalier manner in which the negotiations unfolded. Parliament must no longer tolerate it. It is no longer acceptable for the Council to present its position to us just a few days before the deadline, thus putting the knife in Parliament's throat. It’s hard to admit ministers parading in Gothenburg but none deign to negotiate the budget. And how can we be satisfied that, after midnight, the ambassadors desert when the crucial points are still to be discussed? But above all, how to tolerate the insincerity of the Council, which reflects on this budget by imposing to keep extravagant margins in order to subsequently finance the facility for Turkey while showing, of course, a decrease in the pre-accession envelope. The list would be too long, but the conclusion is brief: the account is not there and the Group of Socialists and Democrats will not be able to support this budget. I propose that in the future Parliament refuses to enter into negotiation before the Council has a clear mandate.Above all, I hope that the Council and Parliament can define a budget based on real needs and not on national selfishness and hidden projects and with means mainly from own resources.(The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: blue-card question. – Ms Thomas, I think it was at 4 o’clock in the morning – and I have to congratulate you – you insisted on the EUR 350 million for youth employment, for young people, and I think we made great progress in front of the Council and the Commission. So I am now interested to know whether tomorrow you will vote in favour of this EUR 350 million for young people, for the workforce, for their future?

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: answer "blue card".- Mr Rübig, first of all, we should be sure that these 350 million are not an anticipation of funding, but a step forward.At the moment, this point is not very clear.And to give a concrete answer to your question, tomorrow we will abstain.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I would like to point out that the increase in commitment appropriations in next year's budget compared to this year is symbolic: only 0.2%. On the other hand, payments are clearer, because they increase by 14%, but it seems that this level of growth may be insufficient due to the fact that we are entering the second half of the implementation of the multiannual financial perspective for 2014-2020 and all beneficiaries accelerate the implementation of projects co-financed from EU budget. The point is to avoid a repetition of the payment arrears problem that we experienced in 2012-14, when at the end of this period we had almost EUR 30 billion in arrears. Let us recall that next year's payments of almost EUR 145 billion are, for example, EUR 3 billion lower than the payments actually made in 2013, at the height of the arrears crisis.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - Madam President, the ALDE Group supports the outcome of the Conciliation Committee's work and tomorrow we will vote in favor of next year's budget. I believe that, through this budget, we will be able to boost the European economy, which is in a positive mood. We are making significant investments in reducing youth unemployment and improving the opportunities for SMEs to operate. We are also taking steps to increase climate finance. However, it is unfortunate that we are still not fulfilling our commitment in the Paris Climate Agreement of a 20% budget share for climate finance. I hope that, when presenting the next annual budgets, the Commission will ensure that the budget is in line with the commitments we have made. We believe that we are making the right decision by cutting Turkey's pre-accession funding by EUR 105 million. Human rights and respect for the rule of law are at the heart of European values. I am pleased that now we will send a strong political message to the Turkish leadership not just in the sidelines of the recent worrying development. Ladies and gentlemen, citizens often assess the acceptability of the EU in terms of its spending. Working as a negotiator of my group, I am more and more convinced that we need a clearer and more transparent budget and the EU's spending. If we continue like this, we will not be able to build lasting confidence in our Union. The coming years will not be easy from a budget point of view either. The British are leaving, and a large net contributor is leaving us. The EU, that is, we must therefore also be able to innovate, also save on expenditure and redirect it to new destinations. The majority of the European Parliament constantly wants an ever-increasing budget. Many Member States disagree. A solution must be found to this. The European Union's priorities are changing and the new priorities must have the necessary funding. However, this cannot mean that priorities alone are increasing.Then we will no longer have any priorities, but everything will be just as equal.So we need to find savings and re-prioritize.In this work, as decision makers, we have a lot of room for improvement.Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Mureşan, for his very meritorious and cooperative work.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, we are here today to debate the agreement on the European Union budget for 2018, but it would seem to me that the European Union budgets for 2019, 2020 and as far as is reasonably foreseeable into the future might just as well have also been agreed. The United Kingdom has been a net contributor to the European Union since we joined it in the 1970s and it was one of the richest countries in Europe.  As Members we have always paid in more than we got out and will continue to do so again in 2018 because those are the rules and because we are still Members, despite the fact that by the end of 2018 it will be two and a half years since the UK voted to leave the EU in that referendum. Of course, according to this budget, we will still be paying in over GBP 18 billion a year gross and then get back roughly half of that in rebate and EU funding.  Bizarrely though, it seems that the UK will still be paying into the European Union after leaving the EU, whether it is GBP 40 billion, or GBP 50 billion – EUR 45 or 55 billion. The UK has no legal liability whatsoever to pay any form of divorce bill. Of course if you have an agreement, then you expect something in return for your money. Yet Theresa May has surrendered that. She is expected to surrender too on the Northern Ireland border and to surrender too to allow European courts jurisdiction over the EU post-Brexit, which is what we voted to get out of in the first place.  The killer question though for the British Prime Minister is this: can you show us one single thing that you have actually obtained in return? Show us one concession that has been made on the EU side because all we see is you caving in whilst British ‘remain’ politicians egg you on. Of course you cannot, so in 2018 the British taxpayer will continue to foot the bill. And when it comes to that divorce bill, that is the equivalent of GBP 1 000 for every adult in the UK, without any guarantee of anything in return, that has been signed up to by Theresa May.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – May I ask my colleague, Mr Arnott, whether he thinks that the UK, as a civilised European country that shares European values and defends and promotes European values, should have to pay its normal bill and remain in a close relationship with Europe as it is intending to have access to the common market and the customs union of the European Union?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – Of course, in any negotiation, you want a little bit of give and take and you want something to happen on both sides, but what we have got at the moment is all ‘give’ from the British Prime Minister’s side and all ‘take’ from the European Union side. When you start from the legal basis on this, where the Treaties under Article 50, subsection 3 of the Lisbon Treaty say that the Treaties shall cease to apply, that overrides all other things. The hierarchy of norms applies. So there is no legal requirement for the UK to pay.  Of course, if you leave and services have already been provided, then there is a reason to say ‘yes, pay something for that’. But of course there are arguments on both sides and the UK could easily take aim, for example, at a share of the European Investment Bank.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - Today we are again discussing the EU budget for 2018. Now more than EUR 140 billion, but if it is up to the President of the European Parliament, it will double in the coming years. Supported by the other Europhiles in this house, he shows their true intentions. So don't be frugal with taxpayers' money, instead introduce a European tax and let go of the 1% norm of gross national income. Our view is that taxation is an exclusive competence of the nation-states and that the sovereignty of the states should also be respected by the President of the European Parliament. We know this as the principle of subsidiarity, which the left-wing elite here, if it seems to be convenient for them, also does not care. In view of the limited mandate of the European Union, we see opportunities to significantly reduce the generous EU budget, for example by cutting back on the internal organization, the generous rewards, senseless journeys and the moving circus between Brussels and Strasbourg. We do not believe, like the President of the European Parliament, that an additional EUR 140 billion will end problems such as fortune seekers storming Europe's borders. I also wonder why the President of this Parliament gets the legitimacy to argue for a doubling of the budget and the levying of European taxes. Did he have a mandate from a majority of this Parliament for that? Who did he speak on behalf of? At least not on behalf of our group!

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by thanking Mr Murešana for a really professional job well done. The last couple of months have been very tense in the Committee on Budgets, but on 18 November, exactly the day of the proclamation of Latvia, the Council and the European Parliament reached an agreement on next year's budget. "What do we want to achieve?" asked the previous speaker. Next year, instead of building castles of light, not castles of air, we must use this budget to work actively to make our economies stronger, universities more competitive and businesses better prepared to compete in the global market. EUR 350 million is earmarked to support SMEs in the COSME program. EUR 11 billion has been allocated to Horizon 2020. I am very pleased that the Connecting Europe Facility for Transport has also managed to maintain the funding that the Council wanted to reduce by EUR 200 million. Next year, almost 2 billion will be allocated to all European-level infrastructure projects, which include not only the Baltic States, but also Rail Baltic, which is important for the rest of Europe. Of course, I am particularly pleased that both pilot projects I have co-sponsored have been supported. € 800,000 has been allocated to a study on the differences between identical products in the European single market, demanding equivalent product quality in both Eastern and Western Europe. President Juncker also pointed out that such differences were no longer acceptable. In turn, 1.1 million will be allocated for a pilot project on more efficient work with disinformation implemented by Russia. I am really pleased that, at the end of this lie, the fight against this lie is being given due attention, extra money has been allocated and it is not too much money. It can only be seen as a start, because the future of our Europe depends to a large extent on it.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: - Madam President, three messages, very fast. The first, of course, is to thank Mr Mureşan and the rest of the rapporteurs for the work they have done. We believe that they have done a very serious job and that they have defended the position agreed by Parliament very well. The second, a very quick assessment of the results of this conciliation. We believe that these are results very similar to previous years. It has been neither better nor worse. Some programs have been improved, but we think that much more can be done. And that is why I want to focus on the third message. Because the Socialist Group is going to abstain in tomorrow's vote and we want to explain why. As I say, not because we are not happy with the work that the speakers have done; not because we believe that it is a worse result than in previous years, but we believe that we must give a touch of attention to the way in which the meetings are conducted. You cannot negotiate a serious budget in one day, in sixteen hours, at 4 in the morning. You cannot leave issues on the table, without even entering to debate. We have not been able to talk about proposals like Mr. Deprez's. We have not been able to talk about the European Solidarity Corps and therefore we want to send this wake-up call to the Council and we hope that next year things may change.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - I am pleased that the position of the European Parliament to further increase the budget for 2018 has failed.Here in the European Parliament, we need to take a much more critical look at the expenditure of the European Union.We must ensure that money is well spent and that citizens pay as little tax as possible.Not all money that the European Union receives from taxpayers must, by definition, actually be spent.I therefore propose a European “Salmon standard”: income should no longer determine expenditure.The European Union has to deal with any setbacks itself.If more money is spent on the one hand, it will have to be cut elsewhere.I hope that this system will be applied in the new multiannual financial framework.Clearer priorities will have to be set, especially when the budget decreases as a result of Brexit.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, three very quick points on this agreement. One is a general and political point referring to Turkey. Finally, even if with little courage in terms of figures, it was decided to cut the funds. A reflection on this: I have been asking for four years in the Committee on Budgets to intervene on the pre-accession funds for Turkey, and I was always told that it was a problem, because technically it could not be done, there were regulations, and so on. This approach and this cut show that, when there is political will, especially of large groups, there are no rules that prevent intervention with cuts, but it is done. When there is political will, expenses that are unfair are cut. I hope that on this issue, in the coming months and in the next budgets, it will be decided to act with more cuts on this type of funds. The last point, which shocks me, concerns Russian propaganda: one million euros to counter fake news and Russian propaganda. Here, my question mark is about the limitations of freedom: who will decide what is true and what is false, and according to what criteria. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Regarding this money that has been spent on propaganda, I would like to know if you think that there is far too much European propaganda by the European Parliament, such as the House of History? I call it the House of Horrors; it does not seem to relate to any reality I know of. Do you not think that money should be cut from that budget instead of spending a lot of money saying how wonderful the European Union is and how wonderful the President, the Chair and all the rest of them are? What do you think, sir?

name: Marco ZANNI
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- This is exactly the point I was trying to underline, namely who will decide what is true and what is false, who decides that the information that comes from outside the European Union is propaganda, or whether there will be a body that will verify the material, for exampleinformation that the Union distributes in schools, showing these institutions as perfect, without any problems.Here, this is the real point: who will decide what is true and what is false.This is very dangerous.The European Union spends many millions of euros every year on information, which is not verified by anyone.So it seems like an unequal treatment to me.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Just an observation, Mr Coburn: in our history there were many horrors. I think colleagues would agree with that.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! At the moment we are discussing the budget for 2018. It must be remembered that 2018 will be a time of very intensive work on the next multi-year financial perspectives, but also of intensive work on negotiations with the United Kingdom. This is also the year in which we are looking at the results of the mid-term review that we carried out and proposed as Parliament. Revision, which on the one hand increased the flexibility of the budget, and on the other hand was not a document binding the hands of participants in the legislative process. Hence, the discussions on the 2018 budget - which were difficult and complicated - gave some grounds for thinking that the next negotiations on the multi-annual financial perspective will take place in an atmosphere of cooperation and collaboration. It is extremely important to us whether, firstly, the European Commission will cooperate with Parliament when preparing the proposal and, secondly, whether the Council will be flexible and open enough that it will treat Parliament not only as the body that will finally approve but will cooperate with Parliament. The result of negotiations on the 2018 budget, which does not satisfy everyone, but is a success and achievement for everyone, indicates that it is possible that in the coming year we will not only spend money from the 2018 budget, but work together on a new perspective for the period after 2020.

name: Manuel dos SANTOS
text: - Madam President, the strongest feeling I have towards the budgetary agreement with the Council for 2018 is dissatisfaction. I do not mean to say that with the current agreement we have gotten better or worse than we did with previous agreements, but that it is absolutely essential to do, within the framework of Parliament and the Council, a thorough reflection on the budgetary process. The approval of the budget, that is, of a legal basis for obtaining income and making expenses, is an eminently political act, which implies that objectives, priorities, commitments are discussed. Now, with the current budgetary method, involving the two budgetary authorities and the Commission, and with the current rules, such political reflection is either impossible or very difficult. Therefore, the major reflection on the 2018 budget, and the main conclusion to be drawn from the numerous meetings and discussions, including conciliation, is that it is necessary to change the method. That is what I hope, desire and propose, Madam President. Finally, I want to mention that, despite an attempt by the Council, it was possible to keep the interinstitutional agreement informal, without disturbing the budget of the Council and Parliament.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Madam President, we really have to pay tribute and congratulations to the general rapporteur on the budget, Mr Mureşan, who - together with the rest of the budget group - has made significant progress in this budget. It has managed to turn the budget in a social direction and get extra funding for young people, for our farmers, for development, innovation and Erasmus. We must not lose sight of the fact that this budget of EUR 160 billion is a budget financed by taxpayers, who demand that every euro of the budget be directed to all those actions which require respect for the principles and values ​​of the European Union. Union. It is inconceivable for us to fund countries that do not respect either the principles or the values ​​of the European Union and, on the contrary, infringe in all ways on all these principles and the value system of the European Union. I consider it an important step that there have been cuts in Turkey. Let me remind you, however, that Turkey is the permanent offender, which daily attacks the positions and principles of the European Parliament. Let me remind you that Turkey is the country that violates human rights inside, but also violates human rights in a member state of the European Union; in the Republic of Cyprus. It does not recognize the Republic of Cyprus, it maintains occupying troops, it interrupted the talks despite the efforts of the President of the Republic of Cyprus, and for us it is inconceivable that this country should be financed even with one euro. I am not going to approve or vote for a single euro for countries like Turkey that violate the principles and values ​​of the European Union.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! As the standing rapporteur for the agencies, I would like to thank the colleagues who were on the rapporteur team. I would particularly like to thank Siegfried Mureşan, who has succeeded me as general reporter. I felt very well represented with you, Siegfried, and you represented our affairs and the agency's affairs excellently. We were able to strengthen the agencies that deal with border management, asylum policy and the fight against terrorism, and we also managed to get more resources for GSA in the negotiation round. I look forward to when Galileo, the European satellite network, is operational because I believe that it will be a great gain in innovation for Europe. But we have the same problem every year: the multiannual financial framework is not working. The challenges facing the EU in 2013 could not be foreseen. The trust funds and the financial facility for refugees in Turkey underline this. Unfortunately, the Member States do not have the strength to change that. That forces us to do tricks that I like to call household voodoo. We are in a situation that was not foreseeable. The solution is more equity.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm go bhfuil seans agam labhairt ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo, Buiséad 2018, agus tá áthas orm freisin go bhfuilimid ag caint faoi mhéadú in ionad laghdú. Laghdú a theastaigh ón gComhairle, méadú a theastaigh ón bParlaimint agus an bua ag an bParlaimint sa chás seo. Teaspánann sé go bhfuil cumhacht againn. Therefore, the EUR 750 million cut which was originally introduced in the Council position, that now has been reversed, as well as the success of Parliament in mobilising an additional EUR 104.1 million to the global margin for commitments. I think this is very important because it will cover initiatives proposed by Parliament, especially on areas close to my heart – Horizon 2020, Erasmus, COSME and Interrail. These are largely new allocations, which I particularly welcome given the Council’s overarching focus on cuts and the only option in accordance with the political declaration signed in the context of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) midterm revision.  However, Horizon 2020 has brought significant technological progress, not least in clean energy technologies that will help us to meet our targets and this is the best return of all the commitments we have. Erasmus has massive uptake. My own country in particular has more and more students who gain experience that previous generations could not even have imagined by spending time in different Member States. COSME is supporting a significant number of the SMEs that are the lifeblood of our economy. I also very much welcome the allocation for the Youth Employment Initiative, increasing it to EUR 350 million. I think this is a wonderful development and a potential increase is also mentioned in due course.  Finally I am very pleased Parliament has dealt with important issues to me especially and my country: on young farmers, an increase of EUR 34 million; climate, an increase of EUR 95 million; and milk storage: an increase of EUR 2 million. A great job! The rapporteurs deserve our praise and our gratitude.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: - Madam President, yesterday we had the 9th, we have the 10th trialogue in the evening to simplify the budgetary rules, which are also closely linked to this budget. The European Parliament and the Commission want recipients of Union funding not to be able to use tax-avoidance box companies and structures that use aggressive tax planning that do not meet the criteria of good tax governance. We are fighting for European money to be available to entities established in those jurisdictions that apply internationally agreed tax standards on transparency and the exchange of information. The Council is not clear on this line. I think that the Estonian Government has a different view than those members of the Council who are avoiding such protection of European resources. I therefore call on the Council representative to draw the attention of Council members to the fact that if we want to improve the living conditions of the Union's citizens, if we want to prevent money leakage from public coffers, if we want to restore citizens' confidence in a common European project, The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the comrades of my political group who defended our priorities during the budgetary conciliation in a difficult climate, once again facing an inconsistent Council and little conscious of its responsibilities. But today, dear colleagues, my Europe is hurting. Admittedly, the European Parliament has achieved some progress on heading 1, including Erasmus and youth employment, and on heading 2, with a boost in the installation of young farmers, but this is only one drop in the ocean of needs that we regularly discuss in this hemicycle. These new policies, often relevant, which the Council proposes to us, without bringing the necessary new money, oblige us to undress Paul in order to dress Peter. Every year it's the same process and every year we give in. I'm sorry, but the only weapon I have today to try to shake things up and take responsibility is not to pass this budget.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the European Union budget is indeed like Christmas in that it comes round at the same time every year. I would say to the Council, in thanking everyone for their work, that the least we can do, when we know that the budget is coming around at the same time every year, is to come to the negotiations with a proper mandate so that we can make progress in a businesslike fashion. I hope that will be taken on board in the future. You cannot have everything in a budget, but I would welcome much of the progress that was made, particularly in areas such as youth unemployment, which remain particularly urgent. However, I would say to the Commissioner that, where there are perhaps issues with take-up, I hope he would undertake to look urgently at how these programmes can be simplified in the future. I also welcome the progress on Horizon 2020 and Erasmus. This is not remote stuff, this is real research, real students educated, real lives transformed, real lives saved through that research, and new frontiers of humanity pushed forward.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, in the context of the debate and vote in the EP ministerial on the 2018 budget procedure, I completely support the results of the agreement by the Budget Conciliation Committee for 2018. The joint conclusions on the 2018 budget were negotiated and adopted in the EP Conciliation Committee on the morning of 18 November. The document reflects the priorities of my country, Romania, such as the adequate provision of resources for the financing of the cohesion policy and common agricultural policy in 2018. The agreement is an important one because it includes payment of EUR 46.5 billion for cohesion policy funding (Subchapter 1B), payments that will cover the volume of applications that will be sent for payment from the EU budget in 2018. This is extremely important for Central and Eastern European Union Members. During the negotiations there was a high risk of reducing payment appropriations in the case of cohesion policy. However, it proved possible to protect payments at a level close to that proposed for the common agricultural policy.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, the joint draft general budget of the Union will be adopted. Proof is that the signing ceremony has already been scheduled for immediately after the vote. I wish, however, that this was the only flawed piece of interinstitutional farce, which ended in a dramatic fiasco. The priority and desire of the political elite is to spend funds in the already robust Member States and in third countries that are pressuring and blackmailing situations through directed illegal immigration. Loud statements and paid propaganda do not lead to sustainable development, decent work or a reduction in chronic unemployment in the weakest countries. It is utopian - if not criminally naive - to expect better results by implementing the same policies, with known and failed tools. Citizens oppose and dislike this Union. It is important to prioritize the real problems and needs of the citizens and to find effective solutions. Otherwise, in a few years, the peoples of Europe will be the foreign body of the Old Continent.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to commend the work on the 2018 budget, and in particular the chapters on tackling the migration crisis and the fight against terrorism, as well as the very balanced areas for supporting young people, whether for Erasmus, or for a general program to support the employment of young people. Young people need a sense of perspective in the European Union, and it is really very good that this is the area that has been increased. However, I would like to draw attention to three points on which it would be good if the Commission, in cooperation with Parliament and the Council, could better guard them in the future. On the one hand, it is the use of resources for development aid who actually gets that money, and how that money is actually implemented. On the one hand, it is a better control of the funds spent through the Cohesion Fund, and, last but not least - as my colleague before me mentioned - which companies participate in the use of European money. Are they really real companies or are they some box companies that are cutting state budgets in this way?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we are talking about the European Union budget, which finances - and even loosely - countries that do not respect the principles and values ​​of the Union; a budget that finances Turkey, which threatens Greece with casus belli if it proceeds to increase its territorial waters to twelve miles. Turkey, which violates Greek airspace and Greek territorial waters, is challenging the Treaty of Lausanne and desecrating Hagia Sophia. Turkey, which has filled the Aegean islands with thousands of illegal immigrants, has invaded Cyprus illegally, holds 37% of the Republic of Cyprus and violates the Cyprus EEZ. At the same time, the European Union budget is financing Albania, which is violating the rights of the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus, demolishing houses in Chimarra and making illegal claims on Greek soil. So I am not going to vote for such a budget.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President, although there is clearly no budget on earth that anyone can fully accept. We have all heard comments that also present joys and criticisms. However, I would now rather focus on the pleasures, and I would like to draw your attention to the new phenomena that lie in this budget. Such is the case with the so-called 'smart villages' initiative, and this is first reflected in the budget through a so-called preparatory project. I believe that in an environment where only 6% of farmers in agriculture are under the age of 35, we are actually talking about an aging profession, on which the future of Europe, Europe's nutrition, lies or falls.
