I think this initiative deserves special attention, and I thank Mr Mureşan very much and everyone who drafted the budget for contributing to this.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - President! I would like to say to Commissioner Oettinger. Your name is well known in Hungary, as you have made the historic, exploratory confession that the cohesion money given to Hungary and other former communist countries from the European Union actually goes almost entirely back to Western countries, Western companies, multinational companies. . You cried out with childish sincerity when, because of our migration policy, they wanted to punish us by losing and withdrawing this cohesion money. He said, "God forbid, for I would punish the West!" My question is: what is your opinion on this budget in terms of cohesion, in terms of convergence? Is there an “impact assessment” at all on the extent to which such a budget reduces the huge income and living standards gap between the West and the East? I look forward to your reply, Commissioner. Thanks!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We have taken on board the large number of requests to speak and will, on the one hand, heed them for measures to implement the budget; I do not think that one can say: “The current budget framework is not working.” With flexibility and other instruments, we can deal with the most important tasks and expenses for all problems. Nonetheless, Mr Geier, we can learn from this for the next budget framework by trying to integrate external funds and instruments in order to strengthen Parliament's royal right and, secondly, to measure total income somewhat more in line with the known expenditure plus not yet Concretely foreseeable but more likely new challenges that will always arise over a seven-year period. Now, after four years, that shows all too well. There was mostly approval of the budget framework, but there was also harsh criticism. I regret that only one member of the tough critics remained in the room. The issue of the UK's withdrawal has been raised by some of those now absent. We don't have an agreement yet. But one thing is clear: we have a unanimously approved budget framework that will last until the end of 2020. That was also decided in December 2013 by the then British government; she agreed to him. It consists of income, commitments and payments, i.e. expenditure. And if we are now entering into commitments for major infrastructure projects in these budgetary years - railway measures, road measures or research projects - then we must expect that all 28 participants will give us the income for the entire budget, so that unanimously decided expenditures can be made without any disadvantage for any of the remaining Member States. That's what I call consistency and fairness - we expect nothing more and nothing less. Again: the budget framework requires unanimity in the Council. The UK government has approved the entire volume by the end of 2020. I think we can show a lot of added value in this budget; that is important to me. We invest and add value by investing at European level and not just at Member State level. First: research projects. In a dynamic research world, with knowledge of Silicon Valley, Pentagon, Beijing, Shanghai and Seoul, we must see that with such important research goals in the digital age, no member state - not even the large member states - and no company is able to achieve the speed, To go from research to development and production, to create alone. With European research teams - Delft, Oxford, Grenoble, Munich, Cambridge - and with the research industry, we manage to stay ahead in global competition where we are ahead and to keep up with where we are currently behind. Clear added value for every member state, for the European labor market, for European economic strength and competitiveness. A second example: cohesion. As a citizen of a net payer member state, I am proud that part of the money that taxpayers from Germany, among others, put into the European budget goes to Bulgaria for infrastructure projects. Because the per capita GDP is on the European average at 30,000 euros, in Luxembourg at 90,000 euros, in Bulgaria at 6,500 euros. This distance would tear Europe apart and create opposition and not partnership on the continent. That is why we do not have to bring Luxembourg down through sustained cohesion policy, but bring Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and Romania up. That's a clear one Mission of a solidary continent, which thus also creates peace across language and territorial borders. I am proud that this is happening. I think we should all be proud of it - no matter where we come from, no matter how wealthy and competitive we are now. A third example: no Member State alone has the authority to make a difference when it comes to climate protection - no Member State! This was shown in Copenhagen in 2009. There was no European strategy, no mandate for the European Union. The opposite example: Paris 2015. We had common goals and were successful together. I believe that our British friends in particular, to whom climate protection is rightly very important, must understand that without the European Union, Europe would no longer be relevant in the global discourse when it comes to climate protection. Another example that I would like to address is the agricultural budget, which is often criticized. There are a few things that can be improved on the subject of greening and climate protection. But the fact that we try to organize healthy food, enough food and intact rural areas with 30 cents per citizen of Europe per day and largely manage it - for 30 cents per citizen and day - is an inexpensive use in the European household with great benefits for everyone who wants healthy foods, drinks and local fare in Europe. I could suffice to mention other examples. I come to the end. Of course we can also make savings in the European budget. But we always have to see: for every 100 euros that a European citizen earns through manual labor, brainwork or investments, 40 to 50 euros go to the public purse. One euro of these 40 to 50 euros goes to Europe. There are 39 to 49 euros in London, Berlin, Paris, Rome, Tallinn, in the regions, in the municipalities. That means we are basically only a fortieth to a fiftieth of what is being spent from public coffers, actually a very economical event.Anyone who argues so vehemently against European budget policy or even speaks of propaganda instead of information that defames the house of history as a house of horror - just done - lives, I believe, in a different, at least not in a correct world.(Applause)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for this very interesting exchange of views. It has shown that, despite some differences, which are quite natural, we are united in our commitment to making progress for the benefit of Europe and its citizens. The negotiations on the 2018 budget took place in complex circumstances and in my introductory remarks I also referred to some discussions, not only between the delegations, but within the delegations. In spite of this, we worked together in a constructive manner and were able to reconcile our positions on how to finance the different priorities and actions of the Union. I am convinced that the agreement reached is a good and balanced result, allowing the Union to act and to react to the various needs.  Thank you very much once more and I wish you wisdom for tomorrow’s vote.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Chairman of the Committee on Budgets. - Madam President, here we are at the end of a very interesting debate on the draft budget of the European Union for 2018. I thank Minister Matti Maasikas for recalling that, over the past three years, we have achieved to an agreement. There was the idea in the European Parliament that we were failing every other year. We failed at the end of 2014 on the 2015 draft budget, but, my dear colleagues, it is not enough to fail to have a better budget. What I remember is that the version developed at the time by the Commission did not make any significant changes. When you're fighting a battle, you have to be prepared to go all the way, including refusing to vote on the budget, but I did not find, at the time, the support one could have imagined in this regard. Having said that, I would also like to convince my colleagues who have given us to understand that they could abstain tomorrow. I would like to be sure there is no misunderstanding. First, Mr Viotti could be grateful to us for making sure that the mid-term review is not an intangible bible, quite the contrary, and we have demonstrated this. Mr Viotti will be general rapporteur next year, and he will be grateful to us for demonstrating this. Mrs Thomas, I would like to try to convince her anyway. First of all on one point: you told us that there were not enough funds for humanitarian aid and, if I had one small complaint to make to our dear Commissioner, it would be that he could - to be able, on the occasion of the budgetary reconciliation, to tell us that he was preparing to carry out a transfer project of 62 million taken from the appropriations of the Turkish pre-accession, and this in favor of humanitarian aid. Do not take it in a bad light, Commissioner, I just want to say that this argument could allay the fears of Mrs Thomas and convince her to vote this draft budget. Second element, she tells us that, concerning the initiative for the employment of young people, basically, she fears the concentration of credits at the beginning of the period, and it is true that last year, there was a note of bottom of page, but this note disappeared. There were no comments, no restrictions on the part of the Commission, on the vote of the 116 million amendment that was passed, so there are no restrictions, Mrs Thomas. I wanted to allow myself these observations and tell you, dear colleagues, that our budget, as we have recalled, is 1% of European gross domestic product and that, in this budget, 80% is earmarked, i.e. common agricultural policy, either to the Cohesion Fund, country by country, to the nearest euro, as well as to the institutions - the Commission, the Parliament, the Council, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors and a number of other European institutions. So I trust the Commission. Commitments have been made, in particular for the Court of Justice, and I have no doubt that they will be honored. I also heard commitments that were going to be made in relation to the wishes expressed by our colleague Deprez on the assistance that would be given to victims of attacks. I'm confident. So, for those of you, dear colleagues, who would have had a hesitation, I would recommend that you vote for this budget for 2018 tomorrow. It would be a way to calmly prepare the next multiannual financial framework.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 30 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - 2018 will remain the year of a budget without vision and ambition. Without ambition, first of all, for young people, since, while an entire generation is going through an unprecedented crisis, the European Union is satisfied with a second best, from volunteering to jobs without prospects, intended to temporarily subtract unemployment figures some of the four million young people deprived of jobs. If the Erasmus + budget is slightly reinforced, it is in particular through cooperation funds that will allow its internationalization to the detriment of young Europeans. Without ambition for research either, since projects capable of ensuring the technological preeminence of Europe are seeing their envelopes cut. For it is, of course, immigration and enlargement that take the lion's share, flouting the disapproval of European public opinion. Is it not therefore scandalous to note that, despite violations of the rule of law, despite the hostility of Europeans vis-à-vis a possible accession, 131 million euros will be paid to Turkey in 2018? Likewise, the funds intended for the Balkans have been reinforced, confirming Jean-Claude Juncker's desire to see the accession process materialize from 2025. Obviously, this budget betrays the spirit of a European Union deaf to the aspirations of the peoples who compose it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I congratulate the Conciliation Committee on reaching an agreement on the general budget for the financial year 2018. I am pleased that Parliament, the Council and the Commission have been able to agree on the European Union's budget for next year, and I am particularly pleased that Parliament's negotiators have managed to come up with significant changes that will be of great benefit to European citizens. It is important to note that the European Parliament did not support the Council's proposal to reduce funding for jobs and growth policies by EUR 750 million. euros. No less significant is the additional support for a number of important programs, including the Youth Employment Initiative. It has a budget of 350 million. euros. This is a much-needed financial support for the fight against youth unemployment, and I am pleased to hear that Parliament's negotiators are ready to evaluate this program next year and have promised to allocate more resources if necessary. The EU is already investing heavily in providing prospects for those young people who are still looking for work, but statistics show that the employment rate among young people is not rising as we would like. I therefore hope that this increased support will have a positive effect on tackling youth unemployment. I also congratulate the negotiators on the € 110 million won in Horizon 2020 for the Research Support Program. EUR 24 million for the Erasmus + student exchange program. to enable Europe's young people to travel, become more competitive, acquire more skills and succeed in the labor markets of the future. Finally, support for young farmers has also been increased. They will receive an additional 34 million. euros.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The budget is the most important political tool we have in our hands. It highlights the seriousness of the actions with which we intend to address the problems. There is no doubt that immigration and work are the priorities on which Europe is playing a large part of its future, yet the Council does not seem to have accepted this, given that in the trilogue phase it negotiated to lower the commitments - supported from this Parliament - for the Youth Employment Initiative, for the Horizon2020 COSME and Erasmus + programs, as well as those for the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund and for EASO, the Asylum Support Office. It is necessary to make a different reasoning on these issues that goes beyond the logic of the crisis, giving sufficient resources to plan structured interventions. It is also difficult to digest the lack of importance given to the Europe for Citizens program, one of the main tools for bringing citizens closer to the European Union. On the other budget lines, I believe that a satisfactory agreement has been found, but I do not believe that the overall commitment made by the European Union fully corresponds to the expectations of European citizens and their needs.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing.- The common position of the European Parliament and the Council provides for EUR 160.1 billion in commitments and EUR 144.6 billion in payments for the 2018 budget of the European Union.The most important successes for Hungary in terms of cohesion and agricultural resources.Hungarian farmers will continue to receive the EU subsidies due to them in 2018.And Member States will be able to spend € 1.4 billion more on European rural development next year.A record amount of cohesion funding is expected to be disbursed in Hungary in 2018 as well.The money spent on Member States' projects in the European Union budget will increase by € 16.9 billion compared to 2017.Thus, EUR 46.5 billion will be available in 2018 for the settlement of invoices submitted by Member States.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: In written form. - The EU's main task is to respond adequately to the challenges facing our European societies. We are in a complex geopolitical environment and it is our responsibility to take the right measures and decisions to ensure a good future. The European Union has proven to be competitive when it invests in science, infrastructure, education and small and medium-sized enterprises. Therefore, in the new year, the money allocated to Horizon 2020, COSME, EFSI, Erasmus + and many others, which have proven to be successful, will be a good investment that will create huge added value for Europe. The economic growth of a community cannot be possible when there are security problems. Therefore, increasing the budget in the field of foreign policy in the field of migration, the fight against terrorism and organized crime is the right decision that can be taken. People's needs and concerns are many and range from migration management and the protection of our external borders to the realization of the labor market and access to quality education for our children. I believe that the budget for 2018 fully meets the expectations of European citizens and proves that the EU listens to the voice of its citizens.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Recent events have taught us that European finances need to respond much more effectively than in the past to current events that threaten the security and stability of the European Union.I welcome the increase in funding for borders, security and defense against new types of threats.On the other hand, however, we should not resign ourselves to providing pre-accession assistance to candidate countries, and we should, as before, continue our cohesion policy and close the gap between our regions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - I accept the agreement reached two weeks ago on the EU budget for 2018 with moderate satisfaction. The joint text, with total commitments of EUR 160.11 billion and total payments of EUR 144.68 billion, reflects only to some extent our struggle as Parliament for adequate funding for initiatives involving sustainable economic growth, jobs, in particular youth employment; and security. As the multi-annual budget rapporteur for the Committee on Culture and Education, I am paying particular attention to the adequate funding of programs in this area. On the threshold of the beginning of difficult negotiations on the new MFF, I emphasize the importance of next year's EU budget as one of the last budgets covered by the current MFF. The negotiated perspective will be crucial for the continuity and the very rationale of Union action in the field of culture and education. I am constantly calling for more funding for Erasmus +, Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. For Erasmus +, the revision of the current MFF has already given a good signal, as has this year's budgetary procedure, where we managed to win an additional EUR 24 million for this program. However, I believe that the future financial perspective must respond even better to the needs of programs such as Erasmus + and Creative Europe, which enjoy unwavering interest from beneficiaries and are undeniably one of the successes of European integration.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the 2017 state of the Energy Union (2017/2856 (RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Energy Union strategy is one of the main political initiatives of this Commission, as President Juncker said from day one, and we see it not only as a key contribution to addressing our energy and climate-change challenges but also as an opportunity to boost investment, jobs and growth. Vice-President Šefčovič was scheduled to participate in this debate but he has unfortunately been detained by a medical emergency and he has asked me to present his apologies. We all wish him a speedy recovery. I am also informed that former President Busek is also in hospital and I want to send him my best wishes for a quick and full recovery. The immediate reason for this debate is the third State of the Union report, which the Commission adopted last week. The report gives us an opportunity to take stock of what has been achieved at both European Union and national level, and outlines what must still be done in the future to ensure a successful energy transition in which all of society can participate and engage with the European Union. A clear message stands out already: the energy transition is happening and Europe is moving at a fast pace from an energy system based on the 20th century to a low-carbon, more digital and consumer-centric system that is fit for the future. We can see that the share of renewables in the European Union energy mix continues to rise and we are on track to reach our 2020 target of 20%. The even-better news is that the cost of renewables is falling. Already today, the European Union has successfully decoupled its greenhouse gas emissions from economic growth. Between 1990 and 2016 our gross domestic product in Europe grew by 53%, while total greenhouse gas emissions declined by 23% over the same period. The Commission has delivered its part in implementing an Energy Union and the main legislative proposals provided for in the Energy Union strategy are now on the table. The European Parliament has also played its part. Two weeks ago we reached a milestone agreement on the Emissions Trading System, which, thanks notably to European Parliament efforts, will be considerably strengthened for the next trading period. Similarly, we welcome the process of negotiation on the revision of the Effort Sharing Regulation and the integration of land use, land-use change and forestry. Let me also take this opportunity to thank you for your efforts on reaching agreements on security of supply, an intergovernmental decision which came into force last May. This reflects a major political success enhancing the security of energy supply to the European Union. The negotiations on the Clean Energy for All Europeans package are advancing and it is now up to the co-legislators to finalise it. I am pleased to note that progress is being made on all eight of the legislative proposals in the package. The first trilogue has already taken place on the revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, which we hope can be finalised by the end of this year. Despite substantial progress further efforts will clearly be needed to meet the European Union’s energy efficiency targets, notably to prevent further increases in energy consumption as the cost of higher economic growth. The Energy Efficiency Progress Report accompanying the State of the Union closely monitors the progress towards a 20% target by 2020. This is a further reason why we must ensure that the revision of the Energy Efficiency Directive and the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive contains a high level of ambition. Let me underline, in this context, that it is essential to have a strong governance system and to have integrated national energy and climate plans for the post-2020 period.  The two Clean Mobility packages proposed by the Commission aim to help the sector to stay competitive in a socially fair transition towards clean energy …

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Commissioner, you have a very important message, but I think the interpreters would appreciate it if you spoke a little less quickly.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – […] besides the two Clean Mobility packages proposed by the Commission aimed at helping the sector to stay competitive in a socially fair transition towards clean energy and digitalisation in the transport sector because greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise, which we are aiming to address with the Clean Mobility proposals we presented in November. The past year also brought important progress on a range of enabling measures that were put in place by the Commission aimed at overcoming the difficulties experienced by some regions or population groups. Regarding our tailor—made support and assistance to regions in transition, the Commission has always underlined the importance of a socially fair transition to clean energy, and it thanks Parliament for its support. It is an area where European action can add value to the ongoing efforts in Member States. In this context, in December the Commission will launch a platform on core regions in transition to support a valuable economic transformation of core regions in a socially fair way. With regard to the islands initiative, in May the Commission, together with 14 Member States, signed a political declaration in Malta to accelerate the clean energy transition on islands and the first forum took place in Crete in September. Energy poverty affects close to 50 million of our citizens. This is not acceptable and the Clean Energy for All Europeans package includes a range of measures to address this through energy efficiency measures, safeguards against disconnection and better definition and monitoring. I am certain that the co—legislator will have this in mind in the course of our negotiation. Let me turn now to some of the initiatives associated with the third State of the Energy Union report: a new communication on infrastructure, addressing in particular implementation of the 15% interconnection target and the third list of projects of common interest (PCIs). There will be no energy transition if the energy infrastructure is not adapted to the needs of the future energy system. Interconnectors are the physical component of our ongoing energy transition. The communication on infrastructure draws a picture of the progress made in the field of trans—European energy networks. While there is progress, missing infrastructure links identified through the PCI process and the High-Level Groups remain to be completed. Some 30 projects on the first PCI list will have been completed by early next year, 22 for gas and eight for electricity. More needs to be done regarding electricity interconnection projects, storage and smart grids to enable decarbonisation and allow the integration of an increasing amount of renewables. Therefore the third list of projects of common interest identifies 173 PCIs, among which there are 106 electricity projects, 53 gas projects, six oil projects, four smart-grid deployment projects and, for the first time, four CO2 infrastructure projects to address greenhouse gas emission challenges. We expect a further 45 to 50 PCIs to be completed in 2020. The others will take longer. For this reason, it is crucial that enough financing is reserved in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. The Infrastructure Communication proposes a new approach to electricity interconnection targets for 2030. It is accompanied by the evaluation of the TEN—E framework, which shows that positive results are becoming visible. The 10% electricity interconnection target has provided political momentum to advance key cross—border projects. It is an important and useful policy tool that has helped by sending a strong political signal towards the development of the trans—European electricity infrastructure. The Commission had previously proposed a general headline target of 15% for 2020. As the reality of the electricity system is changing, we need to move forward to a better adapted interconnection framework. Already in 2030 we expect that more than half of our electricity will come from renewables and, based on the conclusions of the expert groups, three operational thresholds will be established. Finally, turning towards what still needs to be done, let me stress that the Energy Union has reached a critical juncture in order to make it a full success. The Commission will focus on several aims. Firstly: helping to deliver the final outcome of our proposals for the required legislative framework. Second: delivering the enabling framework with a focus on promoting investments at local level closer to the citizen, intensifying support for the transitioning of coal and carbon intensive regions, and ensuring that the efforts of industry are consistent with those of policymakers. The launch of the Clean Energy Industrial Competitiveness Forum will help us drive the process on. And finally, engaging all parts of society. The Commission will continue to secure the participation of all levels of society – young people in particular – and to create a stronger connection between European, national and local efforts. This is key for the success of the energy transition. On this point, I would also ask this House for your help. As Members of the European Parliament, you can encourage and stimulate your constituents and representatives of civil society in your regions to get involved and support the clean energy transition. This Parliament plays an important role in the success of these initiatives. I count on your continued support as only together will we be able to make use of the full potential of energy transition in terms of job creation, economic growth and attracting investments, and ensure a clean energy future and climate change mitigation for Europe. Thank you, Madam President, and sorry to the interpreters.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.It is quite clear that it would be easier for interpreters if you slowed down your speech a little more.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. In Europe, we have a number of challenges, particularly in the field of energy. So, first of all, we have a lot of dependence on fossil sources: coal, oil, gas. This is problematic for both the climate - CO2 emissions - and it is also problematic for our energy independence, namely that we mostly import these sources. Our trends are growing with imports. Secondly, we still have a lot of barriers to cross-border trade. So these barriers are both regulatory and physical - sometimes there is simply a lack of interconnections. And thirdly, we have relatively high energy prices in Europe. This is because we often have limited competition and we also have very distortive subsidies, both for fossil fuels and for renewables. In response, this is the strategy of the European Energy Union, which is, in fact, now being implemented gradually; as the Commissioner said, the laws are going through the process. We need to understand that our climate goals of reducing CO2 emissions do not conflict with our competitive goals of reducing energy prices. We can achieve one and achieve the other. Namely, we need to reduce our dependence on imports, we need to remove barriers to trade, and we need to phase out these market-distorting subsidies, which are ultimately detrimental both to the investment climate and to our goals and, of course, Europe's overall competitiveness. Thank you for your attention.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his statement on the state of play on the Energy Union. I think it is always interesting to take some time for that, and in my time today I just want to convey one message. I want you to pay a lot of attention to the strong message this Parliament’s Committee on Industry, Research and Energy gave yesterday. We had a very important vote on two very important files. There was a clear majority, supported by nearly all Groups in the House, to raise the level of ambition on the deployment of renewable energy in our Union to a target of 35% by 2030 –that is 80% above the target in the Commission’s proposal.  Our high level of ambition on renewables takes fully into account the recent spectacular cost reduction in solar panels and offshore wind. The International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) has calculated that the EU can double its renewables share from 17% to 35% in 2030 in a cost-neutral way. If we accelerate our energy efficiency policies renewables can even deliver a higher share of remaining energy demands. This was also voted for yesterday with a less broad majority, a smaller majority. We voted for a 40% target on energy efficiency.  I would like to ask the Commission to pick the side of Parliament because up until now the Commission has come up with too weak proposals because of the situation in the Council. Now we have the opportunity, dear Commissioner, to take up full responsibility and ambition and take the side of Parliament.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: At present, very complex discussions are taking place on the various parts of the energy package. It is very difficult to find a common compromise in these discussions, because there is an attempt to push through the toughest ambitions beyond the Commission's proposal and the position of the Member States. Rather, the energy package becomes a tool to support the conclusions of the Paris Agreement. The energy package becomes the climate package. It is also expanding into areas that often do not even have a direct impact on energy. I see the course of further discussions in the trialogue quite problematic. I believe that the debate on further developments in European energy is important and crucial. A sound energy strategy will decide the future competitiveness of the Member States and thus of the EU as a whole. The second thing is that if we overdo the setting of mandatory parameters on efficiency, renewables and so on, we can severely damage the economies of the Member States. At the same time, with an exaggerated effort to reduce CO2 emissions, we will achieve the opposite, because some modernization projects do not have to take place, because their economy will simply not come out and old technologies will continue. I therefore consider it sensible to give maximum support to research and new technologies before going the way of harsh restrictions and exaggerated binding ambitious targets.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, progress has been made on the Energy Union but there is still a lot to do to call the European Union also the Energy Union. When we look at the assessment of 2016 on discrimination of cross-border flows, the results are quite striking. On 31 border directions, less than 51% of the benchmark capacity was offered to the market. Some borders even have zero percent, for instance between Germany and Poland, or no more than 12% between Germany and Denmark.  Many Member States, including my own, still do not take interconnections into account in their capacity assessment nor energy security. But then we see plans for expansion of the Nord Stream pipeline, which will increase our dependence on Russian gas, or we see some countries keeping up with the subsidies for fossil fuel production.  Regional cooperation, looking at the capacity across borders, is crucial to improve the efficiency of our energy systems. When it comes down to details, from infrastructure projects to giving decision-making powers, to regional cooperation, progress still remains a struggle. We have to look at the reasons why countries look at it this way, but we still have to push interconnections and cooperation between Member States.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission's third report on the state of the energy union solemnly states that the policies pursued solve energy problems and lead to growth. However, the data presented in the report itself confirm that the energy deadlocks and energy deficiencies that plague the Union still exist. Many Member States and regions of the Union are still isolated in terms of energy networks. There are serious problems with energy supply, and much remains to be done to advance the goals, which are not yet as ambitious as the European Parliament wants, for renewable energy sources, to strengthen energy isolation and, of course, to address of climate change. The only thing that has been achieved so far is to promote the concentration of energy policy powers in the hands of the Commission, to the detriment of the sovereign rights of the peoples. Of particular concern is the Commission's failure to present a comprehensive plan to combat energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people. Equally serious is the Commission's failure to utilize domestic energy sources to boost energy supply and energy security and reduce the Union's energy dependence. That is why we have repeatedly asked the Commission, even now, to proceed immediately with the submission of a comprehensive plan for the development of domestic energy sources, in particular the deposits in the Eastern Mediterranean.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! On November 8th, exactly three weeks ago, California Governor Jerry Brown was a guest in this house, and he received a great deal of applause from many of our colleagues for his active climate policy in California and for the diplomatic work he is trying to do globally to limit the damage caused by President Trump in international climate policy to some extent. Jerry Brown received the most applause for his self-criticism. When asked whether he was already satisfied with what he was achieving in California or what he was observing globally in terms of active climate protection policy, Jerry Brown said: To be honest: We are not on track - we are not on a good one Path. I actually expect just as much honesty from the European Commission, especially after the climate conference in Bonn. It sounds good, Mr Arias Cañete, when the Commission keeps saying that we are on the very best path to achieving our climate targets. If you measure that against the goals that you have set yourself for the energy transition in Europe, then you may be on the right track. But if you make the Paris Accords your benchmark, then we are not at all on the right track, because the goals that we have set and that we are working towards mean that complete decarbonisation must take place by 2050. If you start from the climate budgets, the CO2 budgets that remain with us, then if you manage the energy sector as you are planning to do now, we would have to completely decarbonise it from 2030 to 2040 in ten years. And the unreasonable demands that we do not dare to make today, where we are even going back in part to what we can do, you simply want to postpone for the next decade. I don't think that's a good idea. I wish for honesty in the balance sheet with regard to the climate targets, and I wish for greater thinking, because I have long been convinced that the European Union needs and has an innovation project.The climate union - similar to the security union, which we have now settled pretty quickly - is the innovation project for the European Union.And we do not defend the future viability of our industry by slowing down on renewables or efficiency.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, so yet again the Commission wants further help from Member States in meeting energy and climate targets, but what damage is being done trying to meet these artificial targets? The continued imposition by the Commission of never-ending objectives for emissions reductions is forcing the investment of vast amounts of money for activity that will have little or no effect on the climate. Global CO2 emissions will probably keep rising unaffected by these measures. These policies are leading to a massive exit of industry and investment from EU countries to jurisdictions with lower environmental standards and could ultimately increase emissions of CO2.  So we are not so much cutting emissions in the EU as exporting them. Indeed, if you include emissions related to goods imported into the EU, emissions in the EU have actually gone up. Heavy industry, including the cement, steel, aluminium and chemical sectors, is moving factories and jobs out of the EU, leading to a leakage of CO2 emissions without environmental benefits.  This is a particular concern in Germany, which has the largest industrial base in Europe. In Poland electricity prices may double if coal—fired power stations close down. Cement producers have warned that about 80% of production will be offshored. In Britain, overdependence on expensive and intermittent renewables has forced up energy prices. Professor Dieter Helm from Oxford University recently carried out a study for the British Government and said that green taxes will cost the average household almost GBP 150 from next year.  We need to stop this right now and have a balanced energy approach, using methods which are competitive and work with industry, not against it.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – I just want to raise one point with Mr Bullock. If you include the imports, then you should perhaps also include the exports from the European Union. If you mean that we are increasing carbon dioxide more than we believe because of the imports, then you should also count the exports. Can you give the mathematics for that so you give relevance to your contribution?

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for that. I am quite happy to look at all options in this, but what is clear is that things which were made in the EU are now being made abroad and so the CO2 emission involved in this is now elsewhere, so we have exported that emission. I am happy to look at everything and I think the experts will be looking at this, but it is a flawed policy and it will be exposed as a flawed policy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! The third report on the implementation status of the Energy Union makes it clear that an energy transition is not possible without adapting the infrastructure to the requirements of a modern energy system. The focus is on the expansion of transmission networks and pipelines, the decentralization of the line systems and the networking of energy, telecommunications and transport infrastructure. That costs money. 200 billion euros are earmarked for expanding the transmission networks and gas pipelines alone. The EU is supporting this within the framework of the TEN-E strategy with an extended list of BCIs, the EFSI, the “Connecting Europe” facility and the EIB. And in order to make the best possible use of the line infrastructure, connections are needed - interconnectivity - and here I welcome the Commission's proposal to increase the interconnectivity target from 10% to 15% by 2030. That will certainly guarantee security of supply. Another building block for a successful energy transition and the achievement of climate targets is the “Clean Energy” package. We passed two directives on this yesterday in the Industry Committee, namely the RED II and EED votes, which came out very narrowly, 33 to 32 votes, and I would like to say here that goals should be set that are realistic and feasible and where you don't have to fear from the outset that you will get infringement proceedings. I suppose that will be the case with EED. We have overshot what is feasible here with the 40% energy efficiency target and binding goals in the member states.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President!The Commission has drafted a regulation on the internal market in electricity in the name of the Energy Union.The parliaments of eight countries have lodged an objection because the regulation violates the principle of subsidiarity.According to the Hungarian Parliament, decisions on capacity mechanisms will be taken to the EU level, the definition of the energy mix will be indirectly removed from the Member States, and the responsibilities of the Member States' system operators will be reduced.Regional operational centers will be set up while Member States will be responsible for security of supply.They unnecessarily limit the power of Member States to set prices, while this gives them the means to protect consumer rights and reduce energy poverty.European energy cooperation must be designed in such a way that it does not infringe the sovereignty of the Member States enshrined in the Treaties.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, the whole idea with the Energy Union is to strengthen the independence and security of supply for the European Union at the same time as we can develop a policy that is consistent with the Paris Agreement and our climate policies. This underlines the need for well-functioning energy markets, allowing for the emergence of new energy sources, renewable energies and competitive prices. That is why I think it is so important to have a focus on the market structures, allowing for cross-border trade, but also allowing for the new energy sources to develop under business competitiveness structures.  I say this because there is a risk that we are planning more than we are developing. When we are discussing the winter package we clearly see the risks. We have seen in history that planned economies are never successful regarding the environment or efficient energy production. That is why it is important that the legislation we are now entering will allow for better market solutions of different kinds. I very much welcome in this perspective the Commission’s proposal on amending the Gas Directive. The pipelines coming from here or from there must all be under EU law. That is a requirement and a pre-condition for a competitive European energy market but also for fair competition.  Nord Stream is a threat to the Energy Union but also to competition in the Energy Union. Nord Stream must fulfil all the requirements for competition in the European Union. That is why it is very good that the Commission has made this proposal.

name: Dan NICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Cañete, this debate is taking place at an opportune time, because, as you well know, the ITRE Commission voted yesterday on the reports on energy efficiency and renewables and the result is ambitious, which shows a clear commitment, such as and the direction in which investments are needed. European Union target of 35% for renewables, 40% for energy efficiency, a very strong Article 7, clear provisions on combating energy poverty, clear provisions and a 3% target for the renovation of all public buildings, a target of 12% for renewables in transport . We are also prepared to support the Commission's efforts to amend the Gas Directive, as we must ensure the integrity of European Union law, respect for the principle of solidarity, and ensure energy security and diversification of energy sources. Given that around 50 million people in the European Union are affected by energy poverty, we look forward to the European Energy Poverty Observatory portal being operational and, in particular, accessible in all Union languages. I welcome the Commission's initiative to provide assistance to the transition regions on coal dependence and intensive industries, and I would like to know whether this program is being extended to other regions, under what conditions and on what timetable. Also, what is the status of a possible legislative proposal on the prevention of cyber incidents in the energy sector? And last but not least, Commissioner, I welcome the publication of the list of projects of common interest, but I point out that it is very important that projects are closely monitored so that projects like BRUA reach Austria and do not stop at the border with Hungary. .

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, those of us who are involved in the day—to—day parliamentary work on the Union’s climate and energy strategy have a clear sight of the extent of the ambition and the complexity of the task in drawing together so many different pieces of legislation into a coherent plan. That is what energy union means. It is a simple concept, but it has a hugely complex challenge in its delivery. We are on track to achieve the 20% renewable energy target in 2020. Okay, that is good, but we also have a situation where some Member States have vastly over-achieved their renewable energy targets but, if they are generating the rest of their power, including their baseload, from dirty coal, do they deserve a bouquet or a brickbat? I am very happy that GDP has started to rise without a parallel rise in emissions, a clear rebuttal to those who say that Europe is only achieving reductions because of economic downturn.  As a rapporteur for ETS Phase 4 and an active participant in many of the other files, I am only too aware that more needs to be done. I welcome the Commission’s third report on the state of the Union, but would ask them to do more. Europe must fight hard for a pre—eminent position in innovation, in battery technology, smart grids, interconnectors and so much more. So much of our ambition will only be delivered if we ensure that funding is available to bridge gaps in the commercialisation of new technology across energy generation, distribution and efficiency.  I agree with the Commissioner that a fair and socially just system is necessary, but I firmly believe that dealing with energy poverty should be part of a much broader Union strategy for jobs and growth. It is very important that we do not hold up or compromise high—level strategic planning and decision—making on the Energy Union through differences of opinion on social policy.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: - Madam President! When all the world leaders met in Paris almost two years ago, they not only signed an agreement, they also wrote history. With Europe at the forefront, they decided to take responsibility for our future generations, namely by taking climate issues seriously and strengthening cooperation for the benefit of the green transition. However, it requires us to implement the European Energy Union, which makes us less dependent on Putin's gas and oil from the Sheikhs in the Middle East, and at the same time strengthens the fight against climate change. But we see at the moment that there can be a long way from promises to action. When we look at how Europe's governments are acting at the moment, yes, there is a real risk that Paris was full of empty promises. And it must not happen! Trump is pulling the Americans out of the Paris Agreement, and therefore Europe must take on an even greater responsibility to lead the way in the green transition. It requires ambitious goals for renewable energy and energy efficiency. It requires a turbo on investments in more energy-efficient buildings and cleaner transportation. It also requires a genuine internal market for energy, which will provide savings for the climate and for Europeans. It requires a European energy union, where we deliver green results to the citizens and which benefit the climate. In the European Parliament, therefore, we must continue to hold the green flag high. It is needed, perhaps more now than ever before, even though it may be upwind. Thank you to the Commissioner for a good job in this matter. There are major tasks ahead now, not least for us in the European Parliament, to continue to push for the green transition.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, the report on the state of the Energy Union comes just as a new directive on renewable energy is being processed. We have said this before and we also do it now: it is necessary to set binding national targets if we want the countries furthest behind not to be left behind. Forcing states to produce a minimum of renewable energy has been essential for the current Directive to work. If we are not ambitious, we will not achieve what is established in the Paris Agreement. We are also concerned that the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy endorses targets for renewables in transport, which in practice means an increase in the use of biofuels. We must be cautious: with such generalist objectives we will contribute to deforestation and higher food prices, putting the objectives of sustainable development at global level at risk. Again we see how green capitalism wants to link the expansion of renewables to its particular interests, the liberation of the energy market; and this, of course, is not the way. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" question.- I am sorry, Mrs López Bermejo, that you make a statement saying that it is green capitalism that led me, as rapporteur for the Renewable Energy Directive, to set a goal of decarbonising transport.By the way, it must be said that, in any case, biofuels have to meet sustainability criteria.I have certainly not been influenced by anyone.The only influence I have, Mrs. López, is the idea that transport is less polluted in our cities and towns, and you live in a city too polluted to maintain approaches that, not even in relation to development,maintains FAO.I will send you the FAO document on the subject of food and on the subject of reforestation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: "blue card" response.- Mr Blanco, I thank you for his passion in the debate.I do not expect of you, of course, less.But, come on, I want to tell you that you obviously had to mishear my speech.I have not said anything about how you have prepared the report.What I have said - and I repeat it - is that the large energy companies in Spain and in Europe are taking advantage of the use and abuse of certain conditions to start up renewables only for their interests.There is no talk of energy poverty;criteria are established that are truly alarming;it is facilitated that none of the objectives are met.It has been shown in all studies: that there are no national binding targets is a failure.I don't know if they will influence you;What is clear is that they will not influence us.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I do not doubt the commitment of the European Commission to gradually abandon coal. Furthermore, I am glad that at COP.23 an alliance of countries launched an initiative to close their coal plants. But, in Spain, as you well know, the government is going in the opposite direction. While some companies commit to the Paris Agreement and want to close their plants, the Minister of Energy is preparing a law to prevent it. But in Spain there is an installed electrical overcapacity. The closure is already regulated with guarantee of supply. The European Commission says that state aid cannot be granted to companies and thus comply with European environmental standards, but the Spanish government continues to look to the 19th century. Commissioner, do you consider that avoiding the closure of coal plants is consistent with the Paris Agreement and the clean energy package? Do you consider it acceptable to give more money to these plants? Do you consider that this proposal respects the current European energy market? I am counting on you and the European Commission to write a future without coal, that is, in favor of health and the climate.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - The price for the Energy Union is high, but only for the citizen. He pays for it. On the one hand, its political influence is disappearing now that the choice of energy sources is transferred to the European Union, which is, incidentally, contrary to Article 194 of the Treaty. On the other hand, he also pays a higher price for energy than he would in a truly free energy market. The Commission reports successes such as growth and investment, but the citizen simply pays for it with his tax money. Where the Commission speaks of “correct price signals in the energy market”, Dutch citizens see what government interference with energy means in practice. In the Netherlands, the tax on energy goes from EUR 800 to EUR 1000 per year per household. Because without a subsidy, the windmills will not run. Where, Madam President, is that so-called cheap or cheaper sustainable energy? It is therefore priceless in practice. Mr President, the energy union is not about sensible choices, about independence or prosperity, but about centralizing power.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - I am pleased to note that the report does not mention the fight against global warming - apparently the creators know it was a scam - it only talks about fighting climate change. But we will not forget how much money has been spent on fighting global warming. Fortunately, despite the Greens, it has not been possible to stop carbon dioxide emissions. There is more and more carbon dioxide, which makes the Earth green. Earth raises the green flag because there is more carbon dioxide. I am an envoy from Silesia, Zagłębie, which stands on coal. This carbon was created because there used to be a lot of carbon dioxide there, and plants absorbed it and turned it into carbon. And therefore, if that coal returns to the atmosphere, nothing terrible will happen. On the other hand, it is absolutely socially unfair that Poland, and more specifically Silesia and Zagłębie, bear the costs of this now crazy fight against climate change, as my predecessor said. And they have to pay monstrous prices for very expensive, allegedly renewable energy.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Madam President! Together with the Commission, we are delighted with the positive results achieved by the 2020 targets, and we also very much agree with the Commission's proposals for the future targets for 2030. It can be more ambitious with renewables, as we had in committee, and when it comes to savings, it can be more ambitious the Commission is an ambitious 30% proposal, but it can be achieved. The left side here in the House would like 40%, but that - and this is what all impact assessments say - would destroy the ETS system, and we have to consider whether we might not hinder the structural change towards renewable energies with a 40% saving obligation . Because this saving obligation also applies to renewables. Let's consider the topic of electric vehicles: Wind and sun are not yet as efficient as diesel or gasoline technology. That means that we will need more electricity, more electricity from renewable energies in front of the socket. That is why we cannot now say that we have to save 40% energy. In this way we are hindering the structural change towards renewable energies. It is very dangerous what the European Parliament has now proposed here in committee by a very small majority. Anyone who does not recognize these connections, who is now slowing down the development of renewables, is not concerned with efficiency - and I say that specifically to the left - it's about poker, it's about poker with the council and with the others. And when parliament is playing poker, it is no better than an NGO, which sometimes intervenes in the political opinion-forming process with excessive environmental ideas. We as the EPP definitely do not go along with it. We want to work out a realistic perspective, and we would like to urgently warn against hindering structural change and expansion goals with excessive cost savings. That is why we as the EPP are following the Commission's proposals as far as possible. I but also announce that we are of course available for compromises.But the compromise of 40% is not 40, but below.Many Thanks.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: - Madam President, yesterday the European Parliament showed its clear ambition in the field of the energy package, namely by voting on targets of 40% for energy efficiency and 35% for renewable energy sources. But my question is, apart from setting high goals in these areas, are we not lagging behind in another extremely important area, namely the area of ​​interconnectedness. We know that we have a 10% target, which a number of important countries for the European Union, such as the United Kingdom, Poland and Spain, will not even be able to meet, and we are now talking about a new 15% target. The question is simple - can there be a revolution or even an evolution without better interconnectedness? And after hearing the statement "America first" or energy efficiency first, or renewables first, isn't it time to hear the statement "better interconnection and smart grids first"?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! As we all know, the Energy Union has different goals, two main different goals that are not at all easily reconciled. On the one hand, these are climate goals, variously defined, but the other great goal, which we must not forget, is the goal of ensuring security of supply, ensuring energy, not only clean energy, but energy in general. My colleague, Mr Tošenovský, spoke about how big the problem is, how hot the discussions are in the European Parliament right now. But it also seems to me that the Commission is not consistently trying to balance these two goals and is sending out very contradictory signals. Namely, as far as gas is concerned, it has now put forward the initiative to extend the rules of the Third Energy Package also to gas pipelines from third countries in order to regulate this matter. On the other hand, when it comes to electricity, it seems to me that the Commission is paying too little attention to energy security, giving priority to ...

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Madam President! It's nice to hear Finnish spoken in this House again from the Bureau. What we are now discussing is perhaps the most ambitious legislative package we have to deal with this term. Properly managed, it will lead to us creating a more secure energy supply within the European Union, that we manage significantly more of the capital used to procure energy within the Union today, that we create new companies, that we get a growing renewable energy sector that also ensure that we create jobs throughout the European Union. At the same time, there are a number of warning points. We see how, to some extent, Parliament is not really ready to make broad compromises. I would like to warn my colleagues to use Parliament as a pawn in creating the biggest headlines in the spirit of ambition. I myself come from Sweden, which is climate ambitious. I come from a party that was one of the first in the world to talk about environmental policy in Parliament. At the same time: If there is anything that makes me nervous, it is political instability and when we use Parliament as a pawn. We can see how we have succeeded yesterday in the industry committee in raising the ambition for the renewable quite sharply. We also saw the total chaos that came out of the Environment Committee's vote. There we must now ensure that we take clear responsibility and ensure that we get the same broad majority before the plenary vote on the remaining parts of the Renewables Directive as we had in the Committee on Industry. Only then will we gain success in the trilogists and only then will we have a functionally successful energy union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, Mr Cañete, you are going to allow me to tell you that you are like Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, because in the Communication from the Commission on the state of the Energy Union it shows us two faces. On the one hand, it tells us that the European Union is the global engine of the transition to clean energy and that ambition is needed to fight climate change. Right, doctor: when it's true, I'll buy it for you. But on the other hand - or, rather, when you show us your true face through the list of projects of common interest - you are about to grant millions of euros to fifty-three gas mega-infrastructures, including the MidCat or the Southern Gas Corridor. And I wonder: why waste money? Every euro spent on projects that destroy the environment instead of boosting renewable energy is one euro that you throw away. If this is your plan, Mr. Cañete, for the sake of the environment you should not be in the European Commission but in the novel by Robert Louis Stevenson.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: - Mr President! In Paris two years ago, we promised each other and the world to do what is necessary to slow down climate change. We promised to hand over a habitable planet to our children and grandchildren. It is now that we must deliver on this promise. That is why I am concerned about the situation in the energy union. The proposals are thinned out. The ambition is insufficient. The green transition is postponed to the future. The latest example is yesterday's vote in the Committee on Industry, which unfortunately decided that the targets for renewable energy should not be binding on the member states. If we are to be able to actually deliver on the goals from Paris, then the goals must be binding so that we ensure that they are actually achieved. No one should be able to evade our common responsibility. This is not how it can continue. We Greens propose binding targets for member states of 35 percent renewable energy for the EU by 2030. This creates the pressure for green transition and innovation that is required. Then we go all the way to Paris.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I must say it is a pleasure to be here this evening in the company of so many MEPs who are working so hard to make the Energy Union a reality, as indeed are Commissioners Cañete and Šefčovič and others. I am going to concentrate on renewable energy because I am honoured to be the rapporteur for the Renewable Energy Directive for my Group – the European People’s Party (EPP) – and I must say, in this regard, that Europe is brimming with potential. I believe that the position the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) took on this directive yesterday can give the industry a needed boost and help us to fulfil President Juncker’s ambition for the EU to be the world leader in renewable energy.  It is now increasingly clear that the final energy targets for 2030 which we agree upon will see the ambition levels raised from those of the October 2014 Council conclusions. On renewables there is a lot of debate to be held in the coming months, especially as we move to the trilogues. For me, it is important that we give the right signal to drive investments, but we must also consider the impact on energy prices that large increases in support for renewables will bring. In many instances, something absent from Brussels’ discussions of renewable energy is the additional costs that a non-pragmatic approach can bring in terms of energy prices. Therefore, maintaining EU competitiveness must go hand-in-hand with the transition to renewables. We must consider those who are seeking to heat their homes, and the energy-intensive factories that employ thousands upon thousands of Europeans. If energy costs are made too high because of policy supports, and the blame is put on renewables, we will get nowhere. That is why I am pleased that we accepted a 35% ambition level in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy yesterday. It is attainable and it was a bottom-line for the rapporteur, Mr Blanco López. We will be looking at issues like competitive systems of tendering, incentivising renewable self-consumption and developing renewable energy communities, as well as simplifying and shortening the approval processes for renewable energy projects. We are on our way!

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the presentation of the third report on the state of the Energy Union takes place, as you know, in a week when the European Parliament showed, through its votes in the ITRE Committee, a strong commitment to a much more ambitious agenda. . Europe's transition to low-carbon speed is no longer an aspiration and a necessity to become increasingly a reality that is viable, generating growth, jobs and a better quality of life for Europeans. In particular, I would like to highlight the confluence between energy networks and digital networks and between the energy transition and the digital revolution. Interconnections are the key to the development of a single, fluid and competitive energy market. The list of projects of common interest reflects this perspective but must move quickly to the field. No Member State, Commissioner, can commit to ambitious transition goals without the fluidity of the market that interconnections provide. On the other hand, the concept of digital energy has to be further developed and applied. It calls for other types of networks, in particular 5G networks and knowledge networks. It is with them that we can make the single energy market a reference market on a global scale.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, yesterday the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy voted for renewable targets for the year 2030. It was very interesting to see that those Members in this House who usually cannot have enough of Europe were becoming very nationalistic. They wanted national targets instead of Europe-wide targets.  In the energy sector, we now have targets for just about everything. We have emission targets, efficiency targets, renewable targets, interconnector targets and so on. Let me remind you that socialist economies did not suffer from too few targets, they collapsed because there were too many targets. Here, we are missing people who are in favour of liberalisation and safe responsibility for competitiveness. Where are they? We seem to be obsessed with targets. I think we should stop this. Rather than making Brexit difficult, the EU should offer a new deal for Britain. This would enable them not only to stay in the Energy Union, and of course in the common market, but it would also enable them to stay in the European Union.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Thank you for the report on the state of the Energy Union. However, you probably understand that I am not very happy with the result. At present, we have almost completed the reform of the ETS and the ESR. A large part of the winter package has even been voted on in the committee, which at first glance may seem like good status. However, what is sad about it are the mistakes and unfinished work left by the Commission on the documents, which will only become apparent later. The whole concept is currently on clay feet and is not satisfactorily linked to previous energy packages. On several occasions, my political group has emphasized, for example, the non-compliance of the ETS with the Energy Efficiency Directive, where there is a clear overlap, ie the impact of energy efficiency on the ETS. It has not yet been clearly established which decarbonisation tool is actually the main one for the Union. That is why we are having a kind of disparate potato pancake here, where one tool is disrupting the other, which is ostentatiously ignored in the Commission's negotiations. Given that I really appreciate you, Commissioner, I hope that you will do something about the whole situation while there is time, because these documents will not remain open forever.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! The Commission's winter packages contain many good points. Parliament is well on its way, but the Council seems to be plagued by both confusion and unwillingness to produce results. It was the Heads of State and Government who decided that they wanted an energy union, which I think makes a lot, a lot of sense. Had it been up to the energy ministers to create this energy union, nothing would have happened. When the ministers sit in Paris, and when they sit in Bonn, they say 'yes, yes, yes', and when they now sit and have to negotiate with Parliament to get a good deal, it is 'no, no, no' . I would like to say that I find it shameful that we are not moving forward at this stage with the Council. In addition, when you read the minutes from the council meetings, it turns out to be a bit uphill the whole thing. In fact, I believe that Europe has a golden opportunity in these years to create an energy union where we become less dependent on energy from outside - gas from Putin, oil from the Middle East - and at the same time that we create healthier and better housing, that we do cost-effective renovations, that energy efficiency is put on the agenda. It also means that we can create a lot of jobs in Europe. These are jobs where people in blue boiler suits can get a job, jobs that cannot be outsourced anywhere else in this world. At the same time, through innovation and new solutions, we are making Europe more competitive in the long run, and ultimately our energy-intensive companies will not have to pay such a high price for their ETS quotas if we deliver, e.g. in the residential area. I am disappointed at the moment with the Council that it is no longer willing to produce any results, and I would like to ask the Commissioner if he does not share the view.

name: Martina WERNER
text: - Mister President! Almost exactly a year ago today, the European Commission presented the “Clean Energy for All Europeans” legislative package. And since then the Energy Committee has been working intensively on the eight legislative proposals of the Commission. Yesterday in the committee we spoke out in favor of ambitious and binding goals, both for promoting renewables and for strengthening energy efficiency. We are demanding a binding 40% efficiency target at European level with binding national targets. Consumers in particular benefit from greater promotion of energy efficiency, as this means that electricity bills can finally be reduced. From an industrial policy perspective, too, it is important to have a binding, ambitious and regulatory framework, because only then can investments be made and innovation potential tapped. I think that was an important stage victory and I appeal to all colleagues to support the result of the vote in the plenary vote in January as well.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! One of the priorities of the Energy Union is to ensure energy security for all Member States. Nevertheless, we continue to observe measures in the opposite direction, such as attempts to exclude the Nord Stream 2 project from the scope of the Third Energy Package. This is contrary to the principles of energy solidarity and is detrimental to the entire European Union. Speaking of security, we should guarantee our customers a continuous supply of inexpensive energy. We can achieve this through the stable use of our own energy sources, and in Poland - coal. In this context, the initiative of the European Commission for coal regions, including Silesia, should be appreciated. It is a bad solution to propose a strict limit of 550 g of carbon dioxide per kilowatt hour in the power market regulations. It excludes coal-fired power plants from the capacity markets, undermining our energy security and national competences to shape the energy mix.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: - Mister President! I was actually very astonished yesterday that a very narrow majority - with one vote - in the Industry and Energy Committee approved a reduction in total energy by 40% by 2030. If we think about that, if we reduce 40%, then for a single-family house, which is heated to an average of 20 degrees in Europe, that simply means that we have to lower the temperature to 12 degrees. I ask myself: who in our population wants that? Or that if we have a speed limit of 130 km / h today, we will have to reduce the average speed on motorways to 70 kilometers per hour. We have the problem that, of course, with a 40% saving in total energy consumption, renewable energy can no longer be expanded as it has been up to now, but that the expansion programs have to be massively reduced. And we can say goodbye to e-mobility entirely, because then the whole thing is simply not enforceable. I believe that this 40% reduction in total energy consumption is simply irresponsible, and the population does not support it either. I understand that it is a negotiating position, but we have to be clear that these goals are unrealistic.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, the Energy Union is crucial for the competitiveness of the economy, for our environmental goals, for the transition to a decarbonised economy. But there will not be a true Energy Union if we do not guarantee the necessary interconnections that end with energy islands, such as the Iberian Peninsula. But, Commissioner, you will recall that I have congratulated you on the agreements reached in Paris, where you played an important role. I'm going to ask you to join us so that that music that sounded good in Paris is translated into reality, making European legislation on renewable energy and energy efficiency that is in accordance with those Paris commitments. Yesterday we took an important step with a broad agreement in the Industry Committee to have more ambitions, to bring the European Parliament and Europe in line with those commitments: more renewable energy, more penetration of renewables in transport, heating, cooling, more empowerment of the citizen, better regulating the right to self-consumption, and avoiding retroactive situations like some that we had known. Commissioner, align yourself with what the European Parliament agreed yesterday, and together we will all come into line with what was agreed in Paris.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mister President! Have you ever asked children where electricity comes from? As a father, I know that the answer is usually: from the socket. 2018 will be an energetic year for Europe: security of supply and market, energy efficiency and fewer emissions, innovation and competitiveness. The Energy Union has ambitious goals. But it cannot stay that way, because without action the political light goes out quickly. The Energy Union cannot be a black box of fewer winners. No, good energy needs full strength. Good energy needs a real turning point. Good energy must be sustainable, be generated locally and guarantee regional added value. Europe's best energy is a citizen's energy, generated in comprehensive, good networks and not chased through the country in disastrous monster trails. We need clean, cooperative-owned power plants, active medium-sized businesses and involved farmers instead of smoke in the coal in the clutches of corporations. In this Energy Union too, we would do well to ask where the electricity comes from and to be clear: there is more than just the can.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the title of this debate is 'The state of the Energy Union in 2017'. First, it must be recognized that the Commission - and very specifically you - has done extraordinary work so that this energy union continues to crystallize throughout this term. It is impressive, for example, what the winter package that we are dealing with now entails in this sense and in others. I wanted to focus on the issue of interconnections, because "union" and "connection" - and in this case "interconnection" - are absolutely two sides of the same coin.
