One cannot speak of union without interconnection, and there we have a notable deficit, a deficit that, according to the group of experts that has developed the report on interconnections and the Commission's own Communication, makes it clear that a market interconnected interior will give better results in terms of prices; which is absolutely essential for the security of supply - interconnections, in this sense, allow for mutual support between countries - and, on the other hand, allows the integration of renewables, which is so closely linked to the report that we approved yesterday . For projects of common interest, it is necessary to have this series of criteria when supporting it, especially where there are countries that have great problems in this regard.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: - I think that the transition to a low-carbon society is becoming more and more a reality in the EU. Yesterday, the ITRE Committee voted in favor of a very ambitious Energy Efficiency Directive and a Renewables Directive, which are crucial for the Energy Union. I consider it crucial that we also sanctify the committee's ambitious position in the vote in plenary, with a more convincing result, so that we have a bigger and stronger position for negotiating with the Council. Without a significant increase in pressure for ambition, we would not be able to fulfill Commissioner Šefčovič's words that in 2019, the Energy Union will no longer be just a political vision, but a reality. I would like to remind you that the strengthening of powers and the financial strengthening of ACER must also play a role in this regard. Finally, I would like to commend the Commission for taking a much more active approach to tackling energy poverty at both EU and Member State level. For us as Social Democrats, this is one of the key goals of the Energy Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the final establishment of a fully functioning energy union will ensure that all Member States and their citizens have a stable energy supply and a competitive market for products and services in the energy sector.Such a large-scale project for the future requires not only joint political efforts, but also large investments in energy, transport and telecommunications infrastructure.The necessary infrastructure includes the LNG terminal on the Croatian island of Krk, the construction of which I support and I hope that with the help of money from European funds it will be realized as soon as possible.We must primarily view the Energy Union as a common market for energy that we have an obligation to make accessible to all citizens and economic operators, and not as a strictly regulated community whose global competitiveness will be limited by an excessive regulatory burden.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, I believe that the European Energy Union is the cornerstone for the European Union to be able to meet its energy challenges and needs. Indeed, the European Union cannot respond without realizing that the Energy Union is non-existent and that there can be no Energy Union without supporting and funding energy projects that meet the key objectives of creating energy conditions. self-sufficiency in the European Union, easy supply and the creation of conditions for the European Union itself to meet its energy needs. There are areas in the European Union that can really support this grandiose goal. One of these areas is the Eastern Mediterranean, where the Republic of Cyprus, a Member State of the European Union, can offer both the geographical area and the ideal place to create a gas liquefaction terminal, but at the same time to exploit the deposits. for the benefit of the European Union. With such energy infrastructure financing policies in these countries, which have the potential, I believe that the European Energy Union will be put into practice in the interest of all European citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Energy Union is the flagship project of the Juncker Commission and perhaps of the entire legislature, yet the risk that it will not be fully fulfilled is very high. Encouraging data emerges from the third annual report on the subject: the European Union is transforming itself into a low-carbon society, with record levels of renewable energy, at rapidly decreasing costs, but the European energy infrastructure is not developing in same direction and with the same speed to support this energy transition. The European Union is called upon to modernize an obsolete energy infrastructure, to fully integrate its energy markets and to ensure coordination of national energy prices. The Energy Union has the dual objective of ensuring energy security and fighting climate change, while offering secure and sustainable energy at affordable prices and new jobs in the green economy. Any individualistic behavior of the Member States takes us away from these aims and constitutes a severe blow to the ambitions of the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Cañete, the famous Energy Union has failed to meet modern challenges. In particular, it has failed to cure the famous energy poverty that afflicts 50 million of our fellow human beings in the European Union. Especially in Greece, more than 100,000 households do not have access to electricity due to debts to PPC. The Greek people, impoverished by the Troika and the memoranda, are thawing from the cold, as the lenders imposed an increase in the excise tax on oil and its price soared. So Greece and the Greek people thaw, in order to warm themselves, they burn whatever they find, with the result that the smog phenomenon reappears. In addition, Greek farmers, hit by the government's tax evasion policy, are protesting because the expensive agricultural oil, due to the increased excise tax imposed by the Troika, is driving production costs soaring. Is it possible, Mr Cañete, for this situation to continue in Greece? It's not going anymore.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: - Ensuring a reliable energy supply for all its citizens must be a priority for the EU in the Energy Union.Reliability and availability of energy must be a matter of course.Many speakers highlighted the EU's role as a leader in the transition to renewable energy and emphasized the importance of combating climate change.However, I would like to ask the Commission how it will respond to the US government's declared intention to withdraw from the Paris Agreement on Climate Change.It is certainly commendable that the EU is committed to reducing emissions, setting other, perhaps even unrealistic, targets, but if the US does not join as the biggest polluter, I strongly doubt the effectiveness of our efforts.We only have one planet, and Mr. Trump should be aware of that.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, among all the documents presented in the framework of this third report on the state of the Energy Union, I found one interesting, and that is the analysis of prosumers after 2020. I can say that I agree with some of the points made in the conclusions and I would like to emphasize here again that the regulatory framework that will allow citizens to be energy producers (an obscure word) of the market is very important and that it is very important to adopt a common definition. for this at European level. I would also say that it is very important to provide citizens with sustainable ways of financing because after 2020, the study shows that photovoltaic panels on roofs will be endangered because incentives will be abolished. And thirdly, we lack a skilled workforce to install these systems and I urge you to consider this as one of the important points of the Energy Union in the future.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, according to a report from the Commission, Europe is moving from an energy system based on fossil fuels to one based on carbon missions, which is digitized and which puts the consumer at the center. It's a nice mission statement, but it's not really that straightforward, because Europe continues to support oil, coal and gas. The EIB operations that support them, coupled with generous grants from some states, are in total contradiction with the EU's commitments on clean energy. There is a lack of strong, high binding targets and measures that require a real transition, while there is still a lot of focus, for example, on gas. Just think of the TAP, of this pharaonic, harmful work, and of how the militarization of the territory was achieved in order to impose it on the citizens. How can you think of making change if you cling to a fossil source with your fingernails? A question to the Commissioner: why is TAP not included in the modification of the gas directive, why does it not have to respect the principle of transparency, the internal market rules and the ownership unbundling principle?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, while welcoming the third report, I would like to emphasise the fact that, while much has been achieved, we have to continue pushing forward in order to attain the goal of energy union, that of delivering secure, affordable and climate-friendly energy to all EU citizens and businesses. As the right way forward, the energy transition should be socially fair, would pave the way towards innovation and would rely on a future—proof infrastructure with enhanced security of supply. I am particularly glad to see that tailor—made support and assistance was provided to regions facing economic and social challenges, which have been, or remain, reliant on coal and carbon-intensive industries. Indeed, the actions put in place in 2017 ensure that the EU is on the right track to implement the Energy Union project and boost jobs, growth and investment. Now, as the so-called year of engagement approaches, the time has come to involve society – citizens, cities, companies, academia and other stakeholders.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, the energy union is of strategic importance for the survival and competitiveness of the European Union, and we have often criticized the Commission. This time, however, I commend the steps taken, in particular, by Commissioner Cañete. There are serious problems. One of them concerns the isolation of island Member States and the need to disperse sources of clean energy supply. In the Eastern Mediterranean, however, Cyprus is currently making plans that serve the European Union and the wider region, together with Member States of the European Union but also with countries outside the European Union, such as Egypt and Israel. Imagine what it would be like to destabilize the 100 million Egypt. Commissioner, follow the same line and let us know about the developments with the Quartet in Cyprus next week.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner!I would like to underline one thing from your proposal that is particularly important to me: The energy transition should be designed to be socially fair.Why is that important?I come from the Rhenish lignite mining district.There 9,000 people live directly from the lignite.They live there with their families.There are suppliers there, all of whom consume.So we're talking about a five-digit number of jobs that depend directly on this energy source, lignite.All of these people need our support, they need the support of the European Union.We need investments in new jobs, in new technologies, in education so that these people can continue to live there in the region.I am for ambitious and ambitious goals, but in such a way that it can be planned and is fair for these people.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: - Mr President, I will try to keep my time. So, apart from the fact that we all certainly want CO2 emissions to be reduced in the air, and we all want a better environment, I have two issues that I consider to be crucial for the subject, which is primarily about renewables. My colleague has already mentioned before me how forest forests in Europe will disappear, because we have decided to finance a relatively large purchase of wood and to create our own renewable or alternative sources, and something very similar applies to land where, instead of cereals, which we can put into the food or breeding industry, we grow crops for biomass that destroy our soil. Quite a fundamental thing for us - and I am a Member from Slovakia - and therefore for Central and Eastern Europe is Nord Stream 2. I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner what condition Nord Stream 2 is in and whether the Commissioner has considered all the reservations that our countries have repeatedly addressed this project in relation to this project, because this project will create differences between Western, Central and Eastern Europe. Thank you very much.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members for their constructive contributions. First of all, I would like to make a general remark. Mr Bendtsen made some comments on a general view about the lack of ambition that we see in the Council when we approach all these energy topics. I welcome the fact that, on the other side, Parliament is showing ambition. It would be impossible to have a reasonable outcome in the trilogues if Parliament had not shown the ambition it is showing now. The role of Commissioner is to be an honest broker, but without an ambitious position on the Parliament side, it would be very difficult to broker any substantive agreement. Sometimes people make speeches about raising the level of ambition and about more targets, but when it comes to taking decisions on the tools, on the Renewable Energy Directive or the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, then things are quite different in the Council. So I welcome the ambition that has been shown and I also welcome the report by Mr Blanco López, which will very clearly permit us to have an important and substantial debate on renewables, taking into account – and in answer to Ms Van Brempt’s point here – the significant fact that the new data on reduced clean technology costs lower the cost of achieving the renewable energy targets, and the achievement today of a 27% target – the one that the Commission is proposing – is cheaper by EUR 2.9 billion a year compared with the framework scenario we were given. So there is scope for having important discussions in the trilogue, and let us see what level of ambition the Council shows when it meets to decide on the general approach. I would like to devote a few minutes to energy poverty, because Mr Sylikiotis complained that the package is not ambitious on energy poverty. This is an important topic because one of the key objectives of the new package is to ensure that energy-poor and vulnerable consumers can benefit from modern energy services and are not left behind as consumers but become more engaged with the energy market. While fighting energy poverty is a Member State competence, the package presents a series of measures which support Member States in their efforts to reduce energy poverty. First of all, the package ensures that Member States give proper attention to the issue of energy poverty, that they monitor the number of households in energy poverty, and that all requisite measures are taken to address it. Second, the package gives Member States the tools and incentives to tackle energy poverty at the root, because to meet their energy savings obligations under the Energy Efficiency Directive, Member States have to direct energy efficiency measures towards households affected by energy poverty or in social housing. Under the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, Member States will have to consider energy poverty in their long-term renovation strategies. The Commission is currently working to set up an Energy Poverty Observatory to assist Member States in addressing energy poverty, and it will disseminate information and good practice. This observatory will be launched at the end of 2017. The package also provides consumers with the right to be informed about disconnection procedures, and alternatives to disconnection, sufficiently in advance and at no extra cost. Ms Harms also wanted to raise the level of ambition. It is very clear that we are now establishing 2030 targets. It is very clear that in 2018 we will have a facilitative dialogue under the framework of the Paris Agreement and that in 2023 there will be a stocktaking exercise in order to prepare new nationally determined contributions (NDCs). So we will be on a continuous pathway to raise the level of ambition and the stages designed under the Paris Agreement rules. In 2020 we will also have to submit decarbonisation strategies. We already have a roadmap, but we will have to improve on it. Mr Balczó was concerned about whether our legislation goes against the subsidiarity principle. We have been very respectful of the competences of Member States and when we establish regional operation centres we are not invading the competences of Member States or national regulatory authorities. We are only establishing the need to coordinate at regional level because we are no longer energy islands. Member States should now be better interconnected and energy will flow across the continent. We are driving towards a single market in the future, but first we have to integrate regional markets. To do that, we need regional operation centres, but we believe we have fully respected the subsidiarity principle. There was a contribution by Mr Howarth about competitiveness. Competitiveness is one of the five dimensions of the Energy Union and thus is a priority of the governance regulation because, with the national plans, Member States have to report on objectives for national funding targets for research and innovation to make sure that we stay the global leader in renewable energy. The governance regulation established a coherent legal framework aimed at providing long—term global stability and certainty for investors. That is fundamental. We are also putting in place an enabling framework that will be conducive to sustaining investment and growth driven by the deployment of low-carbon technologies. Ha habido una pregunta del señor Marcellesi, relativa a alguna decisión, a algún proyecto de Real Decreto del Gobierno español en torno a la prohibición del cierre de plantas de carbón. En este momento los servicios de la Comisión están analizando este proyecto de norma para ver su conformidad con la normativa europea en su conjunto. Lo que sí les voy decir en este momento —ya se han referido alguna de sus señorías— es que en Bonn hubo un evento, en el marco de la CP.23, en el que aproximadamente 25 países anunciaron su intención de abandonar definitivamente el carbón, entre ellos diez de la Unión Europea. Pero también le debo decir que en estos momentos en la Unión Europea hay 42 regiones —y ha habido algún diputado que lo ha puesto de manifiesto— y 11 Estados miembros que todavía siguen produciendo carbón, y además en 2016 había todavía 206 plantas de generación de carbón en 21 Estados miembros, con una capacidad de 100 gigawatios. Por lo tanto, teniendo en cuenta que el mix energético es competencia de los Estados miembros, la Comisión lo que va a exigir es que se cumpla el Derecho de la Unión y lo que va a hacer la Comisión es exigir que los Estados miembros cumplan sus objetivos de reducción de emisiones, establecidos en la Directiva en el marco de los mercados de carbono, por una parte, y de la Directiva sobre el reparto de esfuerzos, por otra parte. Ha habido una intervención del señor Benito Ziluaga relativa a los proyectos de interés común y la existencia de proyectos que apoyan el gas. Como sabe perfectamente el señor Benito Ziluaga, la selección de los proyectos es un proceso complejo. En primer lugar, los que presentan el proyecto son los promotores de los mismos. En segundo lugar, los grupos regionales, en los que están representantes de los Estados miembros, de los operadores de redes, de las autoridades reguladoras nacionales, de la Agencia de Cooperación de los Reguladores de la Energía, evalúan los proyectos de acuerdo con el valor añadido que tengan y las políticas europeas. Y se elabora una lista que la Comisión valida definitivamente. Sí le puedo decir que, si analiza la evolución de los proyectos en la lista que tenemos en este momento, verá que en 2015 los proyectos de electricidad eran el 55 % y ahora son el 61 %; los de gas eran el 39 % y ahora son el 30 %. Es decir, estamos en una evolución en que los PCI, los proyectos de interés común, cada vez más serán de electricidad y, por supuesto, serán menos de gas. Pero hay que tener en cuenta, no obstante, dos factores: que la demanda de gas en el año 2030 seguirá siendo de 350 000 millones de metros cúbicos y que, en segundo lugar, todavía se necesitan proyectos de gas en algunas regiones, como los países bálticos y los de Europa central y oriental, ya que son muy vulnerables porque dependen de un solo suministrador de gas. Es decir, hay zonas de la Unión Europea en que no hacen falta gasoductos adicionales y hay zonas que están totalmente aisladas y son dependientes de un suministrador único. Por lo tanto, todavía tenemos algunos proyectos que tendrán que realizarse, si bien la tendencia en el futuro será la financiación de proyectos en el sector de la electricidad. Quisiera decirle también al señor Blanco, en relación con su intervención, que la Comisión está en este momento analizando los detalles de su propuesta. Vamos a ver también cuál será la posición del Consejo el 18 de diciembre —la Posición Común—, pero entendemos que es una propuesta que puede ser francamente positiva a la hora de definir ambiciones futuras. Regarding Nord Stream: as you know, the Commission has a mandate to negotiate an international agreement so that we can apply the principles of European legislation. On the other side, we have proposed a reform, an amendment to the current Gas Regulation in order to make sure that the principles that preside in the functioning of the gas markets are also applied to all parts, to off-shore pipelines.  As a whole, I would like to thank all the Members for their interventions and say, to conclude, that the State of the Energy Union report highlights some progress that we have made during the last three years but it also illustrates that we still have a long way to go on the journey towards a carbon-neutral energy system. In the coming months, as we come to finalise the Clean Energy for All Europeans package, it will be vital in finalising the stable regulatory framework to facilitate this journey.  Based on the debate today, I am optimistic that you are aware of the responsibility and opportunities that lie ahead. This is what European citizens are expecting from all of us.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I think that I will express the feelings of those present in the room when I say that in your answers you referred to specific questions and to specific people, going beyond the prepared information on the sheet.Thank you very much for that.It made our debate more genuine.I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The Energy Union is crucial for the competitiveness of our economy, for our environmental goals and for the transition to a decarbonized economy. The 3rd State of the Energy Union report indicates that most Member States are on the right track to achieve the 2020 targets, but some countries need to do more. It also reviews the regulatory proposals that are being implemented. We have the opportunity to take advantage of the updating of the regulation of the European energy system to make it more efficient, safe and respectful with the environment. But for this we need to have more ambitious goals. In this sense, the ITRE Committee has approved two important reports led by the S & amp; D. They set a goal of 40% energy efficiency and a 35% share of renewable energy. With these objectives, the European Union offers a clear signal of leadership for the next decade, and amends the lack of ambition of the Council and the Commission. We risk the leadership of the Union, our international credibility and our commitment to the Paris agreement, as well as our quality of life and health.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - Global geopolitical events, global competition for energy and the impact of climate change are triggering a rethinking of the EU's energy and climate strategy. The challenges we face are unprecedented: growing dependence on imported energy, scarce energy resources and the need to mitigate climate change, all in a context of limited financial resources. The third report on the State of the Energy Union shows that progress has been made towards achieving the EU 2020 targets in terms of emission reduction, renewable energy and energy efficiency. Now is the time to implement the action required by the Paris Agreement and exploit the full potential offered by technological innovation in a true European dimension. To do this, we need to address the persistent obstacles to real market integration, uncoordinated national policies and a certain lack of a common position vis-à-vis non-EU countries. Our market should be in line with recent transformations, such as the increased presence of renewable sources with market-driven remuneration; greater integration of national markets through the development of interconnections; the development of smart grids and new decentralized generation technologies.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The Energy Union is crucial for the competitiveness of our economy, for our environmental goals and for the transition to a decarbonized economy. The 3rd State of the Energy Union report indicates that most Member States are on the right track to achieve the 2020 targets, but some countries need to do more. It also reviews the regulatory proposals that are being implemented. We have the opportunity to take advantage of the updating of the regulation of the European energy system to make it more efficient, safe and respectful with the environment. But for this we need to have more ambitious goals. In this sense, the ITRE Committee has approved two important reports led by the S & amp; D. They set a goal of 40% energy efficiency and a 35% share of renewable energy. With these objectives, the European Union offers a clear signal of leadership for the next decade, and amends the lack of ambition of the Council and the Commission. We risk the leadership of the Union, our international credibility and our commitment to the Paris agreement, as well as our quality of life and health.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The whole world is investing in renewable energy, the production of explosive cars is banned all over Europe, solar parks and wind farms are rising. Why all this? Increasing renewables allows us to pay little or nothing for energy. In Germany, which is at the forefront of renewables, for example, it has already happened twice that the consumer is paid if he uses electricity, not the other way around. The directive that has just been adopted also obliges the Member States to make it easier to install solar panels on our roofs. Today, in many countries, it takes years, many hundred-page forms to fill out to install a home solar panel. This will be abolished by the European Parliament with a mandatory one-stop shop, based on my own amendment. The future is renewable energy because it will make it cheaper overhead, create jobs, increase the economy and, incidentally, even protect the environment. Europe is keeping these in mind.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the deadly floods in the Attica area and humanitarian aid during the natural disaster (2017/2992 (RSP)).

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the flooding that took place ten days ago in West Athens is a human tragedy. I immediately sent my condolences to the families and friends of the people who lost their lives. In the aftermath of the disaster the Commission’s Emergency Response Coordination Centre was in close contact with the Greek authorities to monitor the situation via the European flood awareness system, and through the help of satellite maps of the affected areas. President Juncker met Prime Minister Tsipras in Gothenburg and he underlined the Commission’s willingness to assist Greece in every possible way. First and foremost, the Commission is open, upon request from the national authorities, to rapidly modifying cohesion policy programmes. This means redirecting some of the funding towards the reconstruction of public infrastructure and the regeneration of economic activity in the affected areas.  Secondly, the EU Solidarity Fund can be activated, provided that all the conditions are fulfilled, should the Greek authorities apply for solidarity assistance.  With climate change bringing more extreme weather events, we need to be able to protect human lives and valuable assets and to make our regions, our cities and our towns more resilient. The European structural and investment funds are there to do just that. They constitute a full package that supports climate-change adaptation, risk prevention and resilience building. Under the current programing period, EUR 1.3 billion is available to Greece for climate-change adaptation and risk-prevention measures.  The Commission is also ready to assist the Greek authorities with the compilation of flood-risk management plans and river management plans. These are essential tools to determine what areas are more prone to floods and how to be more prepared. Significant investment in water, waste water and anti-flooding infrastructure in Greece has been supported by the European Union over many years. Let me give you some figures. Between 2007 and 2013 cohesion policy programmes invested some EUR 1.2 billion to improve water supply across Europe, and that resulted in 1.5 million additional people having better access to water. Over 370 000 more people had access to new or upgraded waste-water treatment facilities. Also some EUR 400 million was invested in risk-prevention measures. This investment improves the daily life of Greek citizens and is helping to avoid disasters in many places. But there is more to it than a list of figures and visible results. Those investments also show the spirit of solidarity that is at the heart of the European project, and that is equally important. Thank you for your attention. I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, despair is the word that characterizes the inhabitants of the flood-hit areas of Western Attica, as well as the Municipality of Delta in Thessaloniki. Fourteen days after the deadly catastrophe of November 15, 2017, 23 dead have been identified, although this is not the final number. The material damage is incalculable; huge damage has been done to infrastructure, roads, roads, houses and cars, water and drinking water quality and electricity supply. Greece is finding it difficult to deal with such a catastrophe on its own. We thank all the parties in the European Parliament for their prompt response. We thank the Commissioner, Mrs Crețu, for what she has said before. I would especially like to thank my colleague, Elisabetta Gardini, for her intention to visit the affected areas. We ask for Community solidarity and help. To immediately mobilize the Solidarity Fund, to launch the European Union and other European aid mechanisms and to prepare a five-year program for the construction of flood protection projects in Greece, in cooperation with the European Investment Bank. The responsibilities in Greece will be blamed; both the current ones for the government and the region and the past, from many years ago. But a minister, a governor, should have resigned, just as the fires in Portugal did. Commissioner, let us prove that the European Union is on the side of the citizens who are being tested in Greece today. We hope and count on the help of the European Commission and the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D team. - Mr President, the disaster that struck Mandra and Nea Peramo caused the death of 23 people and major disasters. The situation is very difficult. Many points are not accessible. Even today, it is very difficult to record the damage. The responsibilities are many and timeless. Such a tragedy can not be used by anyone for micropolitics. The absence of an organized spatial plan led to anarchic construction, many times even on streams. The inaction of the state authorities for the construction of flood protection works after the fires of the last years further aggravated the problem. But now we have to see what happens in the future. Mr Stylianidis' intention to strengthen the European Civil Protection Mechanism is positive and will help address similar phenomena in the future. Flexibility on the part of the European Commission is needed to activate the Solidarity Fund. The total GDP of the Attica Region cannot become an obstacle for the utilization of funds, especially when the specific areas are among the weakest economically. They need the immediate support of all of us. We must also work not only for rehabilitation but also for prevention. We must, without oligarchy and bureaucracy, accelerate the absorption of Community funds to deal with specific natural disasters.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, West Attica - and in particular the city of Mandra - is experiencing an untold tragedy. Twenty-three of our compatriots, innocent victims, drowned in the catastrophic floods of November 15th. Floods caused by emergency weather, in a disaster that hit the area. At the same time, the deadly floods highlighted the timeless criminal negligence and responsibility of the successive Greek governments and the Attica Region, which allowed the streams to be blocked and did not carry out the necessary flood protection works. Mr President, we extend our condolences to the families of the victims of the deadly floods and, as we did on 15 November in the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we once again call on the Commission, in cooperation with the Greek authorities, to take the necessary steps. actions to release funds from the European Solidarity Fund and the European Regional Development Fund to repair the damage, carry out flood defenses and immediately compensate those affected who have fled and lost their property.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we are living in a human tragedy and we are already mourning 23 people who have died in a deadly storm of 50 years, which has caused incredible human suffering and devastation. At this time of tragedy, the last thing we Greeks need is micropolitics. What we need, Commissioner, is practical European solidarity. Not just words, but more works. President Juncker promised this to the Greek Prime Minister, Alexis Tsipras, a few days ago, and now it must be done. The Greek government, the region and the Greek society are doing their duty, with brave measures to rehabilitate and support the victims, measures to alleviate human suffering and a giant program of flood defenses that should have been done decades ago. But we also need more resources to deal with natural disasters in Europe. Increase flexibility and speed of response, make conditions more flexible and enhance efficiency, Commissioner. When a people suffers and experiences such tragedies as recently as Italy and Portugal, and formerly the Czech Republic and Germany, it wants European solidarity not only in words but also as a visible result, with material and human resources. This is what we expect from you.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we have seen a horrible tragedy happening in Greece. Twenty-one people have lost their lives. Families and friends are grieving for the victims of this latest disaster, and Greece really is one of the hotspots of the effect of climate change that we see all over Europe. We have also had floods in past years, and we have had heatwaves. So this is really where we need to help. We need to do whatever we can do as the European Union. The Commissioner has already outlined some of those issues. I think we should also engage in the long term to help rebuild. Apart from the lives that were lost, we also have severe damage to infrastructure and housing. People’s homes have been destroyed, their economic means of support have been destroyed, and we need to help in the long and medium term, too, so that those properties can be rebuilt, and so that EU regional money and funds can also be used on long-term measures such as anti-flood works and on prevention for the future. It is one thing is, of course, to respond to a disaster, but the second question is how to prevent it from happening again in the future – with smart urban planning, with making sure that we respect the environment, keeping green zones, and making sure that rivers can extend when there is heavy rainfall. All those prevention measures will become more and more important as we see climate change progressing. A joint effort is therefore needed, not just in Greece but also all over Europe, because we have also seen, as colleagues have mentioned, similar disasters happening all over Europe. So we need to get smart. We need to make sure that people are not harmed, that no damage is done by the catastrophe. We need to focus on prevention so that we don’t have to be sorry for loss later on.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I express my solidarity and that of the entire delegation of the 5 Star Movement, as well as my sympathy, in the Greek sense of the term, to the people of Attica for the very serious human losses and serious damage due to floods. As Italians we are well aware of the pain and the sense of helplessness and anger that one feels when faced with such situations. That said, we are co-legislators, we have a duty and a responsibility to act. The primary objective is to give relief to the affected populations, with the utmost speed and effectiveness. Therefore, the Solidarity Fund must be revised, the maximum disbursable advance must be increased - today at 30 million euros -, the total allocation - stopped at 500 million euros - must be increased, but above all, for the next regulation of the cohesion policy , rules are indispensable to enable rapid reprogramming, unrelated to thematic concentration, and with 100% funding from the Commission.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, 23 human lives have been lost, and there are questions about any immigrants who have never been registered. Great catastrophes for the life of working class families and small self-employed. Everything is a consequence of the timeless policy of current and previous governments, regional and local administrations and the European Union. The Greek government does not compensate the victims in the amount of 100% of the damages and burdens them provocatively even with loans, new loans, setting up development fiestas at the crime scene. And the European Union does not provide any compensation for the affected working-class households, except for business groups and those who treasure up as investors in the reconstruction of the ruined, ossifying the solidarity fund of large builders. Also, based on the criterion of reciprocity, flood protection is referred to the calendars for decades. To compensate here and now 100% the victims of the tragedy, by removing all the elusive limits and restrictions of the European Union, which Mrs. Crețu confirmed today that they apply in full. Such solidarity; we are talking about the European Union. Also, based on the resolution submitted by the KKE MEPs to the REGI committee, all the required anti-flood projects should be implemented immediately.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - On behalf of the EPP Group and as coordinator in the REGI Committee, I would like to express my condolences to the victims and nevertheless make a few comments about that situation. We heard it: it concerned special weather conditions, which only occur occasionally. I can tell you: I come from the Netherlands and large parts of the country are below sea level. We use a risk profile of once every 10,000 years. That's how high our dikes are. How is it possible with such a circumstance in Greece? It is not checked how indeed the beds are built up and so on. We must move towards a European standard, towards a common European risk profile. What colleagues are saying here seems so strange to me. Two suggestions. The first is indeed to show solidarity and to deal flexibly with the borders in the Solidarity Fund. That is why I ask the Commissioner: can you actively support Greece in applying the rules that we have recently completed in Parliament? Secondly, with regard to the already existing possibilities from the Regional Development Fund, where there is still room in Greece, do you want to see whether a prevention plan can be drawn up? Of course, you cannot stop a thunderstorm, but you can make sure that the water can escape. In that sense, I would like an answer from you.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, let me add my voice to that of my colleagues, to express our solidarity with those affected by the catastrophic floods. While we are still mourning the dead, it is not the time to take responsibility; but the time will come. As is well known, the Solidarity Fund is activated when disasters exceed 1.5% of the GDP of the affected region. We call on countries in financial crisis and on a memorandum of cooperation not to be subject to this 1.5%. Last Thursday, the Commission unveiled its plans to build an immediate response force based on joint operational technical means, such as firefighting planes, joint hospitals, etc. But the most important thing is not the technical infrastructure; it is that the Member States will submit to the Commission their plans for dealing with natural disasters, in order to identify and correct any gaps. So this is the solidarity we demand from the European institutions. It is necessary to allocate funds from the Solidarity Fund, but it comes after the disaster. But prevention is needed. The European Union must offer security to the European citizen, regardless of the malfunctions and distortions of national mechanisms. Ensuring economic solidarity, but also evaluating and correcting the supposedly complete and always ambitious national plans that often drown in the flood waters they are called to deal with.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, two weeks ago thunderstorms of exceptional intensity hit Greece. The torrential rains caused extensive property damage and the death of 23 people. I would like to express all my support and solidarity to the Greek people in this terrible ordeal they are going through. According to Prime Minister Tsipras, this disaster is aggravated by, I quote, "numerous deficiencies in public infrastructure". Indeed, major public drainage and renovation works had been approved before being postponed. Such a humanitarian disaster demonstrates the importance of quality public services ensuring the safety of citizens. However, if the government has its share of responsibility, due to the continued urbanization of a region at risk, the evils of the budgetary austerity policy imposed by Brussels on the Greeks have not helped. So today we hope for a strong gesture from the Commission.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr. President, the catastrophe that struck West Attica, leaving behind 23 dead so far and hundreds of homeless families, is also due to the destructive intervention of man in nature, but mainly to criminal negligence and mismanagement by the political leadership over time. Climate change and fires are difficult to control and do not depend solely on the actions of a country or a government. However, the existence of illegal landfills, the dense, arbitrary and unplanned construction, the absence of flood defenses and the poor planning of such disasters have a strong basis in the political ethos of the last 40 years. Left, right and center politicians, instead of dealing with the good of Greece, were and continue to be concerned with their own interest and the appropriation of power. We see the results today; disasters, deaths, memoranda, deterioration of the social fabric and moral decline. Immediate solution: the most urgent assistance to the residents of West Attica affected by the disaster. Essential solution: the immediate removal of incompetent and selfish politicians from the government of the country.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today we are all united in expressing the deep sorrow for the victims and their families, because a part of Greece - we have heard and seen it - has been severely and severely hit. Loss of life - the toll is probably not complete yet -, houses destroyed and thousands of people evacuated. Those who live in those areas still find themselves struggling with the dramatic consequences of this natural disaster that has hit them. Civil protection has redoubled its efforts and spoke of a perhaps unprecedented flood. So it is good that we remember, as the Commissioner did, that solidarity is at the very heart of the European Union project, but this solidarity must be fast, it must go fast and reach the populations quickly. We must give a strong signal and help this seriously wounded population. This Fund needs to be mobilized. I believe that my colleague Kefalogiannis has made some very clear proposals, very acceptable, as has the Commissioner, whom I thank for his words. We can't be blocked by bureaucracy, but let's really make it our primary focus. It is not a question of blaming. There is climate change, things have changed, we must secure our territories, we must equip ourselves with other tools, we must allow more investments. The resilience of our territories must be a main and fundamental objective. Thus we will demonstrate true solidarity with all European citizens who expect this from us.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, two weeks have passed and the situation remains tragic after the deadly flood in Western Attica. The dramatic toll is 23 dead and major or complete destruction in more than 1,500 buildings, while schools and kindergartens remain closed. Residents of the area, despite their efforts to return to normalcy, are facing tons of mud, as well as the cold and damage to their homes and small businesses. This cannot be the image of 21st century Greece and, of course, there is no time to shift the big responsibilities for this catastrophe. The European Union must show in the best possible way its solidarity with Greece and its citizens, by immediately mobilizing European funds. It is important to activate direct resources to deal with the disasters in Western Attica, as happened with the earthquakes in Italy. The Commission should also reconsider the damage limit of 1.5% of regional GDP for eligibility for regional natural disasters from the Solidarity Fund. At the same time, however, the Greek state must and must strengthen its cooperation in the field of civil protection to combat emergencies. We live in a time of extreme weather and the Member States of the European Union must take appropriate action to protect the lives and interests of their citizens. We expect that there will be public investment and immediate implementation of flood protection projects. Unfortunately, in recent years Europe has been suffering a lot from natural disasters as a result of climate change. We must stop mourning the victims of natural disasters and offer more by providing solidarity and assistance by improving risk assessment mechanisms, prevention systems and means of combating these phenomena.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I come from West Attica. I recently landed in Brussels. The president of New Democracy, Mr. Kyriakos Mitsotakis, went there for the second time. What we have seen can not be described; mud-soaked houses, people who have lost relatives, friends, damaged infrastructure, inaccessible roads; not even clean water. This is not the time to focus on responsibilities, this is the time to decide what to do. It seems that, here, all political forces agree on this question, starting from the need to show strong political will, so that this translates into additional resources and support for Greece in the face of this great crisis. Let me explain: I propose, as Mr van Nistelrooij opened the debate and Mr Kyrkos continued, the revision of the Solidarity Fund regulation. We ask the Commission to be more flexible depending on the circumstances and not to stick to the regulation of 1.5% of Gross Domestic Product per region. I suggest that we explore all possibilities for additional funding for Greece beyond the Solidarity Fund, as happened in Greece. Finally, I suggest that we have procedures independent of the activation of the Solidarity Fund, that there be no national participation in flood protection projects, prevention projects and rehabilitation projects in high risk areas. Greece needs tangible proof of our solidarity and it is necessary to show it today. (applause)

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you all very much for your valuable support. From this step, I also want to express my warm condolences to the families of my 23 fellow citizens who lost their lives in the tragedy in Attica. Two weeks after this unprecedented natural disaster, it is time to immediately launch all the necessary European mechanisms to support the people affected, their families, businesses, homes and vital infrastructure that have been completely destroyed. At the same time, it is necessary to combine emergency aid with preventive measures, in order to offer relief to the local communities, municipalities and communities of Attica that are experiencing this nightmare in the worst way. In this context, we welcome the Commission's proposal to establish a strengthened European system of civil protection and response to natural disasters, which will strengthen the prevention mechanisms and preparedness of the Union, as well as of the Member States, to deal with emergencies. This is an expression of true solidarity. We are all vulnerable to natural disasters and only with proper cooperation and coordination can we deal with them. Europe is in solidarity. He recently supported Italy, Portugal and Spain by mobilizing the Solidarity Fund. Ladies and gentlemen, winter is ahead and the weather is unpredictable. My colleagues made very important suggestions. Today, I call for the acceleration of the procedures for the immediate relief of our Greek fellow human beings who were hit so hard by the recent floods in Attica.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I call on the European Commission to respond quickly and effectively.I want to express my support for Greece and also for us to help the affected region.Rapid, solidarity-based assistance is, I think, the best response against the spread of Euroscepticism and mistrust.Natural disasters are not being avoided by any country in Europe.The Czech Republic also experienced a catastrophic flood in 1997, when 49 people died.17 people died in 2002, and it was also important for us at that time, even though we were not yet members of the EU, that we were not alone and even then we could already draw on the reconstruction of infrastructure from the Solidarity Fund.However, national governments must also work effectively and build flood prevention measures.As far as possible, we must do everything we can to prevent losses and destruction today, but we must also think about the future.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, Greece is facing an unprecedented human tragedy with dozens of deaths, as a consequence, on the one hand, of extreme weather events caused by climate change and, on the other, of the lack of adequate flood planning. Europe must show its solidarity. At the moment, however, it is doubtful whether Europe has the institutional tools to show that solidarity. The Solidarity Fund Regulation therefore needs to be revised. The limit of 1.5% of regional GDP on the one hand is too inelastic and this can be seen in the case of the Attica region, which is a huge region with almost half of Greece's GDP and therefore it is almost impossible or very difficult to mobilize the Fund, and on the other hand, it is a limit that is misrepresented only from an economic point of view, while the human factor should also be taken into account. It is inconceivable to have dozens of dead and not meet the conditions for assistance from the Solidarity Fund. The regulation therefore needs to be revised to make it more flexible and more humane.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to express my sorrow for the unjust loss of 23 of our fellow human beings and my sincere condolences to their relatives and friends. No one disputes the fact that in those days the weather was extreme and Mother Nature showed her destructive abilities, especially since we humans do not respect her. If the streams had not been blocked and so many arbitrary buildings had not been built, this disaster would not have happened. The criminal oligarchy of both previous and current governments has allowed this situation. Following the summer fires, the district did not carry out the required anti-corrosion works. In the aftermath of such a catastrophe, no substantial move has been made by the government to support the victims or relatives of the victims; only words and hypocritical political confrontation. From the first moment, our movement, the Golden Dawn, found itself with the meager means we have at the side of the victims. However, the European Union is not without responsibility, as it did not examine whether the approved funds of the European Union were used properly for the construction of flood defenses. Of course, no one will accept their responsibilities. But the people know and I assure you that they will not forget. However, immediate priority is the relief of those affected by compensation in 100% of the property.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Mr President, I was there in Mandra last Saturday. I was shocked, the situation is nightmarish despite the enormous efforts of the residents, the volunteers who arrive from every corner of Athens and the state authorities. Water has knocked half the city off its foundations. Only debris was left from the kindergarten. Half of the residents do not have houses. It is a fact that immediate assistance is needed for the first aid, but I ask the House to think that we should adopt this new city, which should be built on the ruins of the old one, but without any problems. Can the reconstruction of the city be included in the Juncker fund? The best investment is to invest in people.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, after some other European countries, it is unfortunately Greece's turn to suffer the consequences of a major catastrophe, a major flood that caused the death of 23 people in West Attica and the destruction of all its infrastructure and facilities. area. Anarchic construction, violation of the rules of nature and the lack of flood protection were the main causes, which over time cause these disasters, and also caused the death, as I mentioned, of our fellow human beings. I express my sincere condolences to their families and wish that God gives them strength to face the problem that currently exists. It is true that the European Union has shown its solidarity, but this solidarity must be substantial, honest, courageous and not only repair the damage to the facilities, but above all compensate those who have lost their property.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: We close the parliamentary debate.We therefore proceed to hearing a position on behalf of the European Commission, Commissioner Creţu.I believe your task is not too complicated: a lot of things have been said to the Commission.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I will speak in Romanian. Mr President, unfortunately, I am more and more present here and in the Member States in the face of such tragedies, in the face of such catastrophes, and I express my sincere condolences once again. You know very well, the European Commission has always been present. I went to the field in Italy, tomorrow I'm going to Portugal where, you know very well that this summer eighty people died in the tragic fires that took place four times over the summer. In Greece, as I said, from the first moment I was here in front of you to change the regulations and you know very well that in the period 2007-2013 we practically took this exceptional measure with your help as co-legislators, to help Greece with liquidity and , so it was practically the only country that did not have co-financing, it did not have to co-finance, so we can unlock all ongoing projects. So, once again, I want to assure you of the full compassion of the European Commission and myself. As I said, we are in constant contact with the Greek authorities to investigate all possibilities, to help Greece, to help the people of Greece. I have listened to you very carefully and I assure you that we in the Commission stand shoulder to shoulder in solidarity with the Greek people and all the states that are suffering because of these issues related to natural disasters, which are more and more frequent, as I said. . We are at the disposal of the Greek authorities, of the national authorities to evaluate together and take immediate and long-term measures together, to help as much as we can, not only in words, as you said, but, you know well, that in deeds we want to do as much as possible. I proposed to Minister Charitsis to examine the Attica Operational Program and see if we can redirect part of the allocation, both for the reconstruction of infrastructure and for economic development. We try to respond as quickly as possible to urgent needs. So far we have not received an assessment from the Greek authorities, as it has been a difficult damage assessment process for Italy. So they cannot be evaluated overnight. In connection with the Solidarity Fund, I have listened to you very carefully and I largely share your point of view. I just want to remind you that this legislation has been adopted by you in the European Parliament and the European Council as co-legislative institutions. Attica, indeed, is the richest region in Greece, and therefore this threshold is higher and we do not yet know whether it can be reached to activate the Solidarity Fund. In any case, we are waiting for this evaluation, but I also want to remind you that this instrument is being re-evaluated every two and a half years and I think that with the negotiation of the new regulations after 2020, we should work together to see to what extent can we leave more room for maneuver in such cases. It is in your hands this decision to re-evaluate the regulations on the Solidarity Fund. In any case, I want to tell you that Greece has benefited from 114.3 million euros in the face of national disasters, both since 2006 for the fires in Evros, in August 2007 for the fires in the forests, in 2014 for the earthquake in Kefalonia, in February for a new earthquake, and we are now in the process of assessing the damage in Lefkada and Lesbos. You know very well that this summer I was right there in Chios when this earthquake occurred. So, 114.3 million euros from the Solidarity Fund, the second country after Italy in terms of these amounts, which reflects the solidarity of the European Union. We still need to assess more precisely, with the help of the Greek authorities, the total damage caused by the floods and see whether the region is eligible for assistance. I would also like to remind you that the European Union has been instrumental over the last year in establishing a preventive and adaptive framework for Greece. I am convinced that, without our ex ante conditionalities, we would have had many more natural disasters in Greece but with these ex ante conditionalities, we have avoided so many things. Following the launch of an EU adaptation strategy in 2013, Greece adopted this national adaptation strategy last year. I know that regions in Greece are working very hard. I know all the Presidents of the 13 regions and they are working very hard to develop and implement regional adaptation action plans. We are not naming and blaming here. It is our duty to do our utmost together so, coupled with the Commission’s recent proposal for a revised civil protection mechanism, this action will certainly allow disasters like the one that hit West Attica to be tackled in a more effective and coordinated way. Mr van Nistelrooij, I want to tell you again that, under the current programming period, Greece has EUR 1.3 billion which have not been spent and are available for climate change adaptation and risk prevention measures so we should have plans and projects to spend this money . Money is not everything.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: in writing. - Greece is facing an unprecedented human tragedy mourning, already, 23 dead. The deadly floods in West Attica are the result of extreme weather events and the timeless lack of adequate flood planning. The responsibilities are timeless and concern the Greek governments until today and the Attica Region, which either allowed the streams to be blocked or did not proceed in time to carry out the necessary flood protection works. The EU also has responsibilities, which continue to ignore and allow projects that endanger the environment and human lives. The deadly floods have shown in the worst possible way that the existing European disaster management system has reached its limits. What the EU needs today is more resources, more flexibility and simplification of administrative procedures in order to reduce response delays, strengthen the effectiveness of its interventions to prevent, deal with and repair natural disasters. The Solidarity Fund regulation needs to be revised immediately. It is inconceivable that we mourn dozens of dead and that the conditions for assistance from the Solidarity Fund are not met. The 1.5% threshold needs to be made more flexible. The Commission must take immediate action to release funds from existing mechanisms to repair the damage, carry out flood defenses and compensate those affected.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Peter Simon, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU)No. 575/2013 for leverage ratio, net stable funding ratio, own funds requirements and eligible liabilities, counterparty credit risk, market risk, counterparty exposurescentral, exposures to undertakings for collective investment, large exposures and requirements for the presentation and disclosure of information and amending Regulation (EU) No. 648/2012 (COM (2016) 0850 - C8-0158 /2017 - 2016 / 0360B (COD)) (A8-0255 / 2017).

name: Peter SIMON
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! This dossier is just two individual articles of the extremely extensive Commission proposal to revise the Capital Adequacy Regulation CRR 2, more precisely transitional rules for the accounting provisions under the new IFRS 9 standard and for large exposure rules. So it is about certain limits for banks to invest in government bonds that are denominated in foreign currency. It is necessary to deal with these two articles in an accelerated procedure so that these transitional rules can come into force in time for January 1, 2018, in order to avoid a so-called cliff effect by softening the effects of the introduction of these new standards. In July we in the ECON committee already determined the position of the European Parliament with a very large majority and, after three trialogues, we were also able to come to a result with the Council that we believe was very good and supported by a very large majority of this House at committee level. I would therefore like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the representatives of the Commission and the Estonian Council Presidency for the good cooperation and the speedy conclusion of this dossier. What is it in detail? On the one hand, there are accounting standards. IFRS 9 replaces the old accounting standard IAS 39, but brings about significant changes in the accounting for the expected losses of a bank. As a result, there is a risk of a considerable additional burden on the banks due to a significant increase in regulatory capital with the introduction on January 1, 2018. This expected additional burden is intended to ease a transition phase of five years. However, these transitional provisions must then also come into force on January 1st, hence the accelerated procedure that we have chosen here. The European Commission has one to mitigate these consequences The dynamic approach is provided, which allows the expected losses to be added back to equity to a certain extent over a period of five years. We have clearly supported this dynamic approach in our positioning in the European Parliament, since with such an approach the relief can be adjusted annually and unexpected situations such as an economic crisis can be taken into account much better and more risk-sensitive. However, we have also made some important modifications to ensure that the additional burdens actually only caused by the introduction of IFRS 9 are relieved in this transition phase. The position of the Council, on the other hand, was significantly more complex than our position and, conversely, pursues a statistical approach which, however, has a dynamic component. According to this, banks would have to calculate the expected losses for the period of one year and for the entire remaining term in the transition phase using both the statistical approach and a dynamic approach. Only in the event that the result of the calculation according to an annual dynamic calculation method deviates by more than 20% from the calculations according to the original statistical approach at the beginning, for example due to a negative economic shock, can the amount exceed the 20% limit must be calculated back in addition to common equity tier 1 capital. The main concern for us in the trialogue was defending the dynamic components of our approach, and we succeeded in doing so. We have managed to walk the tightrope of reaching a compromise on the basis of the statistical approach of the Commission, but this provides for a strong and clear dynamic component, which says that from a threshold of 0% deviation - i.e. everything that is greater than 0% deviation of the dynamic calculation part from the original static calculation part - here again an addition to equity can take place.This ensures that we can proceed in a more risk-sensitive manner here, that we can make annual adjustments here, and basically that is all that we have pursued here in Parliament with the dynamic approach, with the approach that the Commission originally proposed.All in all, this is an important success for this House in the negotiations with the Council, and we think that we are putting forward something that will ensure, on the one hand, that the new accounting standards will put us in better waters here than in the pastbut also ensures for others that this takes place smoothly and without unnecessary cliff effects.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the vote in this House today on International Financial Reporting Standard 9 (IFRS 9) can be considered an early harvest from the Commission’s November 2016 proposal to amend the prudential requirements for banks. This early harvest is important for at least two reasons. First, it will provide banks with the option to phase in the impact of enhanced expected credit-loss provision. It will also address a specific issue that some Member States have with regard to exposure to the public sector denominated in a currency other than their own under the large exposure rules. Second, it will provide these solutions on time. Subject to Parliament’s agreement, the proposed solution will become available to banks from 1 January 2018 onwards. That is when the IFRS 9 financial instruments become mandatorily applicable and when the existing transitional agreements under the large exposure rules are set to expire. At this point, the impact of IFRS 9 on capital raises may be relatively limited for the majority of banks. However, nobody will really know the impact until the standard is applied. More importantly, nobody knows what the effect of IFRS 9 would be should the economic situation suddenly deteriorate. It is from this ‘better safe than sorry’ perspective that the Commission included a five-year transitional regime in the proposal. This will work as a safeguard against unexpected sudden adverse impacts on bank capital raises, due to a new accounting approach on credit risk provision. The Commission, like Parliament, considers that the dynamic approach would be a more effective safeguard against unexpected deterioration of the economy than a static approach, whereby the amount of add-back would be determined as a point-in-time number. The final political agreement with the Council was on a static approach, but with the dynamic top-up that, thanks to the Parliament’s perseverance during the negotiations, is not subject to any threshold. So, overall I consider that the outcome of the agreed approach will constitute an effective safeguard for the next five years. The adoption of this transitional package is a temporary safeguard. It does not undermine the longer-term risk-reduction benefits of IFRS 9. Enhanced expected credit risk provisioning will lead to earlier and higher provisioning against credit-risk buybacks. IFRS 9 will help prevent the build-up of stock of new non-performing loans with insufficient provisioning. Unlike in the case of IFRS 9, we know what the potential impact would be of failing to put in place a suitable solution for the treatment of public sector exposures denominated in a non-domestic currency under the large exposure rules. For Member States which are not part of the euro but which issue a lot of their public debt in euros, not finding a solution would mean that banks would either have to increase significantly their capital or sell a significant amount of their sovereign bond holdings. That would have the potential to distort the market for government bonds in those Member States. This is why the Commission proposed to provide for a specific arrangement to mitigate such an impact. I welcome the fact that the political agreement reached by this Parliament and the Council is very close to the Commission’s proposal. Parliament’s vote on this matter can demonstrate that the European legislative construct is capable of delivering important regulation within a short time frame. We have accomplished important work to agree on a final text. I want to take this opportunity to thank Parliament, and in particular Mr Roberto Gualtieri and the rapporteur, Mr Peter Simon and the shadow rapporteurs. Your work on this file can deliver an early harvest from the negotiations on the banking package. I hope this will also be a prelude to an agreement on the full banking package, for the sake of financial stability and economic growth in the EU.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! With the introduction regime for the new global accounting standard, we are drawing another lesson from the financial crisis. We protect financial stability, lending and legal certainty, and we are taking another important first step in the ongoing revision of the regulatory framework for all European banks. The new accounting standard is more forward-looking in recognizing expected credit losses in order to ensure adequate risk provisioning by financial institutions and reduce excessive risk-taking. However, since its introduction - as previous speakers have mentioned - could lead to a disproportionate impact on capital ratios and lending, the European Parliament already called for an introductory regime in October 2016, and tomorrow’s decision will provide an answer to this request. We strike a good balance between the dynamic and the static approach in order to be more flexible and risk-sensitive in the face of economic changes, we anchor a freedom of choice for institutions to take into account different requirements, we ensure adequate disclosure and reporting requirements, and we set the duration of the regime in accordance with the Basel requirements for five years. At the same time, we are anchoring a transitional provision for the exception to the upper limit for large loans in foreign currencies in order to prevent undesirable effects on financial stability here too. I can tell colleagues that I consider it a good, suitable, forward-looking compromise and that I am asking for approval tomorrow.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr. Chairman, we are going to adopt, through an accelerated procedure, the conditions for the introduction of IFRS 9, which is an accounting standard allowing losses incurred to be passed to expected losses, which has a direct impact on the accounting of losses on loans. Mr. Karas has just recalled that this Parliament, in its resolution of December 6, 2016, had requested such a procedure for adapting the conditions for introducing IFRS 9 into the financial statements, since this accounting standard will come into force. to January 1 of next year. It was important to recognize that the transitional arrangements were necessary, as a sudden increase in provisions for expected credit losses would have led to a sharp weakening of regulatory capital ratios, just as we ask banks to consolidate them. But we must look beyond this, because if this regulation makes it possible to mitigate the negative impact on the regulatory capital of banks, the question of the impact of this standard on the financial stability of the Union remains unanswered, even then. that the IASB does not yet carry out impact studies. We will therefore have to take up a certain number of concerns that are already on the table regarding the risks of procyclical effects of this standard when a period of recession begins or regarding the question of the alteration of the distribution of credits between activities. , or the risk of shortening loan maturities. This leads us, as Parliament, as we said when adopting IFRS 9, to reiterate our request for a serious assessment of the impact of this standard, in- apart from the amendment which will already be proposed, as we know, next year. Indeed, we must ensure that this standard does not weaken the conditions for forming long-term investment. That's the reason for which we perhaps want to ask the Commission not to delay in considering the impact assessment of this standard.In this spirit, we must recall the recommendations of the Maystadt report, which invited us to reject any standard that would undermine the financial stability of the Union and, if necessary, to reflect on the possibility for the European Union to adopt,either carve-out or, I also think, carve-in, that is to say a possibility to add to what the IASB offers us when they define an accounting standard.These are the few elements I wanted to bring to our debate this evening.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The Polish delegation in the ECR group fully supports the establishment of transitional provisions on international financial reporting standards from January 1, 2018. This solution is even necessary because the comprehensive implementation of IFRS 9 at this stage may cause banks to accumulate large provisions against expected credit losses, but at the same time reduce the proportion of their capital required by regulation. The possibility for banks to include part of the increased reserves in the transitional period, as the so-called additional capital, will contribute to the financial stability of this sector and will facilitate the implementation of the entire directive. However, it remains to be hoped that banks will make good use of the additional time they have been able to adapt to the new regulations and, without the risk of losing the liquidity of their assets, will build more solid provisions to cover possible credit losses, so that the 2007 scenario, which is a compromise for the bank loan market, does not become he repeated.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately we will go to vote tomorrow on another accounting rule which will heavily affect what is the European credit market and above all the systems that are more oriented towards this process linked to credit. I do not see any action on the part of regulators, on the part of the European Central Bank, on the part of the Commission, to stem the financial problem, and in the asset quality reviews and stress tests of the European Central Bank there is no mention of the derivatives problem, while, on the other hand, the focus continues to be on the problem of credit and credit deterioration. Now, going and asking for capital on what may be loans that will show signs of deterioration in the future is obviously a too strong sign of persistence on the part of the institutions towards the credit system, I repeat, doing nothing for the derivatives and finance market. Incidentally, Germany, which has more than 1 600 banks offering credit on a regional basis, will be excluded from this system, which seems to me quite shocking, because it is a very obvious systemic risk.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. Chairman, the IFRS 9 accounting standard will significantly increase the volatility of bank balance sheets, and in particular of French banks. IFRS 9 will indeed have a significant procyclical effect by generalizing fair value to replace historical value. Rules like IFRS 9 are part of a multifaceted arsenal intended to weaken banking intermediation in financing the economy and to encourage its replacement by financing markets under the control of American players. In addition, this rule will increase the propensity of the big banks to approach a default when political deadlines in a given country would make it possible to predict that Eurosceptic parties, which would of course displease the financial markets, would be on the way to collapse. be elected. We want strong banks, but IFRS 9 does not allow that. This rule, on the contrary, makes banks more fragile. We can no longer continue the process of weakening and dismembering the banks of continental Europe, and in particular France, for the greater profit of the American banks.
