Under these conditions, this Simon report, which de facto amounts to delaying the application of IFRS 9 by five years, is therefore very positive and it is for this reason that we will support it.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Mr President, the financial crisis has shown us that financial institutions, especially banks, have reported too late and too little the huge losses suffered by all kinds of financial products. International Financial Reporting Standard no. 9 is the main answer in the field of highlighting these damages, moving from the method of recording damages when they are produced to the assessment, forecasting these damages before they occur and, at the same time, establishing provisions. This is the novelty brought by this standard in the field of financial institutions. Accordingly, the need arose to increase capital, thus having an impact on the amount of capital needed by financial institutions and, as a result, industries required a transitional period. But, we must mention very clearly, this transitional period refers to the prudential rules that the banking system, the European Central Bank, the central banks follow and not to the accounting, registration, financial reporting rules, which still oblige financial institutions. from 1 January 2018 to register, highlight possible product damage in the future and take measures to prevent them.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this text we have concluded a political agreement to avoid a significant increase in the level of provisions in the balance sheet due to the new approach to impairment required by IFRS 9 accounting standards. In particular, we have achieved a good result regarding the so-called phasing-in. In fact, we have avoided that the application involves a sudden increase in provisions for expected credit losses and therefore a consequent decrease in the capital ratios of banks, especially small banks, and planned to be able to adopt these measures with transitional provisions aimed at preventing any unjustified impact on the system. Furthermore, this transition period should also provide an adequate measure to avoid any pro-cyclical effects. Finally, the text on which the Parliament and the Council agreed is appropriate to minimize the disadvantages for all those institutions that use the standardized method compared to institutions that use internal models. It is therefore an important measure in support above all of small banks, protagonists of investments in the real economy, and of small and medium-sized enterprises in our continent, which would have had greater difficulties in adopting these measures without these transitional provisions.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mister President! The new standards were presented in 2014 and should originally come into effect in the EU on January 1, 2018. The schedule was too tight, especially for smaller banks, as the implementation is associated with considerable implementation costs. Transitional periods are intended to minimize such costs. The later implementation of these standards is therefore appropriate. This makes perfect sense in the context of the system. At this point I would like to point out another point: regulation costs money, regulation costs tend to be borne more by small companies and banks. They have fewer staff and less lobbying power to influence regulation in their favor - a crucial point for me. Complicated banking regulations are only necessary because the elementary principle of liability for economic activity has been suspended. Anyone who saves insolvent banks with taxpayers' money because it appears politically opportune needs complex regulation to give taxpayers the feeling that they will no longer be asked to pay up in the future. The bailouts after the recent financial crisis had become necessary because the banks had made risky commitments. The low interest rate policy of the US central bank in particular has led to this. Because of the ECB's zero interest rate policy, this dangerous political game is repeated. Even close-knit regulation does not protect against this.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to avoid a new crisis it is essential to reduce risks within the Banking Union and this is a precondition for the reform of the euro area. The introduction of the new IFRS 9 international accounting standards will lead to major changes for banks, in particular on the crucial issue of credit risk and provisions. The new scenario will oblige a growing interaction between risk management structures and administrative structures, and will imply the need to adopt managerial choices and estimates, the opportunity for a conscious attitude also on the side of credit demand and the consequent attention to customer information. This is therefore a major challenge for the banking sector, also in view of the risks in terms of future profitability and volatility. Transitional provisions are therefore essential, especially for small banks, aimed at preventing any unjustified impact of the introduction of IFRS 9 on the regulatory capital of EU banks, for example by allowing them to add part of the capital to their primary capital. provisions for expected credit losses.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we are talking about rescuing the banks while there is a huge scandal, because the banks have been rescued with various packages and what they are actually doing is now attacking the borrowers themselves or the people who rescued them. For example, in Greece we had at least three bank recapitalizations. The Greek people, with the memoranda, paid dearly for the recapitalization of the banks. And what are the banks doing now? They started the aggressive policy with the auctions from today. The government with MAT and by force now imposes electronic auctions and so the "crows" seize the property of the Greeks. Also beware: banks give new loans to those who will participate in the auctions to buy real estate. It lends them up to 70% of the value of the property that is put up for auction, to create a new generation of red loans. Will we save these banks?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I do not have very much to add to the discussion. We have mostly been thanking each other by our various comments, so the only thing I want to add is that, as agreed before, the Commission will make the overall impact assessment of this new standard by 2020. I thank you all for a good discussion. Once more, this is a good compromise. It shows that we can prioritise important files and also find a compromise and adopt quite complicated pieces of legislation, which is important for financial stability.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Tonight's discussion showed two things. On the one hand, that tomorrow we can expect a broad parliamentary majority for our trialogue result. Second, it has shown once again that the verbal contributions of some colleagues are eloquent and interesting, but that they would be even more substantial if they had only dealt with the dossier once. In school one would have said in an essay in German: “Subject missed”. But sponge over it. It is important that we get something off the ground here tonight, which Europe and the banks that have to act with our regulations will transfer into a new world of accounting standards in a healthy, timely manner. This is important to maintain stability, and I am sure that if we continue in the same way with the further treatment of the CAD package, then we will be able to complete the very large package just as satisfactorily in the coming year.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- The creation of IFRS 9 standards is an important step to ensure that financial risks and losses are accounted for from the moment they are known and not only when they threaten to bankrupt the entire financial system.In this sense, opting for a late implementation of these rules means continuing to encourage financial speculation and easy credit, to the detriment of the health of the real economy.Once again, the European Union shows that it prefers to create the conditions for a new financial crisis than to intervene to put the banking system at the service of the general interest.We, on the contrary, will defend the popular classes against the looting of the financial lobby.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Arnaud Danjean, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 230 /2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, of March 11, 2014, establishing an instrument for stability and peace (COM (2016) 0447 - C8-0264 / 2016 - 2016/0207 (COD))(A8-0261 / 2017).

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: protractor. - Mr. President, I will not go back, at the beginning of this debate, to all the stages which led to our adopting, I hope, tomorrow this modification of the Instrument for Stability and Peace. I will simply recall that this is a process that started almost four years ago, since it was during the Council in December 2013 that the High Representative envisaged an instrument allowing the financing of equipment for armed forces with from which we have European Union missions that work on security and development. I would like to begin by thanking all of the coordinators and Members of Parliament who worked on this text. I would also like to thank our Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Mr McAllister, who led the trilogue negotiations, which were swift and successful. The Commission has, moreover, made very significant efforts to find funding that corresponds to Parliament's demands, and I really wanted to thank all the players in this very successful trialogue. To return to the substance of this instrument, I would recall that this is the missing link in European Union instruments in the field of security and development. Today we have missions with the armed forces in certain developing countries, missions which provide training, but which are not able, which do not have the legal, concrete, financial tools to provide equipment - which I would point out that they are non-lethal - civilian equipment that allows these armed forces to support development operations, because we are talking about countries in which no development is possible without the assistance of the armed forces: Mali, Somalia, Niger, the Central African Republic and many others unfortunately. I also wanted to recall that the The debates that we had were extremely rich and interesting, many points of view were expressed. For my part, I had a more ambitious vision for this instrument, it's no secret. We made a compromise, which I find well-made, and I wanted to thank the groups who participated. I also wanted to reiterate - because I always hear arguments - that we must not show bad faith. Firstly, this instrument is legally, financially and politically very framed. We cannot do whatever we want and do anything with this instrument. Second, this instrument is not used to finance arms purchases or deliveries. This is indeed equipment that is non-lethal. I still see and I still read in the press, in particular, arguments which are totally biased, which are totally incorrect. The European Union is not going to finance the purchase of weapons in developing countries, that is not what it is at all. We are talking about non-lethal equipment. I say this very solemnly, very firmly, because I do not want there to be the slightest doubt in this regard, and I would not have allowed the adoption of a text that would go in this direction. So we have a text which is balanced, which is strictly controlled, which is modest - it must be remembered: this is an important contribution in principle, but financially modest, we are talking about 100 million euros for three years. And we also have a contribution today which does not exhaust the debate to come, and I say this in particular for the groups which had reservations: yes, a more sustainable system will be needed in the future and that will be able to do subject to political debate in the coming deadlines. But for now, I think we can be satisfied with the tool that we have put in place and which will be very useful in concrete terms for the Union's missions European Union which are deployed in these sensitive countries.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Parliament, and notably the Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, David McAllister, and of course the rapporteur, Arnaud Danjean, as well as the other Members involved from the Foreign Affairs Committee and the Committee on Development. Our cooperation and your engagement over the past months on this important file were truly excellent. I also thank the Council and, in particular, the Estonian Presidency, for their efforts to reach a swift agreement in interinstitutional negotiations. EU assistance under capacity building in support of security and development (CBSD) will be a vital part of our collective efforts to ensure peace, stability, human security and sustainable development in our partner countries. If we want our development policies to be effective and our humanitarian aid to reach the people most in need, it is crucial that our partner countries have professional and well-trained security forces.  This has nothing to do with militarising development cooperation. On the contrary; we want to make sure that our development assistance does not fall into the wrong hands and that all security actors in our partner countries are trained to respect the highest human rights standards. This is also what our partners are asking for. For them, this is a way to protect and enable their economic growth, and it is a matter of autonomy to prevent or manage crises by themselves and take full responsibility for their own destinies.  CBSD respects the spirit and the objectives of the United Nation 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular its Goal 16 on just, peaceful and inclusive societies. To be eligible for EU funding, potential CBSD projects must have development as their main focus and be embedded within a wider security sector reform strategy. Each situation will be examined on a case-by-case basis to determine whether or not CBSD activity would be appropriate.  EU financial support will cover the performance of development in human security-related tasks, including by the military in exceptional and well defined circumstances. This could entail training, advice and technical cooperation, including the provision of equipment and infrastructure improvements. In terms of equipment, this may cover, for example, IT systems, protective gear, training-related facilities or health facilities.  We have clearly defined the purposes for which the EU funding will not be used, such as recurrent military expenditure, the procurement of equipment designed to deliver lethal force, or training that contributes specifically to the fighting capacities of the armed forces.  Overall, the European Union objective is to assist partner governments in providing their citizens with effective, legitimate and accountable security and justice services which are consistent with democratic norms, good governance and respect for human rights.  We will monitor CBSD measures closely and evaluate their impact, effectiveness and coherence with SDG 16. This will be done in association with civil society organisations, local authorities and, where appropriate, with Member States. Our ambition now must be to commence rapid implementation of the CBSD project, so as to assist partner countries in need of such support.  We look forward to informing you about CBSD implementation over the coming years and would like to thank you, once again, for our excellent collaboration in reaching this landmark agreement.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Danjean, on the report he has presented to us and above all for the speed and diligence with which he has worked. I believe that this area of ​​security is an area in which we must not sleep, and I also believe that it places this report in a very appropriate perspective, which is to constitute a first step in a more ambitious strategy in what is refers to strengthening the security and defense capacities of our partner countries. I also believe, Mr President, that it is important to distinguish to what extent we can insert development aid policy into security policy. This is an essential element of the European security strategy and it is an essential element also of the common strategy of the European Union, of the global strategy in everything that refers to conflicts and situations that reinforce our security. I believe that the objective - the Commissioner said it very well - is that the action of the European Union has a possibility of being exercised in a more flexible and efficient way and, above all, in a defined catalog of interventions, with a series of friendly countries, a series of limited conditions and I would also say, Mr. President, as the commissioner has explained to us, in an area in which weapons, ammunition and all lethal materials are excluded. I believe, Commissioner, that it is important that we remember that we are affected by global threats such as terrorism and extremism. Therefore, I understand that investing in everything that affects the security of our partners and our neighbors is also investing in the security of the European Union and in the security of all.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Tomorrow we will vote in plenary on the long and initially controversial expansion of the Instrument for Stability and Peace. The text is the result of good collaboration. Because for the regulation as it is now drafted, we have managed to bring the External Action Service, the Commission, the Council and the political groups together here in this House. I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur Danjean for the committed, compromise-ready and, above all, reliable cooperation, not only because it is rhetorically just as usual, even when things have crumbled. By changing this instrument, the EU is to be put in a position to also work with military actors in the security sector in partner countries. So far that was only possible with the police. And for this purpose, the instrument will be increased by around 100 million euros. If we want our efforts to endure in many countries, then we must also be ready to protect these partner countries' projects and follow-up facilities. In some cases, the military on site must be supported so that it can even do justice to this task. The expansion includes, for example, the provision of - as you have already correctly said - non-lethal equipment: protective vests, transport capacities, first aid equipment. In spite of everything, it is important that the financing of weapons and ammunition is expressly excluded. The key point for us was that the security measures are not funded from funds that have been allocated to aid and development. The first goal of development cooperation is poverty reduction, and military support - even if it is right in this context - must not divert resources from that goal. We have achieved that together There are paragraphs on transparency.It is important to us that the Commission monitors and evaluates the measures taken by the instrument and that the MEPs are regularly informed.The fact that we only achieved these two points after some resistance from the Council and part of the Commission shows how seriously we should take these two commandments in the future.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the instrument contributing to stability and peace is an important tool, as underlined by the European Commission, most recently in the form of the global strategy. Existing tools allow for direct financial support to be given by the EU to police forces, but there are gaps in its ability to make similar provision to other civilian security forces; forces that are often vital to ensuring peace and stability. It is these gaps that this revision hopes to plug. It is important to note that financing options will be limited to non-lethal weapons. So these changes are far removed from representing a move towards financing military hardware by the back door, as some critics have wrongly claimed. Indeed, one of the examples given as a potential use of this instrument would be for the EU mission in Mali for the purposes of financing a garrison of medical facilities. The emphasis is clearly very much based around the mantra of security as a precondition of successful development. And it is on this basis that I strongly support the excellent report by Mr Danjean.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! As a reminder of the previous speakers: The Instrument for Stability and Peace is an instrument for development, and it is shocking how easily scruples are brushed away in order to free up development aid funds for the training, maintenance and equipment of armies in third countries, money that is actually loud EU treaty should serve the clearly defined goal - I quote the treaty -: "The main goal of Union policy in this area is the fight and, in the longer term, the eradication of poverty." Using development aid for military purposes is an abuse. Unfortunately not completely new, but it is being operated more and more openly, previously rather hidden. For example, the African Peace Facility was used, now it should be business as usual, at the expense of civil conflict resolution approaches and development. Yes, development needs a safe and peaceful environment, but how do you do that with military training, arms exports and military cooperation? And it is not that we have no experience! Democratic Republic of the Congo, Somalia, Mali, Afghanistan, all countries in which nothing has improved despite EU aid for the military and security apparatus, on the contrary! The result: more insecurity and more poverty. And to make matters worse, we are talking about an instrument - I would ask you to consider that too - with the weakest budgetary control options compared to other instruments. I will close with the words of the President of Bread for the World on the transformation of this instrument. This is a peace and development policy declaration of bankruptcy. The EU started as a peace project and is now focusing its foreign policy more and more on the military dimension.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - We Greens do not feel that with this proposal we get any guarantees at all that this will not be a militarization of the only instrument we have for civilian conflict prevention measures - rather that we turn it into an instrument for military capacity building operations in other countries. So far, the idea has been that the efforts made via the instrument should be compatible with the DAC regulations and we believe that it should continue to be so. Especially since we are at a time when more and more policy areas are trying to benefit from funds intended for civilian operations in third countries and paid for by development aid. It is important that we ensure that development assistance funds are used in accordance with the regulations and are not diverted to anything else. The legal basis for the Instrument for Peace and Stability is Articles 2009 and 2012 on aid and technical cooperation. According to the Council's own legal statements of 29 July 2016, the proposed change has security as its main purpose and can therefore not be the basis for the proposal. Nothing has changed since then and we believe that the proposal is not compatible with the Treaty and should therefore not be adopted. The problem for us is not that EU countries assist with capacity-building efforts in third countries. The problem is that initiatives that, according to the regulations, burden the Member States' national budgets are instead proposed to receive EU funding taken from other important areas. According to the EU Treaty, EU funds cannot be used for military purposes. Nothing prevents Member States from investing in military capacity building in third countries, but then they must also be prepared to invest in it, instead of taking away the important civilian efforts. So even if the rapporteur has succeeded in getting a joint statement that funds should not be taken from an aid budget, and this will not happen in 2018, a number of other areas in need of increased budget cuts, such as the neighborhood policy, may have foreign police operations and the buffer for disasters.What the development assistance fund was intended to pay for must be taken from elsewhere and it is unclear where.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, some perplexities, indeed considerable ones, arouse the consideration that this provision, in fact, objectively dismantles the instrument created in 2014 for stability aimed at combating drug trafficking, demining, support for displaced persons, crisis management , rehabilitation and reconstruction of war theaters. This was the rationale of the old provision. Now you want to change it structurally, to do what? Financing the military of partner countries, that is, equipping the security forces of these countries, as - it says - without this intervention it would be difficult to achieve concrete, lasting and constant results in terms of training for the benefit of these armies. I seem to read the reason clearly in a passage of the provision, in which it is said that the economic effort to support the armies must be strengthened, because we are faced with a growing commitment from Russia, China and Turkey. Why isn't it clearly stated that this is all a different thing than the provision being emptied? Because you don't have the courage to speak clearly about these things. So enough with this hypocrisy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the basic precondition for stability and peace in a state and an organization is security. This principle also applies to the European Union. At present, the European Union does not face a total threat to its security and integrity from a large and powerful enemy, in order to justify an increase in its military capabilities. But it faces smaller-scale threats such as international terrorism, organized crime and cyber-attacks. Dealing with these threats requires reasonable funding. Military missions undertaken by the European Union in the context of peace and humanitarian operations must also be financially supported. In addition, the governments of friendly third countries must be funded in order to strengthen their security forces, equip them with non-lethal materials and train them. If the funding remains within the framework of 100 million euros, it is estimated that this will not affect the ability of the European Union to financially support the countries in need, especially the Greece damaged by the memoranda. Finally, if NGOs known for their corruption are not involved in the mechanism, we could support the report.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Mister President! I would like to thank Mr Danjean and everyone who worked on this compromise, because it is a necessary step that we are taking here now. We are expanding the Instrument for Stability and Peace to include these aspects of capacity building for security and development. We have to realize that there is this direct link between development and security, and security comes first, so that safe development can take place. From my point of view, it must be made clear, especially to the critics, including my critics in my own Protestant church, I would like to say clearly: The global strategy of the European Union formulates an ethical policy. This is not only morally justifiable, it is on morally high ground, as the English would say. One of the instruments that we need for implementation in this specific case is this capacity building for security and development. We have a situation where we do not use development funds. This budget has been increased by 100 million euros so that this very claim cannot be upheld. I do not need to repeat what has been said by both Arnaud Danjean and the Commissioner, what it can be expressly used for and what it expressly cannot be used for. Anyone who continues to claim that this is used to finance arms purchases is dumbing down the public, and that is not proper.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, in some cases security really is an important element for sustainable development. The proposal we will vote on tomorrow is a pilot project. It will have to prove in the next few years that it is efficient and functions properly. We must check that the main principles cause no harm. That is why EU assistance should be used to build the capacity of military actors and partner countries only under exceptional circumstances. These exceptional circumstances require that military actors should only receive financing when development goals cannot be achieved by non-military actors and when state institutions are at risk of collapse. There must also be a consensus among the international community. This may take the form of a UN Security Council resolution or a programming document agreed between the Union and other international partners as, for example, as it was with the case of Somalia. To be successful this pilot project should be properly restricted, transparent, controlled by the European Parliament and not financed from funds for the development cooperation instrument. I ask you to vote in favour tomorrow.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: - On the day of the EU-Africa summit, we recognize the enormous threats to security on the African continent.The planned changes to the instrument are to support our impact, counteracting these threats, and cooperation with organizations such as the African Union.As legislators, however, we must remember that we operate in an extremely sensitive legislative environment with many treaty restrictions.We must also remember that there is a need for a balanced perception of threats, both in our southern and eastern neighborhood, and the search for solutions that will have a similar impact on mitigating threats.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, this proposal has the merit of seeking to strengthen the link that the European security strategy established in 2003 between security and development. The security of a country is indeed a necessary condition for its development. Charles Péguy already said: "order, and order alone, makes freedom". Clearly, the proposal aims to allow the European Union to support the military forces of developing countries. At a time when Islamist terrorism is destabilizing many countries, especially in Africa, this initiative may at first appear relevant, but you have to be clear-headed and know what you want. This proposal is part of a strategy aimed at extending the European Union’s grip on the foreign and defense policies of its member states. However, I believe that foreign affairs and national defense must continue to be the sovereignty of states. This is a question of principle, especially for France, which remains a great diplomatic and military power. But it is also wisdom, because the Union lacks realism. It has already failed to stop immigration from Libya, so much so that Italy had to take its place in order to resolve the problem through a bilateral agreement. Moreover, it gives moral lessons to the whole world and we will quickly see that its moralism will cause the failure of its intervention policy. History teaches us that empires always end badly.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Mr President, I thank the rapporteur, Arnaud Danjean, for his excellent report.The European Union must recognize the upcoming security and defense threats in the partner countries as an important factor in the global order and intervene in a timely manner.In addition to supporting available assistance instruments, a credible European Union involvement in conflict resolution is needed.Arnaud knows that very well.The European Union must not allow the mistakes of the past and stand aside and wait for conflicts to be resolved by someone else if it intends to maintain its position as a global leader.We have an example when an embargo was imposed on the import of weapons and self-defense of Croats in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina through the United Nations, and today their self-defense in Bosnia and Herzegovina has been declared a joint criminal enterprise.What have we learned over the years?My condolences to the family of General Praljak.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mister President! I am glad that, with the help of the European Social Democrats and the European People's Party, I pushed through my two amendments to the Commission and the Council: first, that no money from the EU budget may be used for development cooperation to expand the peace and stability instrument; that the Commission undertakes to thoroughly evaluate military equipment projects. But that doesn't stop the work. With a view to the next multiannual financial framework from 2021, a new European financial instrument must be developed to promote security policy goals in partner countries. The mandatory evaluation forms an important basis for this. From my perspective, Europe needs a wide range of instruments, from humanitarian aid to development cooperation to security and defense policy. However, the dovetailing of development policy and security policy must not come at the expense of development work. Many thanks to everyone who contributed to this compromise, including on the part of the Commission.

name: Soraya POST
text: - Mr President, I will speak in Swedish. Tomorrow we will vote on an instrument for stability and peace, but the text is about how the EU should build a common defense. As a feminist and pacifist, I must express my despair that the EU's response to how we should build stability and peace is more weapons and military. The most destructive patriarchal expression of violence is seen in the patriarchal security policy, militarism, which wants men with military means to defend the nation and its women and children. This is an outdated patriarchal policy. We must change the EU's and the world's security policy agenda to be based on creating human security - that every human being has the right to live a life of security, every day, every moment. The instrument we have in front of us will not create peace and stability, it will only create more violence and insecurity. I will vote against more military and call on all feminists and pacifists in the European Parliament to do the same.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I thank the rapporteur Danjean for respecting our group and for the good cooperation. The result is a good text of clear guidelines that retains the original Commission proposal with amendments. This instrument is welcome, and its implementation can provide either short-term assistance, for example to countries in crisis, or long-term support, in particular to mitigate various risks, address global and acute threats and build capacity for sustainable social and economic development. The instrument should be complementary to other possibilities of the European Union, primarily development. He is happy to accept the proposal to ensure full transparency of the funds spent, which has caused a lot of doubts from the beginning. Clearly, development without security is not possible, but equally security without development is not enough. This is not about substituting development goals for security. On the contrary, it is about focusing on the importance of supporting national security institutions in fragile or conflicting states. The intention of this instrument is to more effectively link development and security, which this report reflects very well.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Mister President! I am not giving away a secret when I say that we already had concerns when we voted on the trialogue negotiations on the Instrument for Stability and Peace - concerns based on legal opinion. Above all, we wanted to clarify whether the instrument is compatible with the objectives of the common foreign and security policy, and more specifically with Article 40. However, we are clear: development aid is of no use if it does not arrive effectively in the recipient countries due to a tense security situation. So we have to debate how security can be achieved for effective and sustainable development aid. The compromise found reflects the willingness to view the instrument as a foreign policy instrument of the European Union. That is expressly to be welcomed. Overall, I am of the opinion that when it comes to global peace and security, a real common foreign and security policy of the European Union is essential. Challenges we face require a Europe that speaks with one voice. From a foreign policy perspective, the EU must not get stuck in its payer role, but must become a self-confident player. Only in this way can it contribute to stability in the world.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, I would also like to begin by congratulating Mr Arnaud Danjean on the work that he has done, of great seriousness, which has led to broad membership in the AFET Committee and which is also the expression of the broad parliamentary support that this proposal will certainly generate. This instrument is an absolutely fundamental instrument, for a very simple reason: we cannot oppose the concept of security and the concept of development. If there are no minimum levels of security, it is impossible to create the conditions that can provide the development of any country, any region in the world. And we have very recent historical experiences in which this was very clear. What is more, development aid, provided by the European Union, will suffer if the regions to which that aid is destined are not in the least decent security conditions and, therefore, the mistake that some make is the mistake of wanting to oppose idea of ​​development to the idea of ​​security, when they have to be absolutely associated. This instrument is a vital instrument for this to happen. Some problems that, at the beginning, were related to this proposal, were fortunately overcome by means of a wide and participative debate and I am therefore convinced that the conditions are now created for a very beneficial instrument to emerge, both for the peoples Europeans, or for the people of our partner countries.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I am ready to support this proposal. I am convinced that this is another preventive tool that can reduce the danger of international tensions and, in the future, help to ensure that we do not see another refugee crisis. It is precisely such preventive measures that are stabilizing the situation in some high-risk countries, especially in Africa, that we should take. Prevention is more important than dealing with the consequences. I very much welcomed the fact that my colleagues and the Commissioner have assured us that the money cannot be used directly to buy weapons or to buy tools that endanger life and health. The examples that could be addressed in this way, such as the issue of medical equipment in Mali, confirm to me that this tool is the right one. I am ready to support this instrument tomorrow, and I think it is good that this is increasing our activity in the world, especially in countries where stability, peace and security are just a theoretical matter.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, as is well known, the European Union budget excludes activities aimed at financing the defense and military sectors in third countries. With this report, the Commission and the majority - from what I see here - of colleagues are trying to make a bypass, to extend the mechanism for contributing to stability and peace, so that it includes the development of military capabilities, the use of development aid for military purposes, to pay for equipment and training of armed forces in third countries, to substantially strengthen the defense industry and, in particular, to infringe Article 41 (2) of the Treaty on European Union, which prohibits the use of the Union budget for expenditure - as I explained earlier- military. Beyond that, we believe that growth should be mainly supported. Only in this way can poverty be overcome and cease to be a fertilizer for the development of jihadism.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, first of all, much of what is being said today creates the impression that we live in a parallel universe that has nothing to do with reality. Parliament fails to realize that the European Union, as an organization, has little to no weight in the field of international diplomacy and geopolitics. Only two Member States really have some power internationally; Great Britain and France. Of these two countries, one soon leaves the Union, while the other has chosen to limit itself, accepting the role of Germany's follower, who has almost no influence in countries outside the Union, but is rather clumsy in diplomacy issues. Moreover, when almost no country, except Greece, fulfills the commitment made by all within NATO to defense spending, how exactly do they expect to support security, stability and peace worldwide? This, of course, begs the question: who gave the Union the right to impose security on third countries and to fund anyone who serves its interests each time? Finally, the Commission 's view on the use of non - governmental organizations as a means of promotion shows the inability to perceive and, in addition, emits a strong sense of entanglement.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! If the European Union really wants to contribute to stability and peace in third countries, it will inevitably include a contribution to law enforcement and military capacity-building. In African countries with weak central power, the success of any development program is in jeopardy as long as the host state does not have the strength to organize and defend these actions. Of course, there are understandable concerns about the funding of security structures, but we must also see that, in the meantime, other non-EU states are less sensitive and strongly support the expansion of military capabilities in Africa. If Europe wants partners in Africa and functioning state structures, law enforcement cooperation cannot be ruled out alongside development aid. I think it is a huge naiveté to take the position that we can still save this. And if there are dysfunctional states on the African continent, it carries unpredictable security risks for Europe.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Danjean once again on his excellent report, and of course, I have to say that this fruitful discussion and debate is quite important for us in the Commission and that your support in this file is very encouraging for us.  Our world is becoming more and more complex. Traditional development policies are not always as effective as we would like them to be. We, the European Union, want to put all our tools at the service of sustainable development. We are a great civilian power and at the same time, a security provider.  We are the leading humanitarian donor, and the largest foreign investor for most countries in the world. We work with governments and with NGOs alike. This is the European way to development, and I strongly believe that with CBSD we have set up a new tool to promote sustainable development and human security worldwide, while pursuing a fully integrated approach to security sector reform.  Let me conclude by underlining that the Commission will ensure that all CBSD provisions are fully respected, particularly the exclusion criteria, so that any support to the military is solely in pursuit of development objectives. We completely agree with the rapporteur on this very important issue, and we look forward to continuing our excellent work with Parliament and with all of you, its Members, and keeping all of you informed about progress.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you to all the colleagues who took part in this debate, of course, but also to those who intervened during the preparation of this text to enrich it and to make it a compromise, I believe, quite virtuous and useful. To those who oppose this text, I would like to say that I obviously respect all opinions and oppositions, they still have to be in good faith and that they really be based on what there is in the text and on the reality we are working on. Nowhere in the text does it say that we are going to finance military equipment. We will finance civilian equipment for military forces. The reality is that we are going to fund hospitals and we are going to fund communication systems. Are these military equipment? Obviously no! Is it also useful for civilian populations? Obviously yes! This is what we are talking about. I would like the many colleagues who have spoken out against the text to read it, first, to see what is and what is not in it, and to know a little about the reality of country we are talking about. In Mali, when you have a European Union mission which trains Malian soldiers, but which cannot provide them with equipment - the Malian army loses one soldier per day or per week - to treat these soldiers, believe me. you that it participates in the militarization of development? Frankly, it’s not fair to say that. This is not honest and it is not correct for the reality we are talking about. I hear colleagues say: "We are going to militarize development aid through this instrument". But what are we talking about? It should be remembered that development aid, the EDF, amounts to 31 billion euros. The instrument we are talking about is 100 million euros. Who can speak of the militarization of development with this instrument which does not even allow not buy lethal materials and weapons?Once again, I believe that we have reached a very strict compromise, very legally framed and very politically binding.I thank all the colleagues who took part in it and I would like the colleagues who continue to oppose it for ideological reasons to show a little more pragmatism and realism to really see the needs that we are meeting with this instrument..

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- We face a number of security challenges today, and these challenges know no borders, do not stop at the EU's external borders.That is why I believe that the European Union must play a greater role in security policy in the region, as well as at global level.For this reason, I support more intensive funding for the training of security forces in partner countries, as well as the provision of non-lethal equipment.When allocating grants, attention must be paid to the fact that they also contribute to the strategic and security policy goals set by the EU.These investments can contribute to maintaining global and regional peace and stability in the future.Thank you for listening!

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - I consider it important that the EU always uses its public funds prudently, even when it comes to spending funds outside the EU. It is precisely this aspect that is emphasized in the text adopted, as supporting the activities of other countries' defense forces is always a far-reaching decision. That is why it is good that money cannot be used for current military spending in other countries. I also consider it important that the efficiency of spending is assessed, as we must not have additional administrative structures or spending machines. At this stage, it is too early to comment on the operation of the instrument in the next multiannual financial period, but with the British resignation from the EU, I consider it justified that all activities be critically examined so as not to impose additional burdens on net EU contributors such as Finland. I would like to believe that the operation of the instrument will contribute to the objectives that have been set for it and I will follow future developments with interest.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - The Instrument Contributing to Stability and Peace (IcSP) has been in place since 2014, and since then we have had a lot of information that it really helps to solve problems in places of conflict. IcSP is used as a solution in urgent situations where other programs are not immediately able to provide financial assistance. A budget of around € 2.3 billion has been approved for 2014-2020, and more than 70% of resources go to short-term assistance, which is a maximum of 18 months, with the possibility of an extension for another 18 months. This instrument subsidizes 281 projects in 70 countries around the world, making it one of the EU's key external assistance instruments to support prevention and response projects for real or emerging crises around the world. As an example, I can cite projects addressing the refugee crisis. I was recently in Turkey, an area where Syrian refugees are integrated. I must say that these efforts are going well, and I am glad that the EU is also contributing to this through this IcSP. The amendment that we are now approving brings a very significant change - the possibility of financing the security apparatus in third countries. Given the security threats we face not only in the EU's neighborhood, this is more than desirable.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament and the Council jointly prepared a proposal to amend Regulation No 230/2014 of 11 March 2014 establishing an Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace (Capacity Building in Security and Development). The amended regulation introduces, in specific cases, additional safeguards in order to strengthen the military capabilities in the Member States to maintain the peaceful and sustainable development of society and the state. The proposal aims to increase Community support to better protect and develop partner countries. This program is one of the deliverables of the European Commission work on defense in December 2013. More extensive EU involvement could support activities such as training, mentoring, counseling, the provision of safe materials, infrastructure facilities and other services. The proposed regulation aimed to involve partner countries in preventive actions, as well as in providing advice on how to deal with the emerging crisis without interference from neighboring countries. At the same time, the established instruments would improve cooperation between EU countries and partner countries in the area of ​​joint military defense, as well as guarantee the protection of the rule of law, the rule of law and enhanced civil surveillance. The planned budget assumes expenditure of around EUR 100 million for the period 2017-2020, funds for this purpose are to be transferred from the fourth column of the main budget. We must remember that only by supporting each other will we be able to maintain the peace.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate based on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Yemen (2017/2849 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, forgive me if I skip the introductions and go straight to the point. The war in Yemen must end. In times of dire humanitarian crisis world-wide, from Syria to Myanmar, Yemen still continues to be the worst of all. And the situation, unfortunately, is getting worse. The current escalation is undermining the prospects of a political settlement, which is the only sustainable solution. We immediately condemned the launch of a missile targeting Riyadh, and we understand Saudi Arabia’s security concerns. At the same time, the new measures taken by the coalition are having a severe impact on the delivery of life-saving assistance. Commercial goods cannot enter the areas beyond government control. Most Yemenis no longer have the means to get food or fuel. This escalation has worsened an already dire humanitarian situation. Today 19 million people are severely affected by the conflict – 19 million people! More than 7 million are on the verge of famine. Yemen is also facing the largest cholera outbreak in living memory. Almost one million suspected cases and more than 2 000 deaths from cholera have been recorded. The numbers are shocking. It has become almost impossible for aid agencies to provide the necessary assistance to the people in need. Despite international pressure and condemnation, international humanitarian law continues to be disregarded. Markets, hospitals, clinics, schools, factories and hundreds of private residences have been hit by air strikes. Densely populated cities continue to be under siege. This war is not only causing mass starvation in Yemen. It is also creating a war economy that benefits only the smugglers and traffickers. All kinds of illegal traffickers, including those involved in arms trafficking, find their way into the country via well-established irregular routes. And beyond the humanitarian tragedy, the security situation is also getting worse. The recent missile attack directed at Riyadh shows that three years of war have made Saudi Arabia, together with the whole region, less secure. Meanwhile, al-Qa’ida and Daesh have found fertile ground in the southeast of the country, precisely at the moment when they have been forced out of Iraq and Syria. This is all happening a few miles from one of the busiest maritime corridors in the world, on the route connecting the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean. More than 10% of global trade transits through this corridor. At a time of rising tensions in the Middle East, we cannot afford the risk of a larger conflict. That would be an even greater tragedy, not only for the region but also for the world. It is a global threat. This is the situation we face, and we, the European Union, are on the front line of the world to address both the humanitarian and the political crisis. Firstly, we are doing everything we can to address humanitarian needs. We have privately and publicly called for access to be granted to humanitarian workers. I went myself to Riyadh last month, together with the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), to discuss ways to improve humanitarian aid delivery in Yemen. Our humanitarian advocacy was intensified with the adoption of common humanitarian messages in 2017. Foreign Affairs Council conclusions on Yemen were adopted in April this year. Two diplomatic démarches, on access and delivery of humanitarian relief, were delivered to all the parties to the conflict, in March and in August. We are, again, among the top humanitarian donors. The UN Human Rights Council decided in September to establish an international group of experts to examine alleged violations of human rights and international law. We fully support this initiative to guarantee accountability and prevent new abuses. My second point is that humanitarian aid is crucial but it is not enough. As we have said many times, unfortunately, for humanitarian problems we need political solutions. The people of Yemen cannot wait to get sanitation or electricity. There are a number of early recovery projects that can be started right now, even before a final settlement is agreed upon. We are already working with our partners on health, nutrition and local development programmes. Such early recovery can also provide us with some extra leverage to push for peace and conciliation. Thirdly, and maybe the most important point, the European Union is working intensively to help find a political solution to the crisis. We are urging the whole international community to work towards a resumption of the political track. We are encouraging the parties to reach a political solution under UN auspices. We have engaged directly with all parties to build confidence through informal initiatives, particularly at local level. In coordination with the UN Special Envoy and his team, we have explored the possibility of local ceasefires based on mutual trust. This would also lay the groundwork for a resumption of peace talks. We urgently need to revive peace negotiations. Every day, the humanitarian situation gets worse, the security situation also gets worse and a political solution becomes more difficult to achieve. Along with Federica Mogherini, the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs, we are using all possible channels to restart the political track. We are sure that we can also count on Parliament’s support to bring this tragedy an end. And what we are talking about here is a tragedy, with many tragic aspects.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I can only agree with the Commissioner’s statement. Yemen has become a key battlefield for the Iranian-Saudi Arabian regional conflict. The country is now fragmented and is experiencing the worst humanitarian crisis in the world today, but the immediate victims are the people of Yemen. Systematic destruction of infrastructure, civilian targets and the blocking of ports have resulted in a truly catastrophic situation where two thirds, or 28 million, of the population are suffering from dramatic shortages of food and water. In fact, starvation and diseases have become a much greater killer than the war itself. Just one fact: it is estimated that 130 children die each day from famine. I am glad that the Commission and Parliament are united in condemning indiscriminate airstrikes against civilians. We also condemned the launching by Houthi rebels of Iranian-provided missiles against Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The situation has become really explosive, as the conflict is spilling over the borders of Yemen. The key priority today is to allow UN relief ships to enter the ports and provide immediate aid to those who are in need. Yes, two days ago, something happened; one port and Sanaa Airport were reopened, but it is far from being enough.  The EU and international actors must work together to bring the main opponents to negotiations. The EU needs an urgent and integrated strategy for Yemen, accompanied by a new push for a Yemen peace initiative under the auspices of the UN. Today, there can be no more excuses for delaying united international action to end this human and political disaster.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I will just add my voice to that of my colleague, Tunne Kelam, and to the Commissioner’s statement because, indeed, in Yemen, one of the poorest countries in the world, war and famine continue in all impunity.  Civilians die under the bombs of one of the richest countries in the world – Saudi Arabia – a country to which we continue to sell arms and offer support. The other side of the story is that while we are turning a blind eye and while some are shamefully choosing sides, Saudi Arabia and Iran are turning Yemen into chaos and misery. This is a terrible man—made disaster and it is mostly the result of a wider conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia. I am therefore very worried about the rising tensions and the way this could further affect the whole Middle East region and beyond.  It is difficult to describe the human tragedy going on in Yemen, with famine, malnutrition, a cholera outbreak and death. It is, as many will say today, the worst humanitarian crisis in the world. The Commissioner repeatedly mentioned that this is the worst humanitarian crisis known in the world. Yemen is highly dependent on food imports. The Saudi-led coalition has blocked much of the country’s air, sea and land ports, thus there is no access for the desperately-needed humanitarian aid, medicines, assistance and so on. I am adding my voice today to those calling for an immediate and total lift of the blockade and a return to the negotiating table.  Impunity cannot be accepted, neither in Yemen nor in any other place. The many war crimes perpetrated in this conflict have to be investigated and prosecuted. On Monday, a complaint was submitted to the International Criminal Court on this matter and I can only hope an investigation will be launched soon.  Finally, it is imperative to put an end to this conflict, but it is also imperative to realise that long-term aid alone cannot address the full needs of 28 million people. Yemenis need a sustainable solution for development in agriculture, to fund and address their existential needs and give them a chance to live in peace. This is the comprehensive answer they need and it is our duty to help, together with other international actors, find a solution to the worst tragedy known in the history of mankind.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I too remain deeply concerned about the large and unacceptable levels of civilian deaths allegedly due to the poor targeting or even indiscriminate targeting of civilian areas by the Saudi-led coalition in this tragic conflict – actions that must be condemned in the strongest terms. Continued attacks on Saudi territory by the Houthi rebels too, however, cannot be tolerated and its recent targeting of Riyadh’s International Airport in a missile attack points to the escalating nature of this conflict. Credible reports that the missile was supplied by Iran further illustrate the complications.  Meanwhile, the people of Yemen are suffering from the largest humanitarian crisis in recent times. The Saudi-led naval blockade is leading to unacceptable food and medical supply shortages. Poor sanitary conditions have also led to a tragic cholera outbreak of epidemic proportions as the number of cases is set to reach one million by the close of this year, only a few months after the first reported case.  I therefore echo calls for the EU and Member States to continue their support for the efforts of Ismail Ahmed in trying to negotiate a peace in his role as UN Special Envoy. This tragedy must stop, and all war crimes must be investigated and all those brought to justice.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the war in Yemen is leading to unprecedented humanitarian suffering. Let there be no mistake; these problems and this suffering are man—made. The most respected international organisations are crystal clear. I quote: ‘The largest food security emergency in the world’, says the UN Food and Agriculture Organization; ‘130 children dying every day’, Save the Children; ‘Half of all health facilities closed due to damage, destruction or lack of funds’, World Health Organization; and ‘Nearly 900 000 cases of cholera’, Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).  There are 20.7 million Yemenis who require assistance and, as if that is not cruel enough and bad enough, the Saudi-led coalition, as well as rebels, are blocking land, air and sea borders and access for lifesaving deliveries to people in need. Even if some of these blockades are lifted now, this in no way compensates for the devastating choice of blocking in the first place. Aid should never become a weapon of war.  Conventional weapons of war, including cluster bombs, have been used and are causing civilian deaths on top of the indiscriminate airstrikes that continue to kill. We call for an urgent end to the violence and urge the High Representative to come up with an EU strategy towards Yemen. Key elements of such an EU strategy should be: to engage the Saudi and Iranian sides, to engage in ending the violence and to support the UN-led negotiations. Of course, airstrikes and the killing of civilians should stop, as well as all blockades, so that lifesaving aid can continue to reach people.  We also should have EU funding for accountability mechanisms that must hold violators of international law and those who commit crimes against humanity to account. For the third time now, we in Parliament call for an EU-wide weapons embargo on Saudi Arabia. The Houthi rebels are already under an embargo.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, after more than two years of the forgotten conflict in Yemen, with more than 50,000 civilians killed, wounded or maimed, the worst famine in the world and a terrible cholera epidemic, the situation has reached a critical point with the escalation of tensions in the area. Saudi Arabia strengthens its bombings and its blockade against the Yemeni people. Even if I partially lift it, the suffering of the Yemeni people continues: 130 Yemeni children die every day; two million boys and girls have had to leave their schools; meanwhile, the Daesh expands and multiplies its attacks; and Trump adds fuel to the fire by supporting the aggressions of Saudi Arabia, while multiplying his extrajudicial executions with drones in Yemen. We are not facing a humanitarian crisis caused by a natural catastrophe but by a war, and the solution to war is not more war. Commissioner, I really appreciate her presence, but the one who should be here today in this debate is the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mrs Mogherini. Sixteen Member States of the Union, led by the United Kingdom, Spain - my country, France, Italy and Germany - continue to sell arms to Saudi Arabia. My country, Spain, has recognized a sale worth 1,383 million euros in the last five years. All this encouraged by the well-known and close relationship between the Saudi and Spanish royal families. These European states violate international humanitarian law and are not only accomplices, but necessary collaborators in this massacre. In order to really stop this massacre, the European Union must apply the Resolution already approved by this Parliament, which I hope we will approve again tomorrow, to immediately impose an embargo on the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! It is a scandal that EU member states continue to support the war in Yemen by exporting arms to the conflicting parties. The European Parliament took a clear position in February 2016 and called for an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia. That position will also be confirmed in tomorrow's resolution. Nevertheless, numerous EU states - including Great Britain, France and Germany - continue to supply weapons to the Gulf state. That must end. Those who deliver weapons to warring parties are complicit. I urge the High Representative to finally implement what this Parliament has called on her several times, namely to launch an initiative to impose an EU arms embargo on Saudi Arabia. We expect Mrs Mogherini, as Chair of the Council of Foreign Ministers, to formally put the embargo on the agenda of the next meeting. Thousands of civilians have already been killed by military operations in this war. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in particular are accused of massive violations of international law. Crimes committed in this war must be solved and those responsible must be brought to justice. That is why we support extensive investigations, as requested by the United Nations Human Rights Council. The humanitarian catastrophe in Yemen is worsening dramatically: Millions of people are threatened with hunger and cholera is spreading. Saudi Arabia and its allies must immediately lift all blockades on ports and airports. Against this background, I also appeal to the executive federal government in Berlin not to deliver any further patrol boats to Saudi Arabia. Exactly these boats can be used to block ports and use hunger as a weapon against the population.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Yemen a child dies every ten minutes. An unacceptable humanitarian catastrophe, the result of a bloody, barbaric and petty proxy war. Yes, mean. How petty is the blockade imposed by Riyadh on the country's ports and airports, because its dire consequences, as always, are paid by the civilians. Every day, families have to choose whether to buy clean water or bread, because they can't afford both, not anymore. I strongly condemn the launch of the missile by the Houthi rebels, but I also stress that the usual hypocritical asymmetry is under the eyes of all: on the one hand the Houthis, rightly subjected to an arms embargo for more than two years, and on the other Saudi Arabia and our Member States which, despite the continuous, repeated and insistent requests of this Parliament, of our Parliament, continue to export and allow the use of European armaments in Yemen, and beyond. My country, Italy, unfortunately figures among the merchants of death. The photos of Premier Gentiloni in Riyadh testify all too well the commitment to support this bloody business, in spite of the common position on arms exports, now reduced to a farce. Our Member States are complicit, this is the truth, and for the umpteenth time I appeal to the High Representative to propose and demand an immediate arms embargo on Riyadh. It is not only our appeal, it is the desperate appeal of the Yemeni people, while a diabolical negotiation stall is consumed, while his children, his children, continue to die, one every ten minutes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! The civil war in Yemen - a humanitarian catastrophe - has now lasted almost six years, with over a hundred children dying every day, two million children are malnourished, there is hardly any clean drinking water and one million are infected with cholera. It is a proxy war between the Saudis, supported by the US, on the one hand, and the rebels, supported by the Shiites, on the other - all at the back of the population. The resolutions in this House were correct, but of course there is still a lot to be done, a great deal of effort still needs to be made, such as stopping arms deliveries, including those to the Saudis, which are also being carried out by European states, at the end of the year Area bombing, resumption of negotiations and, above all, the opening of the ports blocked by the Saudis. I already know that it is easier to bring ex-Yugoslav generals to court martial than members of the Saudi royal family.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mister President! Commissioner, you were right to point out that hospitals, schools and houses are being bombed, destroyed in air strikes, women and children are being killed, this is what is known as collateral damage. But who has planes in this war, who can bomb? They're not the Houthi rebels, are they? The Houthi rebels, who once fought against political persecution, against disregard by a Sunni majority. These Houthi rebels are placed under an arms embargo by the United Nations, while on the other hand the Sunni majority is supported by Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, the USA, Great Britain, Jordan, Morocco, Pakistan and Al-Qaeda. Why don't you decide to take action against these states, as here in this House? Why are we not doing anything against Great Britain, which is still a member of our EU and is taking a leading role in these bombing attacks? The EU's sanctions and measures are not far-reaching enough. They must be directed against everyone!

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr. President, we discussed the situation in Yemen a few months ago and since then there has been no improvement, quite the contrary. The situation has worsened sharply in recent weeks due to the sea and land blockade, which has only left the civilian population in disarray. Beyond the humanitarian situation, the prolongation of this war is synonymous with the collapse of all state institutions. The two small glimmers of hope we can hold on to are the partial lifting of the blockade, which has allowed part of the humanitarian aid to be delivered, and the organization of talks in London in the presence of the United Nations. What role can the European Union play? First of all, I would say that we must support a total lifting of the blockade, with the definitive reopening of ports and airports, to ensure access for humanitarian aid and trade and, indeed, to get the civilian population out. of isolation. This reopening must be done while ensuring that the security conditions are met because we cannot tolerate missiles being launched at neighboring countries. Second, the European Union can and should - in my opinion - play a diplomatic role. We can no longer afford to be just a humanitarian actor. The negotiations have stalled, while the European Union is a credible interlocutor in the eyes of all parties involved in the conflict. In summary, we must focus on three points that I consider essential: an immediate ceasefire, a realistic peace plan, under the aegis of the United Nations, and, finally, support for state institutions in order to leave no room for a security vacuum once peace has been restored. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to put a question to my esteemed colleague, Mr Preda, who, as you know, has a special instinct when intervening somewhere, especially on the part of Russia.So I would be interested to know whether he is aware that almost all weapons from the United States or Europe are delivered to Saudi Arabia, and whether he has information or can give me information as to whether Russia is also involved in this entire conflictbe it through arms deliveries or through personal support.I would be very happy, Mr Preda, if you could give me the answer.You are sure to be well informed.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" response.- Mr. Obermayr, to my knowledge, 17 member countries of the Union sell weapons.I don’t know how heavy the Russian arms industry is because I don’t have any figures at hand, but I would be grateful if you had those figures, if you could give them to us.In any case, since you mentioned the question of Russia, I certainly hope that the conflict in Yemen will not be resolved as it is happening in Syria, namely without the participation of the Arabs.What is happening now with the conflict in Syria is that the Russians, Turks and Iranians will make an arrangement from which Europeans and Arabs will be excluded.In my opinion, Europeans and Arabs must get involved in both resolving the conflict in Syria and resolving the conflict in Yemen.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this debate leads us to talk about Yemen and highlights several situations that have been mentioned here by the Commissioner: the humanitarian crisis, the worst in recent times, the security crisis, the conflict that brings a food emergency. I would like to remind you that Yemen is one of the four countries that are experiencing famine and hunger. Here, I would like to focus on another point, which you stressed, Commissioner, that of having highlighted the situation of human rights, respect for which must remain at the heart of our concerns. First of all, I express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims of the conflict which continues to sow death and desolation inside Yemen. The hold and role of Saudi Arabia on Yemen is well known, but we know that, due to this conflict, we have a Yemeni population with significant loss of life, as well as a situation of extreme suffering for those who remain alive, especially women and children. We have had the opportunity to denounce the fact that an important segment of the population cannot even access humanitarian aid, even if only to be able to use basic necessities. This situation has already deserved the attention of the European Union and in fact the Commissioner reminded us that the European Union is the first donor in terms of humanitarian aid and, above all, thank you for having supported the monitoring. violation of human rights. We have had the attention of the United Nations, the Arab League and also several international organizations. The United Nations has recommended that everything be done to bring about a resumption of negotiations, because only negotiations can guarantee a lasting resolution of the conflict and lead to peace. We need a dialogue between the various parties involved, leading to a political solution inclusive, involving all actors in the Middle East area, including Yemen itself.In addition to the Yemeni population, trapped in the internal war, I would also like to highlight the situation of the Yemeni refugees in Djibouti.There is talk of over 4 000 people in a small country like Djibouti, which already welcomes 20 000. I therefore ask for more humanitarian aid to refugees from Yemen and for steps to be taken to strengthen their security.Finally, I call on the United Nations and the European Union to intensify the resettlement program of these people - asylum seekers and refugees - also in other more peaceful contexts, in order to improve their condition.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, there is a security and humanitarian catastrophe in Yemen. We support the UN Special Envoy, in particular in trying to secure humanitarian corridors for those suffering; yet despite efforts vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia, we have to know that the Houthi do not act alone. There, a symmetric activity has been financed and supported by Iran changing, for some time now already, its foreign affairs paradigm and destabilising the region. In focusing somehow on the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), we forget this role and our activities should be aimed at Iran as well and at trying to ensure that this country stops financing non-state actors playing this very negative role in the region.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr Speaker, like much of the instability in the Middle East, the tragic war in Yemen is a consequence of the destructive power struggle between Iran and Saudi Arabia. Iranian support for the Houthi rebels is the source of this conflict. That support must end immediately. At the same time, the methods used by the Saudi-led coalition are, by all means, unacceptable. The ruthless bombing of civilians and civilian infrastructure amounts to war crimes. The blockade deployed by the Saudi-led coalition aims to conquer Yemen through starvation. Mr President, we as Members of this House must condemn the appalling actions of both Iran and Saudi Arabia in the strongest possible terms.
