The expansion of political or military influence will never be acceptable at the expense of innocent civilians. The people of Yemen deserve to live in democracy, in freedom and with respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Amnesty International describes the current conflict in Yemen as the forgotten war. More than two and a half years of brutal bombardment from a Saudi-led coalition has received very little media attention. Civilians are the first victims of this conflict. Millions of people, particularly women and children, are now living in horrific conditions. The European Union must therefore use all means at its disposal to demand the opening of a humanitarian corridor in order to provide water, food, shelter and medical attention. As Europeans we must call out our own governments for the responsibility they bear in the widespread human rights violations in Yemen. Not only have France and the UK backed Saudi Arabia in the conflict, some Member States have also contributed to the extrajudicial killings led by the US. Under the pretence of war against terrorism, The Trump administration has hugely increased the size and scale of its operations on Yemeni territory, including destructive air and drone strikes. I am ashamed that my country contributes to the devastating situation of the Yemeni people by sharing intelligence with Trump’s criminal administration and helping them find locations for strikes. Other EU governments are also involved in these widespread human rights violations. Germany plays a crucial role in this programme through a satellite relay station located on its territory that allows US drones to function and Italy allows the US Government to fly drones across Libya from its Sigonella airbase. We must expose the West’s cooperation with Saudi Arabia, and in this respect Theresa May’s most recent visit this week to Saudi is ineffective and hypocritical. The Saudi bombs dropping on Yemen say ‘Made in Britain’.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - “Yemen today is one of the worst places on this planet to be a child,” words from Unicef's regional director. The strategy game of the greats in the region, Iran and Saudi Arabia, is also the horror of the little ones, the citizens of Yemen. Good that international pressure is being stepped up to end the blockades, famine, health crises and human rights violations. But it would be much better if we also took responsibility at home. When do we stop arms deliveries? In the first place I look with shame on my cheeks at my own Member State: in Belgium arms export is the competence of the federal states. The Walloon government supplied EUR 576 million in weapons to Saudi Arabia in 2015, the year that country started its war in Yemen. Wallonia, yes, the Belgian federal state that blocked the trade agreement with Canada again approved 25 arms transfers last month, worth 1.8 billion EUR! Do you understand that? Not me! I am embarrassed and I am angry. This hypocrisy undermines the credibility of our Member States and the European Union!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I want to join the debate that has just taken place here.We cannot be indifferent to the terrible humanitarian tragedy in this troubled country, Yemen.Unfortunately, we have talked about this repeatedly and the situation has worsened significantly in recent weeks.So we should at least make a major international effort to lift the blockade of airports and ports and at least try to ensure that humanitarian aid is provided to this country and that hundreds of people and children do not die there every day.I am in favor of what my colleagues have described here, what is the hypocrisy of both some EU countries and the United States in supporting Saudi Arabia, which has a huge share in the tragedy in Yemen.We should also address these issues more internationally, although at this point we will initially try to at least ensure effective humanitarian aid.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, this is my fourth speech since 2015 on the humanitarian crisis in Yemen. Saudi Arabia and Iran are clearing their accounts to the detriment of the people of Yemen. Where a large-scale humanitarian crisis is unfolding as, according to the UN, out of a total population of 21 million, 19 million have no access to drinking water, 7 million people do not have access to food and 320,000 children are malnourished due to air and naval blockade. imposed by Saudi Arabia, which bombs refugee camps, schools, health facilities and even Médecins Sans Frontières. So, where war crimes are being committed and while all this is happening, the SYRIZA-ANEL government with a shameful decision is launching the sale of thousands of missiles in Saudi Arabia. A ban on arms exports from European Union and other countries to Saudi Arabia must be imposed. Let the war criminals sit on the stool.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the case of Yemen is further proof of the European Union's inability to play an important and serious role in international politics. For three years he was indifferent to Saudi Arabia's violations of the principles of international law and simply watched the destruction of the country and the killing of civilians due to clashes between Saudi-backed Saudi and Houthi troops. But how can it be different when the United States and various European Union countries sell arms to Saudi Arabia; the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Spain, and even my country, Greece, have sold out military equipment in Saudi Arabia. And suddenly, when the blockade of Yemen's ports and airports by Saudi Arabia led to the mass deaths of children and vulnerable people, the European Union hypocritically decided to intervene. To put an end to this hypocrisy, the European Union must ban arms sales to Saudi Arabia and bring to justice those who have committed war crimes.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, no matter how much efforts are made to silence the war in Yemen, it is neither foreign nor irrelevant to the European Union, its governments and the capitalist system they are defending. Saudi Arabia's intervention in Yemen and rivalry with Iran are linked to the interests of the United States, the European Union and other powerful capitalist states in controlling the poorest country on the Arabian Peninsula, which has, among other things, strategic shipping lanes. and is a transit point for the largest volume of goods. Your tears for civilians, young children, the spread of cholera and the millions of malnourished people are hypocritical. The sale of munitions by the Greek government, for the sake of the geostrategic upgrading of the Greek bourgeoisie, to a murderous state such as Saudi Arabia, is essentially an example of European Union support for that country and must be annulled. The Communist Party of Greece insists on this.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this debate has been a very useful exchange and I thank our colleagues, the honourable Members, for their interventions. I gather from our exchange that we need as a matter of urgency to ensure that Yemen is high on the EU’s agenda of political priorities. We will reflect on how best to use the policy instruments at our disposal to continue to play a constructive role in ending this conflict and helping Yemen on its path to recovery and reconstruction.  There are just two points I would like to raise. Firstly, after a lot of efforts by the international community, and in particular by us as the European Union, regarding humanitarian access, just last week humanitarian flights to and from Sanaa were granted permission to operate. This is the only access for humanitarian assistance into the north of Yemen and must definitely be allowed to operate without interruption. But this is not enough of course, and this is why we have to continue to put pressure in order to sustain unrestricted humanitarian access. It is the only way to provide humanitarian assistance.  The second point I would like to clarify is that any decision to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia would require unanimity within the Council. Let me once again stress my appreciation for your having decided to debate this issue and for Parliament’s role in advancing what I see as a common goal on what is definitely a humanitarian tragedy.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received eight motions for a resolution tabled in accordance with Art.123 sec.2 of the Regulations.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 30 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: David McALLISTER
text: in writing. – On 16 July, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs announced that 20.7 million people in Yemen are in need of assistance. Moreover the destruction of infrastructure and breakdown of public services have fuelled the outbreak of cholera. The devastating humanitarian impact of the conflict on civilians is alarming. The downward spiral in Yemen must be stopped by all means. The European Union should continue to support the efforts of the United Nations to achieve a resumption of the negotiations. All parties in the conflict have to act in a flexible and constructive manner and without preconditions to their efforts. Only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution to the conflict can restore peace and preserve the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing.- In the joint motion for a resolution across the political factions, we express our concern at the failure to find a political solution acceptable to all parties to the conflict.We emphasize that the only acceptable solution must be a peaceful one and its finding under the auspices of the United Nations.Since March 2015, more than 8,000 people have been killed and another 50,000 injured in the conflict.According to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, an alarming number - 20.7 million people - need help, especially food aid.We therefore call on all those involved in the conflict to end it immediately peacefully.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The situation in Yemen is catastrophic.20.7 million people are in need of food aid, 7 million of whom are in an emergency, 2.2 million children are suffering from acute malnutrition and one child dies every ten minutes from preventable causes.Since 2015, more than 8,000 people have died, 60% of whom are civilians.According to Save the Children, 130 children die every day in Yemen, and millions of children are unable to go to school.A cholera epidemic has broken out in the country, and the humanitarian catastrophe continues due to air and sea blockades.These are dumb numbers.It is vital to gain immediate access to humanitarian aid.Efforts to reach a political agreement must continue, and the UN's leading role in this is important, as is the EU's support for it.It is also important that perpetrators of war crimes be brought before the International Criminal Court.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on an oral question to the Commission by Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, to negotiate the Convention establishing a multilateral court for the settlement of investment disputes (O-000084/2017 - B8-0611 / 2017 (2017/2924)(RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! With a large majority in this House, Parliament supports the establishment of a multilateral tribunal as a consequence of the recognition that the old dispute settlement mechanism, the old ISDS system, has many weaknesses and should be thrown in the dustbin of history. We discussed for a long time about non-transparent procedures, about the lack of revision options, about the question that law firms do big business with them, and, and, and. That is not sensible investment protection, and in this respect it is correct - and we as Parliament have ensured that a different system in the Canada Agreement, a court system with judges, with a review body, with full transparency, and, and, and has been established and, as you know, both partners have committed themselves in the Canada Agreement to stand up for a multilateral investment court and also to win partners. We saw that there was a lot of interest in a presentation during the Unctad conference. We saw that many technical meetings were already there. In this respect, this is really a way to really dissolve the old ISDS contracts. We want to support this path, and that is why, Commissioner, we have put this question for an oral answer. There are three points in particular that are important to us. You know the questions that I don't need to read out. Maybe the three elements. First of all: If you want to support this process, it is of course also about knowing what difficulties there are, what counter-arguments and what restrictions there are. And that's why it would be very good if we could talk a little more intensively about where there are actually possible obstacles. For example, I could imagine that some countries on this earth would say: It's really nice if he is with you now His proposal for a multilateral investment court comes around the corner, but the Council of Ministers and some member states are not even able to sign the Uncitral Convention on more transparency. That is a certain contradiction, and I say: that could be an obstacle. So look again: what are the obstacles? Second, we are of course particularly interested in what this actually means for the European bilateral investment agreements and for the only investment agreement that the European Union has passed with ISDS, the Energy Charter. We have around 1,200 bilateral investment agreements. I think it is a miracle that we are arguing fiercely about future agreements and their dispute settlement, but the existing ones simply continue to exist and are also heavily used. For example, Spain is currently one of the countries that has been sued most frequently by other, including European countries, or by companies in European countries and sometimes also from countries that criticize this system particularly strongly. So what about the new approach to the existing agreements? I think you have to be clear about that. Thirdly, there is criticism from my home country from the German Association of Judges, a very serious association of judges, who say: This is not a good system because the national legal process is not exhausted to the full. We would like to have another answer, as you see it - a combination of the request to first exhaust the national legal process in order to then be able to appeal to an international, multilateral court. Three points - among others - that I think are necessary so that we can go on the offensive even more.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this question and for the opportunity to discuss where we are in discussions on the Multilateral Investment Court. Mr Lange kindly added some extra questions to the written questions, so I will try to answer them and then we can come back to it in the debate. On the first question in the written questions – because I am eager to answer all of that otherwise I will be criticised – we have engaged, as you know, with Parliament and the stakeholders on the need to reform the existing investor-state dispute arbitration, particularly at meetings in the Committee on International Trade, in public consultation, the impact assessment process, and quite a lot of stakeholder meetings here in Brussels, as well as across Europe and in other countries as well.  From these discussions, it became even clearer that investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS), the traditional way of resolving disputes between foreign investors and host states, has a number of shortcomings. We have discussed this numerous times. I think that even in the first hearing I had, before I became Commissioner for Trade, I promised to reform the system, and it was very clear then that many of you already had criticisms. One of the problems is that the disputing parties choose and pay what are perceived to be their adjudicators for each case. This raises important concerns and does not fit with the principle that justice should not only be done, but should also be seen to be done. Secondly, this ad hoc system inevitably creates fragmentation of the interpretation of core elements of investment protection standards, and that leads to uncertainty for governments and investors alike. Furthermore, the ISDS system as it is today is not transparent, it has no possibility for appeal and it does not provide for sufficient review opportunities, and this is a problem. In order to respond to these concerns, we have been working on the initiative to create a permanent Multilateral Investment Court. This would ensure a higher degree of legitimacy, consistency and reliability. It would also reinforce independence and impartiality, transparency and also effectiveness in investment dispute resolution at global level, because this discussion is not only taking place in Europe.  I have been discussing this matter with trade ministers across the globe, and in many countries it is a focus of debate. So they are also looking at how to reform the system. They get a lot of criticism from domestic stakeholders and this is, therefore, something on which there really is a case for global reform, instead of each country trying to reform in its own way. We have examined different options in our Impact Assessment, ranging from the reform of the existing rules or renegotiation of each investment treaty, to the establishment of an appeal body, but these alternatives do not really fully address the totality of the concerns identified by us, and also raised by this House and many others. This is why a Multilateral Investment Court could be the optimal reform of the system.  The Council and its Member States have broadly welcomed this and they have expressed political support. The Commission adopted a recommendation for a Council Decision on 13 September, authorising the opening of negotiations for a Convention establishing the Multilateral Court. That recommendation is public. You can see it, so you will know what we are talking about, and we are looking forward to the swift adoption by the Council of the authorisation and directives. But we still have no indication of when this will come. On the other question, the idea that the Multilateral Investment Court would replace any ISDS mechanism included in the investment treaties; yes, but there are internal bilateral investment treaties (BITs) between EU Member States. They will have to be outside this reform initiative. We consider them, from the Commission side, as contrary to EU law, and Member States have to deal with this issue. Therefore, we should not move them to the Multilateral Investment Court. Another question that was asked was about our current thinking on the relationship between the Multilateral Investment Court and the domestic courts, and how that will be governed in the investment treaties under the Multilateral Investment Court jurisdiction. Our approach, included in our EU Agreement, will be to encourage recourse to domestic courts prior to initiating international dispute settlement. This is the EU position. However, in different countries we are discussing with their different traditions, so we will have to see how we can find a way forward as part of the negotiations. On the fourth question, one of the priorities would be to facilitate access to the Court for SMEs, to ensure full transparency of proceedings, the intervention of affected third parties and an effective international enforcement regime. So these are our priorities for the international negotiations. On the final question, it is intended that discussions and future negotiations on the Court should focus only on procedural issues. Matters such as counter claims and compliance with other international obligations will, in principle, be addressed in the underlying investment treaties to be applied by the Multilateral Investment Court. If such treaties allow for the possibility of bringing counter claims, the new Court should also be able to hear those claims against investors. Finally, it is still too early to say whether the Multilateral Investment Court would be a stand-alone institution, which is one possibility, or docked into another. There are different views on this and options are on the table. It is a little too early to decide this yet, but I promise to keep you fully informed because, of course, we will continue to have the highest level of transparency in these discussions. I welcome the opportunity of discussing this with the House today, and hopefully we will continue these discussions within the International Trade Committee and elsewhere as well.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: for the PPE Group. - Thank you, Mr President. Thank you Cecilia Malmström! We are here tonight to discuss and debate the fact that the Commission wants to start negotiations on a multilateral court to deal with investment protection disputes. Let me be honest - I still wonder why. I have spent many years following this debate, and I must say that none of what the Commission, and now Cecilia, has declared in a single moment has made it more comprehensible. Actually, it's pretty simple why it's so difficult to understand. This is because there is already a multilateral tool for dealing with the disputes we are talking about. It is ICSID that you are aware of, which was created in 1965, which covers 161 countries and which is basically governed by the same commission, the UN Commission Uncitral, which governs all these types of issues. Now they have decided to reinvent the wheel in a European context and try to create a new, different or maybe even the same type of institution, and therefore I just wonder: Why? To find the answer to that question, I think you have to look in politics, because this is really a question of politics. Unfortunately, it is EU policy at its worst. The story behind this idea, we all know how it started. It actually began with the debate on ISDS, and the dispute resolution process began with a Swedish company, Vattenfall, suing Germany in connection with the decision to phase out nuclear power. My German colleagues nod. You know, that's how it went. Once upon a time, Sweden shut down nuclear power and it was a German company that operated the nuclear power plants, and Sweden paid compensation for it. In this case, no compensation was paid. I do not know whether Vattenfall is entitled or not to compensation. I do not know, but this became a major political problem in Germany. Especially among the German Social Democrats. This major German political problem became the problem of the German government, and what to do then? Then you make your own problem a European problem. All of a sudden ... (inaudible) ... on the EU trying to deal with the controversy over dispute resolution. What is Europe doing then? Let's make this problem a global problem. Can we not ensure that the whole world engages in some way creating a new institution, which we in fact already have, to deal with disputes between states and investors? But I still do not understand why. It is not the case that we have a great many of these disputes. Since the 60s, we have had just over 600. Globally! Then I wonder - is it that we have a lot of problems with the disputes that are being conducted today? So far no one was able to send in the perfect solution, which is not strange. I did a challenge on Twitter for a year or so when the waves of debate were at their height. Now there are not many who are interested anymore but then, when everyone was very interested, I asked: Can you give me an example of a case of such investment disputes that is unfair? I have not received a single proposal. But for every suggestion someone comes up with, I promise to give ten examples that are justified and important. Instead of being caught up in this political description and trying to fix a system that actually works, perhaps one should devote the corresponding commitment and corresponding time to reforming ICSID - the institution that has existed since the 60s, with 161 states, and trying to do so better instead of just duplicating. Unfortunately, I think this will lead to more problems, not less.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, it is true: there are more than 3,300 bilateral agreements in the world - about 1,400 in the European Union - that contain the private arbitration mechanism for the resolution of disputes between investors and States. Created in the fifties - long past - it does not respond to the democratic principles of our time, it is opaque, lacks predictability and legal consistency, puts at risk the decisions of governments when they regulate in defense of the general interest, does not have a mechanism for appeal and is inaccessible to SMEs. With good reason it generates a frontal rejection of the citizenship. Socialists and Democrats are totally opposed to this system. We already demonstrated this when we forced the reopening of the CETA negotiations to eliminate the resolution of disputes between investors and States. We need to create a new legal framework for investor protection, as we have been proposing in this Parliament and, sincerely, I believe that the multilateral court may be the best solution, because it will allow the same rules to be applied by the same judges to any company in any dispute with any State. Commissioner, I want to congratulate you and your team today because I think you are doing an excellent job of gathering international support for this proposal. You can count on my support to defend a multilateral court that is public, transparent, impartial, with permanent, independent judges, subject to a strict code of conduct and incompatibilities and - I add - that also represent gender diversity; that is accessible to SMEs with an appeal mechanism and that allows all interested parties, including civil society, to submit their allegations. But questions remain to be elucidated. How is the relationship with the national jurisdictions to be produced effectively? It seems reasonable to exhaust that system first in the countries that have it before going to the court.How will access to SMEs be effectively guaranteed?How will the new model be financed and how will developing countries be supported?And how will the transition period from one system to another take place?I am looking forward to your response.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, we have seen that multinationals do not want to be taxed where they make their profits. Now the multinationals do not want their cases to be tried in the countries in which they invest and we have seen this with the requirement of ISDS type regulations in CETA or TTIP. Things are simple: we have national jurisdictions and national courts. It is unlikely to say that there will be no protection of rights and investors in national jurisdictions. This is a position that really underestimates national courts. Why should we have this jurisdiction? In whose name will he make decisions? How will these decisions be issued? What will happen to the national courts? Why should only investors have such facilities? I believe that it is a way for the multinationals to evade and in the end to be able to file lawsuits against the states and not fulfill their own obligations. Just as they do with tax evasion.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after months, if not years, of heated debate on how to ensure rules-based trade with the United States, it has gone awfully silent, even on the investment protection question, also known as ISDS (investor-state dispute settlement). Still I’m happy, Commissioner Malmström, that you are not retreating and that you are continuing to address the concerns that have been voiced by this House throughout the various debates on rules-based trade. Some key points that we have expressed concerns about are: the need for more transparency, the need for an appeals mechanism, and also the risk of conflicts of interest for adjudicators or arbitration judges. And it seems, from your presentation, that the multilateral investment court system would actually address these main concerns and could replace the controversial ISDS mechanism. So our Group is very encouraged by these proposed reforms, which are far-reaching. Besides the updates that you gave, it would be good to hear a little more about the specific needs of SMEs – which have always been a priority for our Group – and also what would happen to existing intra-EU bilateral investment treaties that are still in place. That has been perhaps a parallel concern, but it would be good to know a little bit more about where that is going. And I am sure we will hear more details of the proposed organisational nature, the set-up and operation, in order to have a better sense of how that would go. So thank you for these first steps: they are going in the right direction according to our Group. We look forward to continuing the discussion about these important reforms.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - 150,000 people stated in 2014 that ISDS is completely unacceptable to them. The multilateral court for the settlement of investment disputes, the MIC, was intended as a replacement for ISDS. And it is true, compared to ISDS, the MIC contains a few improvements. But there are still very serious objections. The MIC is still a separate legal process that allows foreign investors to claim millions or even billions from governments that do nothing but enact a democratic decision. No requirements are placed on those investors and the system is not accessible to third parties. Moreover, it is not tested against national laws or international treaties. I cannot agree with such a multilateral court for the settlement of investment disputes. My question is therefore: are you prepared to impose obligations on investors that follow from UN conventions, ILO standards and the Paris climate agreement, for example? Are you willing to open the MIC to states and third parties such as trade unions so that they can sue investors? Are you prepared to make exhaustion of national judicial process a condition for access to the MIC? And finally: are you prepared to wait for the judgment of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Investment Court System with European law?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I am happy to see that the Commission is finally ready to move forward from the old-style investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) system and has decided to replace it with the permanent multilateral investment court. The problems of the traditional ISDS system are many and well known. Already two years ago, the Commission stated that it would provide a full replacement of the old ISDS mechanism with a ‘modern, efficient, transparent and impartial system for international dispute resolution’. That is a quote. Again, the Commission has stated that it needs a court that is based on public trust. Therefore, the opening of negotiations to set up this system is very welcome. In order to gain public trust, however, the Commission must be able to answer the questions that this Parliament and European citizens have posed. The key question for public trust is: what improvements will this multilateral investment court bring in terms of access to dispute settlement for states, investors and, especially, affected third parties who are often completely denied access to justice? I see the multilateral investment court improving on the technical and procedural problems of the investment court system. But reforming only the institutional and procedural aspects of the system will not solve its fundamental flaws. It does not provide a full replacement of the old system, as was promised two years ago. In the negotiations the EU must build a court to which states and affected third parties may also bring cases: a court that protects states’ and citizens’ rights, not just investors’ rights. Otherwise, we are not providing trade for all, Commissioner, but only for the privileged few.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a global court for corporations, with TTIP, CETA and TiSA I thought I had seen them all, but here you have truly surpassed yourselves. This is what we all need: a global court where big investors can sue any world government to enforce the rights of big business people all over the world, and therefore also in Europe, and make us citizens understand who is boss. really. Your proposal not only legitimizes the abuses linked to ISDS, but multiplies them by a thousand, because it creates a permanent tribunal without there being a clear law to apply. Seventy years of international trade have not yet given us a univocal interpretation of the rights of investors, but one thing is certain: it is the parliaments that must define these rights, certainly not the super courts. Better a single global court than many small bilateral courts, you might say, but even this is false, because the judgments of a bilateral court are valid only for that specific case, while a permanent court would become a body capable of defining standards and creating precedents globally, and this is not me saying but the association of German judges. What about the enormous discrimination that only foreign investors will be entitled to this special and faster justice, while domestic companies will still have to settle for what you consider slow. Other than investor court! What we need, Commissioner, is an international tribunal for the crimes committed by many multinationals against the citizens of the world: murders, land grabbing, contamination, pollution. But this you cannot clearly propose because it would be true justice and this is not what interests you.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The multilateral trade court is a step in the right direction when it comes to improving investor protection. The future Court of Justice must of course meet strict criteria. It must be set up permanently, it must be transparent, inexpensive and independent. An appeal body is also needed, and the judges' impartiality must be guaranteed. Under no circumstances should this new system lead to foreign investors receiving special rights that are denied to others such as NGOs, third parties, political parties or states. Commissioner, I would therefore be interested: is the Commission working in this direction? What do the Member States, but also the countries outside the EU, say in general about the proposal to set up a multilateral commercial court? One last question that my colleague Bernd Lange has already asked, but which you have not yet answered: is the Commission planning to modernize investor protection under the Energy Charter?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Many questions have already been asked. However, opinion seems to be clearly defined by many. Citizens refuse to give foreign investors the exclusive right to threaten and initiate lawsuits before arbitration tribunals. Hence the question: does the mandate you put forward for a multilateral investment court really break with the wrong basic principle of ISDS? Do You Offer Equality Before The Law? Does the mandate provide an answer to the question: what law should the judgments be based on? On constitutions, on UN conventions or only again on the narrow text of the respective investor protection agreement? Furthermore: Does the Court of Justice also address obligations of investors? Put an end to the one-way street! All international experiences say: We also need a right of action for municipalities, cities and states, for the victims of legal violations by transnational corporations against people, social and environmental rights. Let us learn from the negative example of the decades-long conflict between Chevron, Texaco and Ecuador. Even if it were possible to create a court of justice that met the criteria mentioned: As long as the ISDS instrument in the Energy Charter Treaty continues to exist, we will remain subject to EU lawsuits. As a consequence, this means: let's follow the example of Italy and leave the charter!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a better regulated global economy needs a multilateral court capable of resolving investment disputes fairly. The situation we have cannot continue. The anarchic multiplication of the most diverse arbitration systems in numerous bilateral and regional investment agreements, in addition to the costs involved, does not guarantee a coherent solution of disputes or the application of common rules. As the European Union is the world's largest exporter and importer of investment, it is obviously in our interest for this multilateral tribunal. And it is important that this debate takes place not around the old model of private arbitration but rather the new European proposal for a public arbitration system, as enshrined in the agreement with Canada. And this is the Commission's primary task: to build confidence in the new model of public arbitration and to gain the necessary support in the international community. A multilateral tribunal is only worthwhile if it is really new and not a solution from the past.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is indeed a historic night. So I have more speaking time, right?  Why are we doing this? Mr Fjellner is right that much of the debate in Europe originated around the Vattenfall issue. There was discussion before that, and also in other parts of the world there has been discussion of this. But that was probably the triggering event. It showed that there were issues related to transparency, procedures that were brought into question, and there were certainly questions related to legitimacy. This is a debate that is ongoing around the world. That is why it takes a little time to get everything right, because we do not want to impose a system that is European: we want to listen to our colleagues from other regions as well. Canada and the EU are the leading ones on this, but many other countries are interested. We are looking at setting up a group of friends who could start the process, and start looking into more details of this. If I was unclear in my introduction: all the Member States support this, it is not a Commission-driven idea, it has the support of the Member States. And I believe, judging from various votes, that it has the support of the majority of this House as well. We do not have to re-invent the wheel. We could very well envisage incorporating this into an existing organisation. The United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) is now discussing it, they agreed that the system needs to be reviewed, so discussions are taking place there. The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) is one possibility, although it handles only 60% of cases, so there is not full coverage, and unanimity is required to change the rules, so that could be a cumbersome process, but it is certainly not excluded. Issues related to tax evasion are important, Mr Marias, but they will not be discussed in the Multilateral Investment Court. The intra-EU bilateral investment treaties (BITs) are to be abolished. They cannot be transferred in. Coming back to another question, there is a process being discussed internally to review the Energy Charter as well, and we are looking into this. One of my colleague is responsible, and we could come back to report on how that is going. What would the new court look like? It will have to have independent judges and they will be appointed on a permanent basis; there will have to be two instances; and there will have to be some sort of secretariat – not a huge bureaucracy but a secretariat. There will be costs, depending on how many participate. For purposes of comparison, the appellate body in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) costs EUR 10 million a year, but that is just one figure we can use as a comparative. The aim would be for the least-developed countries to pay less, and then we will have to see how much everybody should contribute. That will also depend on whether we create something new, or plug into something existing – or, rather, something slightly reformed. Responsible business conduct is really important. There are laws that companies need to respect in the various countries, and European companies need to respect European laws even if they are operating abroad. Discussions on investors’ responsibilities are going on in various international forums. There is the human rights working group in the United Nations, and we are following that. It is a little too early to see how it is going. It was a bit dramatic at the start and the scope was unclear but we are participating and I have high hopes that this could lead to something, either as part of the discussion or in parallel. This is an important discussion and it is a firm objective of the Commission that affected communities should have the opportunity to make their views known in proceedings before the future Multilateral Investment Court, so they will have a voice there as well. They could be able to intervene with third-party submissions or amicus curiae. This should be allowed in the proceedings, but exactly how it should work is something we will have to come back to. Lots of work has yet to be done. We are still at a very early stage on this, we need a critical mass of countries before we can begin, and I will be looking forward to continue reporting to Parliament on how these deliberations are going.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing.- With this statement, I want to make it very clear that I agree with this question addressed to the European Commission and which aims to obtain some fundamental clarifications on the objectives, legal framework and way of functioning of this multilateral court for resolving investment disputes.But at the same time, I must affirm that I do not see myself in attempts to use this part, or others, of the trade agreements that the European Union establishes with third countries, to try in a sometimes blind and demagogic way to question a whole foreign policy andinternational trade.I consider these actions, carried out in the name of old-fashioned protectionism, to be completely out of step with the role that the EU must play as a global actor, with a view to protecting its citizens, defending its values and even combating the deregulation that results from the process ofglobalization.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: written. - In the EU, we do not need private courts to decide disputes between companies and governments. Not only in the European Parliament, many have been given this opinion, but also think of all Europeans who have made their voices heard against ISDS. Despite the fact that ISDS is now giving way to the multilateral court for the settlement of investment disputes, it is no reason for me to be less critical. Yes, there are improvements over ISDS. However, in my view, we still have a lot of work to do when it comes to transparent and fair dispute resolution. I can therefore endorse the questions from my colleague Bernd Lange. In my opinion, it is important that we do not jeopardize our standards and values ​​in order to achieve transparent and fair dispute settlement between companies and governments. This means, for example, that UN conventions are observed and ILO conventions are signed. People are still concerned about the shadowiness that seems to accompany such courts. These concerns can only be allayed if not only companies, but also citizens, trade unions and environmental organizations can rely on fair trade compliance.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The ECR Group supports the initiative to create a multilateral dispute settlement tribunal, the latest proposal in the context of the multilateralisation and institutionalization of a decentralized system of international investment law. The aim of the measures taken is to reduce administrative burdens by centralizing disputes within a single set of procedural rules, which aims to ensure that investors have access to the resolution of international investment disputes, regardless of the size or turnover of companies. In addition to a centralized redress mechanism and the possibility of third party intervention, the proposal contains strict ethical and impartiality requirements, appointment of judges for one term only, full-time appointment of judges and independent appointment mechanisms. This proposal raises a number of practical and legal problems, such as the confidentiality and independence of the parties in the appointment of arbitrators, while raising questions about the cost, duration of procedures and the funding of the tribunal. Moreover, the pool of potential permanent judges of the tribunal with the necessary qualifications, with no conflict of interest, is rather small. Most likely, the tribunal will consist of the same arbitrators who are already arbitrators for investment agreements. I believe that the success of this proposal will mean a new era for international investment law around the world, but it cannot be firmly stated at the moment that a multilateral tribunal will be better or worse, although usually institutionalization and an appeal mechanism make dispute resolution a even more expensive.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - In recent years, the inclusion of dispute resolution between investors and the State (RLIE) in trade and investment agreements has become the subject of greater concern and public intervention. Some of the problems identified stem from the RLIE, which is based on the principles of arbitration. These problems refer, in particular, to the little or no legitimacy, coherence and transparency of the RLIE, as well as the lack of possibilities for review. The institutionalization of this investment dispute resolution system in EU trade and investment agreements through the inclusion of the investment court system (ITS) represents another step in the creation of a court above national states and above the sovereignty of states. peoples. It serves the interests of multinational companies that should be subject to the national laws of the countries in which they operate, as do most people and small and medium-sized companies.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I would like to draw attention once again to a problem that I have raised several times during this parliamentary term. I call on the Commission to finally start tackling the problem of serious crime, smuggling tens of thousands of cats and dogs from the eastern part of the EU to the western part of the EU. This problem of serious crime, which is almost as lucrative as drugs or prostitution, is underestimated by the European Commission, and because it is a cross-border form of crime, no state is able to solve these problems on its own. I have received a report that perhaps a department of the European Commission is dealing with this issue. I want to appeal to the Commissioner not to really underestimate the fact that tens of thousands of pets a year are exported from the Visegrad countries to Western Europe in such terrible conditions. In addition to animal cruelty, there is a huge amount of untaxed money and other forms of illegal activity.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Romania has celebrated ten years since it became a member of the European Union and legitimately wants a truly equal status in relation to its European partners, including through its acceptance in the Schengen area. That is why I was unpleasantly surprised by the statements made earlier this month by the President of the European Commission, Mr. Jean-Claude Juncker, referring to Romania, statements that cast doubt on the preparation of my country to join the Schengen area. . Romania has celebrated ten years since it became a member of the European Union and legitimately wants a truly equal status with its European partners, which means accepting the country into the Schengen area. Romania has made important sacrifices to comply with the accession criteria, and maintaining the current situation is an injustice done to Romanians. Such contradictory positions raise questions not only about the consistency of the President of the European Commission in relation to Romania, but also about the vision of the future of the European project as such. Romania is a country that wants to consolidate this project and any such signal that erodes the trust of Romanian citizens in the European Union is totally wrong. In 2018, Romania will celebrate the centenary of the Great Union and I want to believe that this occasion will find us in the position of member state of the Schengen area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr. President, the SYRIZA-ANEL government by force, with MAT and chemicals continues the auctions in the justices of the peace, while today the electronic auctions started. The auctions that pave the way for the "crows" to grab the houses of the impoverished Greek people, and in fact instead of a lentil plate, and all this while there is the possibility of establishing a fund to save borrowers with 4.5 billion euros out of 25 billion. euros that will be left over from the third loan package. A borrower rescue fund that even Draghi accepts, throwing the ball to the Greek government when he answered my question a few days ago. At the same time, the SYRIZA-ANEL government refuses to grant a pre-emptive right to the borrowers, so that they can buy their own loan at the first offer price made by the "crows". And the icing on the cake is put by the banks themselves, which now grant new mortgages that cover 75% of the value of all properties sold at auction. This will mean the seizure of the houses of the Greeks by the "crows" and even with loans.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the so-called Social Rights Pillar, signed in Gothenburg, presented as a new initiative to strengthen the social dimension of the European Union, does not, in fact, bring anything new. An initiative that keeps the set of policies associated with economic governance, the European Semester, Economic and Monetary Union or the Budget Treaty untouched. The same policies that promoted, in the last decade, brutal attacks on labor and social rights and on which we can only see their deepening with more exploitation and impoverishment. In the set of 20 points, any proposals for the increase of wages, the fight against precariousness, the effective defense of collective bargaining, a better redistribution of wealth are absent. We will continue, denouncing the hoax that this Pillar represents and defending the need to promote social development, the valorization of wages, the right to work and work with rights, the promotion of free and quality public services and the universality of social responses, namely public and universal Social Security.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, today we had an interesting discussion on the state of the Energy Union and as part of that document I emphasize here the importance of the Report on the state of implementation of energy efficiency measures in the Member States. This report proves that energy efficiency measures contribute to GDP growth, employment growth, have a good macroeconomic impact on all Member States, reduce fossil fuel imports, in general, and all together contribute to the decarbonisation of our society. . However, I would like to point out that the report mentioned that eight member states, including Croatia, failed in this past period and did not achieve the expected goals. Therefore, I take this opportunity to appeal and call on the Government of the Republic of Croatia and the Minister of Energy to abolish the obligation to install heat distributors, because they are not an energy efficiency measure, do not contribute to the quality of life of our citizens and do not reduce their energy bills. poverty.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Mr President, on December 1, Romania will celebrate its national day. As my colleague from the Socialists mentioned, Romania and Bulgaria are ten years old this year since they joined the European Union. Apparently, it should be a festive moment, but the reality is darker. Yes, our countries and our citizens have gained a lot from being a Member State. Yes, there is more visible prosperity in our towns and villages. Yes, many Romanians and Bulgarians feel European, and support for the European Union is still at a very high level. But the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area is postponed sine die. MCV is continuously prolonged under various pretexts. Various regulations, such as the Workers' Directive, put us at a disadvantage. All these deepen the gap between Romania and the rest of the European Union. And this is not the only crack in the European Union. The chance to overcome this situation was a profound reform of the Union, as suggested by the White Paper presented by the President of the Commission. It seems that the chance was missed, the Union chose not to change anything. If we want a democratic and prosperous Europe and above all equal for all, we must make this reform now, as soon as possible, otherwise an explosion is imminent.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, today is the International Day of Solidarity in Palestine and, 50 years after the war of '67 and the occupation of the Palestinian territories by Israel, the criminal Israeli occupation continues. It extends to hundreds of settlements, killing hundreds of people and even children, and imprisoning thousands of Palestinians. The wishes do not hide the support of Israel from the United States, the European Union and governments, such as the Greek government SYRIZA-ANEL, which strengthens civil-military relations with Israel and upgrades the US base in Crete, which is a base against its peoples. Middle East and Palestine. The Communist Party of Greece, yesterday, with its intervention in the Greek Parliament, denounced the government because it does not implement the decision of the Parliament for the recognition of the Palestinian state. An independent sovereign Palestinian state is required on the border of '67 with East Jerusalem as its capital, the withdrawal of the Israeli army and settlers from the occupied territories, the demolition of the Wall and the lifting of the blockade of the West Bank and Gaza, the liberation of all Palestinians and the return of all Palestinians. refugees in their homes.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to comment today on the issue of privacy, personal data protection, and talk about how important it is, of course, for citizens. It is important that, of course, the EP, together with the Council, has adopted a regulation on the protection of personal data, because many people are concerned about the handling of their personal data. The regulation, which will come into force in May, is also partly problematic, at least in some aspects that affect public administration. He says that every municipality should ensure the protection of personal data, but does not distinguish how big the municipalities are. There are also very small municipalities in the Czech Republic, which are not at all on a European scale, they are municipalities that often have only 250 inhabitants. There are 2,000 such municipalities in the Czech Republic. I think that imposing the same level of obligations on such small municipalities is not in accordance with the principles of flexibility and subsidiarity. Therefore, I would very much like us to focus in the coming years on assessing the impact of this regulation, because although it has positive effects, it also has negative effects on the different sizes of municipalities and cities, especially across Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few days ago, Il Sole 24 Ore published the new ranking relating to the livability of Italian cities. The survey, carried out by measuring wealth, consumption, work, environment, services, demographics, justice, security and culture, highlights an increase in the gap between south and north, placing many of the southern cities at the bottom. Despite this step forward, as also highlighted by the latest Svimez report, the south of Italy still remains far from the standards of the other regions of Europe. The employment rate is still the lowest in Europe and social emergencies are many and difficult to overcome. The citizens of the Mezzogiorno are waiting for answers that must also come from the European institutions, for example avoiding questioning the post-2020 cohesion policies, which are fundamental for the relaunching of the lagging regions. However, let me say that quality of life cannot be encapsulated in statistics alone. If so, for a long time we would have lost that smile and that welcome for which we are known in the world.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! This Parliament has set a standard obliging states, governments, parliaments, and political circles to condemn extremist demonstrations under the penalty of complicity in the event of failure to condemn one or another excess. This month, there was an incredible scandal in Paris. The demonstration, which is actually difficult to describe, took place in the town hall. In the presence of the former Prime Minister of the Republic, Mr. Manuel Valls, in the presence of the incumbent mayor, Mrs. Anne Hidalgo, the international Grand Prix of secularity Inna Shevchenko was decorated, not only the leader of the extremist Femen, but also the person who beheaded the cross in Kiev, who was placed on the site of the execution of thousands of people murdered by the NKVD. This matter must be condemned in the first place by all who demand such condemnations. We hear very often that Parliament is asking for a response from our President. That is why I am asking Mr Tajani to expressly condemn this scandalous demonstration. I also strongly encourage my fellow socialists to expressly condemn this excess, which so violates the good name of your political community. Of course, this also obliges the party whose members are those who have allowed the author of this scandalous, extremist and insulting insult to be honored.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, it is clear that the European Union is in an existential crisis because of the citizens' dissatisfaction with it. Brexit is the first withdrawal of a Member State and if European policies do not change, more may follow. The Union must make substantial moves to improve people's lives. Instead, however, we see moves of cheap impression, such as the announcements of the summit on a pillar of social rights, which is in fact a copy of the provisions of the existing Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union on social protection. We need deeds, not words. We need policies that support employment, education, health and social security at a pan-European level. To do this we need an increase in the European Union budget, with a greater contribution from financially sound Member States. Change policy before it 's too late.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, ‘disappointing’ is the only way I can describe last week’s news that UK cities like Nottingham will not be allowed to bid to be European Capital of Culture in 2023. It is disappointing because all the UK candidate cities would have been excellent Capitals of Culture, but more disappointing because I believe this is a direct consequence of Brexit and also a consequence of the ineffective way that the UK Tory Government has acted since the referendum. It’s vital, in my view, that we know how many times the UK Government raised with the European Union representatives the specifics of the Capital of Culture rules and process before last week’s news. And it is ironic that we hear supposed anger about the news from those who campaigned for Brexit. However, Mr President, I appeal to the Commission this evening, on the basis of goodwill, to enter into discussions with those UK cities which aspired to be Capital of Culture in 2023, to see if there is any solution to the impasse in which we find ourselves today. I fear there may not be. But, as a Member of this Parliament for the past few weeks, my impression from other Member States is that there is a desire to forge a lasting, positive relationship with the UK. Celebrating our different cultures is a way to do that, and we must do that.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, in Bucharest we have again a serious crisis of the rule of law. It is, as in January, an attempt to change the laws of justice to protect corrupt politicians. Then the government used an emergency ordinance, now the dictatorship of the parliamentary majority is used. The SCM and more than 4,000 magistrates have shown that the changes will destroy the autonomy of the judiciary. The European Commission has asked the government to consult the Venice Commission, most of which have ignored all alarms. The heads of the two chambers have a direct interest in these changes, one of them being convicted and the other being under investigation for perjury. The two are the leaders of the parties that make up the ruling coalition, so the political stalemate is a major one. Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets and are waiting for help from Brussels. I'm afraid that just a harsh reaction can solve something else. Personally, I think it would be appropriate to activate Article 7 of the Treaty and suspend the voting rights of the representatives of the Romanian government in the Council.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: - Mr. President, a few days ago, I was visiting the port of Sète. A flagship of the economy of the Occitanie region, it generates more than 2,000 jobs and has seen its activity increase by 17% over the past three years. It offers its territory a window on the world and a valuable dynamic for the regional economy, both industrially and in terms of fishing and tourism. However, the free trade agreements imposed by the European Union are now paying a heavy price: the brutal and sudden competition between a local industry and foreign production. Here, the reduction in tariffs enjoyed by Argentine biofuel has the direct effect of a drop in activity of more than 30%. One hundred employees are left behind and the living area today is directly affected. I therefore call on the Commission to commit to preserving local employment, to change course and finally to defend the interests of citizens and local industrial tools through genuine protection of our internal markets at European level and through solidarity. To competition, let us oppose solidarity.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, once again I have come to speak for those who cannot speak from Western Sahara, for the Sahrawi political prisoners that Morocco has in its prisons, such as those who are part of Gdeim Izik's group. The number of Sahrawi political prisoners and the conditions to which they are subjected are inadmissible. These prisoners are in deplorable conditions, without adequate medical care, isolated, on hunger strike and confined to their cells for most of the day. It is urgent that the International Red Cross visit the prisoners of Gdeim Izik in order to have a real knowledge of their situation and to make visible to the world the mistreatment to which they are subjected. Finally, it is essential that Morocco regroup the prisoners and that it allows the right of visits, allowing relatives to have physical contact with their loved ones. Some are more than 1,300 kilometers from their homes, making it difficult for families to visit them. Morocco cannot continue to be a preferred partner for the European Union as long as the violation of human rights and political prisoners are kept in prison.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Mr President, a few hours ago the European Union-Catalonia dialogue platform was presented in this Parliament. Your manifesto has already been signed by 26 MEPs from all groups except the European People's Party and the Group around the Front National. Deeply concerned about the critical situation in Catalonia, the manifesto asks the European institutions for a gesture of responsibility that encourages dialogue to reach a solution to the conflict. Many Catalans regret that European leaders do not listen to us, but the number of citizens and institutions that speak out in favor of dialogue is growing, as does this platform. In addition, its members have addressed letters to the current President of Parliament and his predecessor, denouncing the serious situation in Catalonia and asking them to express themselves particularly in favor of two highly esteemed former members of the European Parliament, Oriol Junqueras and Raül Romeva, who are prisoners. politicians in Spain. Europe is already moving in the right direction of dialogue and respect for human rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, on the occasion of the 25th of November, I want to draw attention to the macho violence. Official data show that at least a third of European women have experienced acts of physical or sexual violence. I want to be at zero tolerance. I urge this Parliament to equip itself with the necessary mechanisms so that no aggressor can occupy a place here in this Parliament. I also call on this Parliament, the European Commission and the Member States to make an in-depth assessment of the application of equality laws and laws to combat male violence, to identify what are the causes that prevent further progress. I think it is essential that we implement an ambitious training program from a gender perspective for all people who are going to apply the laws, to avoid their development with a sexist bias. We believe that this training in a gender perspective should be mandatory for all people in public institutions who have a responsibility to implement the laws of equality and against violence. And when, Commissioner, will the directive to combat sexist violence?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.
